entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), either Loht or Maeve takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; only one of the two can use a lair action each round and the same effect can't be used two turns in a row.

items: Loht or Maeve teleports to a location within 60 feet of themselves, provided that both their current location and their target location is in dim light or darkness. They do not need to be able to see the target location.

Loht or Maeve casts dispel magic on one magical effect producing light within their lair, including fire, using their own spell attack modifier. Alternatively, they can extinguish all non-magical light sources within a room.

entries.name: The Erl Court
entries: The Erl Court is the fey court of Ravenloft. Ruled over by the twin Heirs of the Erlking, this court is the most insular of the fey courts, owing largely to its isolation within the near inescapable Demiplane of Dread.

entries.name: The Erl Tuatha
entries: The agents of Loht and Maeve are wily, powerful, and perilous. They roam the domains of dread, searching for the perfect humanoids to transform into their undying servants and pursuing the inscrutable whims of Loht and Maeve.

entries.name: Aamor the Joyous
entries: This {@creature alven} roams the domains of dread with her retinue of fellow alven in search of new flowers and trees to add to the Shadow Rift. When she finds one, she grafts a sample of the plant to her {@creature treant}, a kindly soul named Ubhal who loyally serves Aamor, bearing each foreign branch as a badge of honor.

Aamor is mischievous and playful. She and her retinue roam across Ravenloft during the evening, playing small pranks on the dull and leaving esoteric gifts for the clever. However, if they witness a humanoid unjustly injuring plantlife, they become vengeful and will enact a fitting punishment. Aamor and her retinue form an alvenbloom garden that has the additional 1/day each spells in its Innate Spellcasting: flesh to stone.

entries.name: Cowan the Rake
entries: This {@creature shay} is a scoundrel. He effortlessly seduces men and women all across Ravenloft, entrapping their hearts with songs of passion, leading them through a whirlwind evening romance. However, when morning comes, he is gone, leaving his lovers empty and alone. These poor, unfortunate souls are doomed to waste away, their hearts still belonging to Cowan. Eventually their love turns to bitterness and they transform into {@b harpies}, doomed to plague their homes and roam the skies, ever searching for their wayward love.

entries.name: Duana the Wise
entries: Duana is among the wisest of the {@creature sith}. She travels the dark paths of Ravenloft with her retinue searching for a means by which she can heal her lord Loht's grievous wounds. She possesses an understanding of the dark paths of necromancy to rival that of the greatest wizards of Thay, and her sithkin servants enable her to craft many strange and sinister magical wonders and devices. Her greatest obsession, however, is Count Strahd himself. Duana craves to understand the curse that binds him so fitfully to his existence.

Duana has gathered her retinue of advisers from all across the Domains of Dread.They accompany her through her wanderings in Ravenlost, riding astride {@b warhorse skeletons} and advising her on the ways of undeath. When they travel, they travel at night, a sinister party winding slowly through the mists of Ravenloft, illuminated by the pale ghost lights of {@b will o wisps}.

items: {@b Marya} was once a kind woman who worked as a healer for the people of Barovia. However, there was only so much she could do, and the grief of so many lives lost weighed heavily on her soul. When she died, her soul was bound to the earth as a {@creature ghost}, doomed to linger in Barovia until she found a way to save more lives. Duana found her and bound her to her services with the promise of helping save the king of the Arak, and now Marya is Duana's most trusted adviser.

{@b Aja} is a {@creature nothic}. Though he was once a wizard who pursued lichdom, he is now but a shell of his former self. Duana finds his fragmented ramblings fascinating, and hopes to understand the secrets of madness and the wisdom of despair by listening to his words.

{@b Ephraim} is a {@creature bodak} that Duana took an interest in, binding him with a mask to restrain his horrific gaze and aura of annihilation. He does not serve Duana willingly, being loyal only to Orcus, but Duana values the counsel of his hateful whispers, learning more from his blasphemous tongue than Ephraim intends to divulge.

monster.name: Morwel, the Queen of Stars

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Morwel's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 22}, {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

3e: {@spell mass healing word} ({@i as a 5th level spell})

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (5/Day)
entries: If Morwel fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead. If Morwel is removed from her palace, she can only use this feature 3 times per day, reducing her CR to 20 (25,000 XP).

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Morwel has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sidhe Weapon: Àréalta
entries: As a free action on her turn, Morwel can create a radiant rapier in a unoccupied hand. The sword uses Morwel's spellcasting modifier for attack and damage rolls and produces bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet. Morwel can only have one such weapon at any given time, and can dismiss it as a free action.

trait.name: True Glory
entries: While wearing her mantle of stars, Morwel’s True Glory is concealed. She can remove this mantle as a free action on her turn. Any humanoid or fiend that starts its turn within 60 feet of Morwel and can see Morwel while her mantle of stars is off must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw. If a creature fails the saving throw, it become {@condition blinded} until cured with {@spell greater restoration}. Additionally, if a creature fails its saving throw when it has 100 hit points or less, the creature immediately drops to 0 hit points. If a creature’s saving throw is successful, the creature is immune to Morwel’s True Glory for the next 24 hours.

Unless the target is surprised or the revelation of Morwel’s true glory is sudden, the target can avert its eyes and avoid making the initial saving throw. Until the start of its next turn, a creature that averts its eyes has disadvantage on attack rolls against Morwel.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of Morwel includes her Charisma bonus.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Morwel makes three attacks with either her Rapier or Chromatic Ray.

action.name: Àréalta (Rapier, Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 1d8 + 9}) piercing damage, plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage (Morwel's choice).

action.name: Chromatic Ray
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 14} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid, cold, fire, lightning, radiant, or thunder damage (Morwel's choice).

action.name: Teleport
entries: Morwel teleports to an unoccupied space that she can see within 60 feet.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Rainbow Light
entries: Morwel transforms into a Medium orb of scintillating colors or back into her humanoid form. All equipment that she is wearing or carrying merges into this form. In light form, Morwel's statistics remain the same except for the following changes: she has a flying speed of 60 feet, she is ephemeral and cannot carry anything, and she is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained}.

reaction.name: Arcane Parry
entries: If Morwel succeeds on a saving throw against a spell, the spell targeting her fails and the spell slot used to cast it is wasted. If she is targeted by a spell with an attack roll, she can add 5 to her AC after seeing the attack result. Morwel can only utilize this ability if she is wielding her sidhe weapon.

legendaryHeader: Morwel can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Morwel regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack.
entries: Morwel makes one attack with Àréalta.

legendary.name: Astral Shield
entries: Morwel creates a shimmering, opalescent field of magical light around herself or another creature that she can see within 60 feet of her. The target gains a +2 bonus to AC until the end of Morwel's next turn.

legendary.name: Magic (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Morwel casts a spell from her Innate Spellcasting feature, choosing from only her {@b at will} and {@b 3/day} options.

entries.name: Archfey
entries: The archfey are beings of incredible power and influence within the Feywild. Almost any variety of creature can become an archfey. Some, such as Titania and Hyrsam, are members of fey races that have gained almost godlike powers over the course of their long lives. Others, such as Oberon or The Sovereign Elk, are awakened spirits of nature. Beings such as the Prince of Frost or Selephra, the Bramble Queen, are eladrin who have gained power from their long lives and deep passion. Some are not even strictly fey, but are instead beings that have gained such power with the Feywild that they have gained the mantle of archfey, such as Relkath of the Infinite Branches and Razcoreth, the Whispering Wyrm.

Morwel is among the fairest beings in all creation. Her hair is fiery auburn and her skin is honeyed gold. Her beauty is so pure, so absolute, that mortals that gaze on her unfiltered are blinded. As such, she keeps herself wrapped in a mantle of stars to spare unsuspecting mortals that fate. She regards all with aloof interest, and is intrigued by many. Though flighty and pretentious, she is never cruel and strives to ensure that all who visit her realm of Tír Naofa find the experience to be of perfect enjoyment. Every chamber and hall in her crystal palace is filled with earthly delights: magnificent feasts, dances, pleasure rooms, art galleries, baths, and more can be found in her palace.

entries.name: Lovers of the Queen
entries: Though Morwel takes many lovers as the mood strikes her, the greatest share of her affection is always reserved for her consorts. Currently, the roles of consort are filled by Faerinaal, the Dancing Mage and Gwynharwyf, the Whirling Fury. Faerinaal is a tulani in possession of incredible magical skill, aloofly polite though profoundly kind, and he acts as ambassador for his mistress in the fey courts of the earthly realms, the celestial courts of the Upper Planes, and beyond. Gwynharwyf, on the other hand, is a boisterous bralani warrior, quick to make friends and always looking for the next adventure, who leads frequent conquests against evil across the planes, though always returning to the arms of her mistress. She frequently ventures from Tír Naofa on missions to strike down demons, wicked dragons, and slavetakers. She shows no mercy to those who would enslave others, but is kind to the helpless.

entries.name: Friends in High Places
entries: Lady Morwel has never left Tír Naofa in all the time she has ruled there, and many believe that if she were to do so the realm would collapse. However, this has not stopped her from forging alliances with beings all across the multiverse. Faerinaal travels all across the planes on her behalf, and he has forged alliances with Titania, Bahamut, the Storm Kings of Arcadia, the Beast Lords, the Wind Dukes of Aaqa, and more. Morwel often entertains guests as varied as angels, djinni, metallic dragons, and archfey in her palace.

These alliances have served her well, as Morwel is a staunch foe of all demons, having participated in the war against the Queen of Chaos long ago. She remains a fervent enemy of the fiends, holding a particular hatred for Baphomet, as he still retains the souls of an entire generation of eladrin children in his realm. Morwel often sends hunting parties of good fey and celestial sidhe to root out demonic infestations on the Material Plane and Feywild, and even sends her warriors into the Abyss itself.

entries.name: Aisha
entries: Aisha is a {@creature djinni} who frequents the Court of Stars. As Morwel's most favored lover from the Plane of Air, Aisha acts as the ambassador between the Queen of the Stars and the Great Caliph of the djinn, spending much of her time in the Citadel of Ice and Steel attended to by {@creature bralani}, {@creature sylph}, {@creature boreal}, {@creature nephele}, and {@creature shiradi}. She also acts as ambassador to the Wind Dukes of Aaqa on the rare occasions when it becomes necessary.

entries.name: Vaeros
entries: A proud and vigorous celestial {@creature ghaele|TheFeyCompendium} warrior, Vaeros has dedicated himself to protecting the eladrin children that remain imprisoned within Baphomet's Infinite Labyrinth, fighting with a ferocity unmatched by any other creature within that wretched place. Though he was once a consort of Morwel, he has since abandoned that pleasure to defend the innocents trapped in the Abyss, bringing whatever light and joy he can to their poor souls. His sidhe broadsword has been empowered to possess the powers of a {@item holy avenger}.

entries.name: Niezzae, The Gentle
entries: Niezzae is an {@creature adult gold dragon}. They reside on an island in the center of a beautiful lake, and often takes the form of a beautiful elven man or woman. Niezzae does not favor one gender over another, seemingly able to transition fluidly between the two. Their hoard contains a vast number of weapons, which they may lend to the good of heart. They are especially fond of promoting just kings and queens to thrones.

entries.name: Krune
entries: Krune is an {@creature androsphinx} that adores Lady Morwel and visits her whenever he can. He is assigned guardianship of a secret portal to Tír Naofa and he takes his duty very seriously. He accrues treasure as a diversion, to trick adventurers into believing that the only thing of value in his realm is the valuables he guards. In his spare time, Krune tends to injured creatures, and he has a number of favorite mice and birds that he cares for dotingly.

entries.name: Criostal Lùchairt
entries: Morwel's palace is an elegant, towering confection of moonstone, opal, mother of pearl, and other precious stones and gems. It stands at the peak of a large but gentle hill, its gardens spilling out from its walls and down the slopes. From her palace Morwel can look out across the entirety of her realm, cherishing every flickering bonfire and faerie lantern like stars in a night sky.

monster.name: Faerinaal

immune.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Faerinaal's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Faerinaal is an 20th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 22}, {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). Faerinaal has the following wizard spells prepared, and can cast them without material components so long as he wielding Aheagna:

trait.name: Glamour
entries: Any humanoid that its turn within 30 feet of Faerinaal and can see Faerinaal's true form must make a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition charmed} by Faerinaal for as long as it can see Faerinaal. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if Faerinaal is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Faerinaal's Glamour for the next 24 hours.

Unless the target is surprised or the revelation of Faerinaal's true form is sudden, the target can avert its eyes and avoid making the initial saving throw. Until the start of its next turn, a creature that averts its eyes has disadvantage on Attack rolls against Faerinaal.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Faerinaal has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Faerinaal fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Sidhe Weapon: Aheagna
entries: As a free action on his turn, Faerinaal can create a radiant rapier in an unoccupied hand. The sword uses Faerinaal’s spellcasting modifier for attack and damage rolls and produces bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 15 feet. Faerinaal can only have one such weapon at any given time, and can dismiss the weapon as a free action.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of Faerinaal includes his Charisma bonus.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Faerinaal makes two attacks with Aheagna.

action.name: Aheagna (Rapier)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d8 + 7}) radiant damage, plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage.

action.name: Dancing Sword
entries: Faerinaal releases Aheagna to hover magically in an unoccupied space within 5 ft. of him. If Faerinaal can see the sword, Faerinaal can mentally command it as a bonus action to fly up to 50 ft. and either make one attack against a target or return to his hands. If the hovering sword is targeted by any effect, Faerinaal is considered to be holding it.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Faerie-light
entries: Faerinaal transforms into a Medium orb of faerie-light or back into his humanoid form. All equipment that he is wearing or carrying merge into this form. In light form, Faerinaal's statistics remain the same except for the following changes: he has a flying speed of 60 feet, he is ephemeral and cannot carry anything, he produces bright illumination out to 30 feet and dim illumination out to an additional 30 feet, and he is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained}.

legendaryHeader: Faerinaal can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Faerinaal regains his spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

legendary.name: Faerie Blade
entries: Faerinaal uses his Dancing Sword action.

legendary.name: Gaze {@recharge 6}
entries: Faerinaal targets one creature {@condition charmed} by it within 60 feet of it. If the target can see Faerinaal, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw against this magic or drop to 0 hit points.

legendary.name: Moonlight (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Faerinaal casts {@spell guiding bolt} or {@spell moonbeam}.

monster.name: Gwynharwyf

immune.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Gwynharwyf's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Gwynharwyf fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Gwynharwyf has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, Gwynharwyf can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against her have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Sidhe Weapon: Afraoch
entries: As a free action on her turn, Gwynharwyf can create a scimitar in each unoccupied hand. The scimitars are magical weapons and use Gwynharwyf's spellcasting modifier for attack and damage rolls. Gwynharwyf can only have up to two scimitars conjured at any given time, and can dismiss one or both as a free action.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of Gwynharwyf includes her Charisma bonus.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Gwynharwyf makes two scimitar attacks.

action.name: Afraoch (Scimitar, Humanoid form only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage. If the target has at least one head and Gwynharwyf rolled a 20 on the attack roll, the target is decapitated and dies if it can’t survive without the head. A target is immune to this effect if it takes none of the damage, has legendary actions, or is Huge or larger. Such a creature takes an extra 27 ({@damage 6d8}) slashing damage from the hit.

action.name: Whirlwind (Sidhe Form only) {@recharge 4}
entries: Each creature in Gwynharwyf ‘s space must make a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw. On a failure, a target is either {@condition restrained} or thrown by Gwynharwyf.

A creature can use its action to free a creature {@condition restrained} by Gwynharwyf, including itself, by succeeding on a {@dc 18} Strength check. If the check succeeds, the creature is no longer {@condition restrained} and moves to the nearest space outside the whirlwind.

A creature thrown by Gwynharwyf takes 17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and is flung up 50 feet away from her in a direction of her choice and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes an object, such as a wall or floor, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. If the saving throw is successful, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and isn’t flung away or knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Glittering Whirlwind
entries: Gwynharwyf magically polymorphs into 20-foot tall, 5- foot radius whirlwind of glittering snow or back into her humanoid form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (Gwynharwyf's choice). In whirlwind form, Gwynharwyf’s statistics remain the same except for the following changes: she has a flying speed of 120 feet and she is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained}.

reaction.name: Answering Strike
entries: When Gwynharwyf takes damage from an attack or spell, she makes one Afraoch attack with advantage against any creature within reach. If she is wielding two Afraochs, she can take this reaction twice in one round.

legendaryHeader: Gwynharwyf can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Gwynharwyf regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Whilrling Fury
entries: Gwynharwyf uses her Multiattack action.

legendary.name: Swift Wind (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Gwynharwyf assumes her sidhe shape and then moves up to 60 feet.

monster.name: Siobhan of the Hidden Depths

immune.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Siobhan's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 22}, {@hit 14} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Siobhan can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Siobhan fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Siobhan has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Seductive Luminescence
entries: While in dim light or darkness, Siobhan produces dim light out to 30 feet. While a creature is within this light, it has disadvantage on all Wisdom saving throws against effects created by Siobhan, and Siobhan has advantage on all Charisma checks made towards the creature.

trait.name: Speak with Ocean Creatures
entries: Siobhan can communicate with marine beasts, plants and monstrosities as if they shared a language.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Siobhan makes two attacks, choosing between Touch and Water Lash for each.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) cold damage.

action.name: Water Lash
entries: Siobhan causes a 10-foot cube of water within 60 feet of her to take a shape of her choice and strike one target she can see within 5 feet of that water. The target must make a {@dc 22} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) bludgeoning damage, and if the target is a Large or smaller creature it is either pushed up to 15 feet in a straight line or knocked {@condition prone} (Siobhan's choice). On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and isn’t pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Drowning Sphere
entries: Siobhan used her Water Lash action. If the target fails its saving throw, it is {@condition restrained} in a sphere of water instead of being pushed or knocked {@condition prone}. While {@condition restrained} by water in this way, the target takes 27 ({@damage 5d10}) bludgeoning damage and loses its breath, even if it can breathe water, and immediately starts suffocating. Siobhan can maintain one drowning sphere at a time, as if concentrating on a spell. The sphere can levitate up to 30 feet above any surface, and a bonus action on each of her turns Siobhan can move the sphere up to 30 feet in a direction of her choice, including up. The target can repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Ghostlight
entries: Siobhan transforms into a Medium orb of pale light or back into her humanoid form. All equipment that she is wearing or carrying merge into this form. In light form, Siobhan's statistics remain the same except that she is ephemeral and cannot carry anything and she is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained}.

legendaryHeader: Siobhan can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Siobhan regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Siobhan makes one Touch attack.

legendary.name: Magic
entries: Siobhan casts one at will spell from her Innate Spellcasting feature.

legendary.name: Melancholy
entries: One creature within 60 feet of Siobhan that can hear her must make a {@dc 22} Charisma saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage on a failure or half as much on a success. Additionally, on a failure, the target loses one inspiration or the benefits of one protective or enhancing spell that is affecting it, such as {@spell enhance ability}, and cannot receive or benefit from {@classFeature bardic inspiration|Bard||1} until the end of Siobhan's next turn.

entries.name: Archfey
entries: The archfey are beings of peerless power in the Feywild. Powerful, perilous, and amazing, the archfey are not to be trifled with. Some were once worshiped as gods by humanoids, while others have little interest in the brief lives of those who walk in the mortal lands.

All the races who travel the oceans have their legends about the dark lady beneath the waters. To humans she is a temptress who lures sailors to their doom. To the aquatic elves she is dangerous and wonderful, to be loved and respected from a distance. To the merfolk she is a whispered legend. To the storm giants she is an aloof figure in their prophecies. To the sahuagin she is a terror deep beneath their hunting grounds. To the tritons she is a beautiful and perilous hero. For her part, Siobhan keeps her own council, in her strange castle at the bottom of the sea where no sun ever goes.

entries.name: The Grieving Palace
entries: Her heart broken and her limbs coated in blood, Selephra returned to the cottage that she spent so many years waiting in, and her bitter vengeance followed her. Neither kingdom now stands, only tangled forests of thorns fraught with vengeful wraiths, weeping ghosts, and cruel fey. She resides in that cottage still, calling it her Grieving Palace, and she is served by fawning sprites and doting hags. Guests in this morose place are served muddy tea from cracked glasses and moldy food on filthy plates. Those who comment on the squalor are tortured in horrible ways.

entries.name: Mysterious
entries: Though calm and melancholy, slow to anger and quiet in the face of a challenge, she is constantly contemplating, turning over new ideas behind her dark eyes. There are stories of entire cities washed away for a slight against the deep lady, and those who doubt her power always do so as far from the ocean as possible.

entries.name: Quiet
entries: The flamboyant politics of the Summer Court and the sinister intrigue of the Gloaming Court hold little appeal for Siobhan, who prefers to let others do as they will so long as they permit her her privacy. As such, she involves herself little in the petty squabbles between Titania and the Queen of Air and Darkness. Siobhan prefers to spend her time in quiet thought, meandering through her gardens of steam or the eerily glowing clouds of jellyfish that fill her realm.

Stories tell that Siobhan was not always like this. Once she was a fey lord to rival Titania and the Queen of Air and Darkness, deftly maneuvering through the intricate politics of fey courts as elegantly as a darting fish, ruling the streams and lakes of Faerun alongside her brother Delimbyr, the Lord Shining. However, while her brother became more and more involved in the clever machinations of his fellow lords, Siobhan became disaffected with all the flippant pageantry, yearning for something more. She left the rivers and journeyed through the seas.

entries.name: Siobhan's Lair
entries: Siobhan makes her lair deep at the bottom of the sea, where the only light comes from bio-luminescent creatures drifting serenely through the dark currents. Her palace is carved from volcanic rock and strange, shadow loving coral, illuminated only by the strange glow of the creatures that inhabit the deepest ocean depths.

monster.name: Thrumbolg, First Lord of Mag Tureah

immune.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

trait.name: Cheat Fate
entries: Thrumbolg automatically becomes stable when reduced to 0 hit points and cannot die unless damaged with Brionac when at 0 hit points.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: Thrumbolg fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Thrumbolg uses his Evil Eye, then makes two attacks with Areadbhar and one attack with Gae Bulg.

action.name: Areadbhar (Spear)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) piercing damage, or 20 ({@damage 3d8 + 7}) piercing damage if used with both hands. The target has disadvantage on any Constitution saving throws it makes to maintain concentration on a spell as a result of this attack.

action.name: Gae Bulg (Javelin)
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 14} to hit, reach 10 ft. or range 90/360 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Flying Javelin
entries: Thrumbolg releases Gae Bulg to hover magically in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of him. If Thrumbolg can see Gae Bulg, he can mentally command it to move up to 90 feet and make one attack against a target, after which it magically teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of him. If Gae Bulg is targeted by any effect, Thrumbolg is considered to be wielding it. Gae Bulg falls if Thrumbolg is reduced to 0 hit points or dies.

action.name: Evil Eye
entries: One creature that Thrumbolg can see within 60 feet of him must make a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) psychic damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. Additionally, if the target fails the saving throw, roll a {@dice d6}. Based on the roll, the target suffers a random effect from the following options:

items: {@b Eye of Command:} The target is affected as if with the {@spell command} spell, which requires no verbal components from Thrumbolg.
{@b Eye of Death:} The target takes an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.
{@b Eye of Obeisance:} The target falls {@condition prone} and cannot stand up until the end of Thrumbolg's next turn.
{@b Eye of Pain:} The target is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.
{@b Eye of Retribution:} If Thrumbolg had been damaged by the target since the end of his last turn, then he has advantage on all attacks made on that target until the beginning of his next turn.
{@b Eye of Terror:} The target is {@condition frightened} until the end of Thrumbolg's next turn.

legendaryHeader: Thrumbolg can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Thrumbolg regains his spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

legendary.name: Javelin
entries: Thrumbolg makes one attack with Flying Javelin.

legendary.name: Hateful Glance (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Thrumbolg makes one Evil Eye attack against a target that he can see.

entries.name: Archfey
entries: The archfey are beings of incredible power and influence within the Feywild. Almost any variety of creature can become an archfey. Some, such as Titania and Hyrsam, are members of fey races that have gained almost godlike powers over the course of their long lives. Others, such as Oberon or The Sovereign Elk, are awakened spirits of nature. Beings such as the Prince of Frost or Selephra, the Bramble Queen, are eladrin who have gained power from their long lives and deep passion. Some are not even strictly fey, but are instead beings that have gained such power with the Feywild that they have gained the mantle of archfey, such as Relkath of the Infinite Branches and Razcoreth, the Whispering Wyrm.

Thrumbolg is a name feared throughout the Feydark. As the mightiest of all fomorians, Thrumbolg is renowned for his cruelty and fanaticism. Like his kin, Thrumbolg is monstrously ugly, his eyes mismatched and lopsided, his swarthy arms awkwardly shaped and malformed, his gait strange and uneven. Unlike his disorderly kin, however, Thrumbolg rules his own realm: the mighty fortress-city of Mag Tureah, where he lords his power over his subjects. Fomorians, cyclops, trolls, ogres, and orcs crack their whips on the backs of wretched humanoid slaves, worked until they can no longer work, whereupon they are devoured and replaced. Mag Tureah is a city of misery.

entries.name: Legacy of Domination
entries: Once the fomorians were the fairest and most magically skilled of the giant race, and they crafted many a wonder. However, as cruelty grew in their hearts, they began to craft more dark and sinister creations, the crowning achievement of which they nestled deep beneath the earth in the Feydark: Mag Tureah, the Iron Tower. A work of magic unsurpassed by giant hands, the winding tunnels and halls of Mag Tureah boast a myriad of portals that stretch across the multiverse. However, when the fomorians were defeated the fortress was abandoned.

For centuries Mag Tureah lay masterless beneath the earth, its halls and tunnels breeding grounds for the strange aberrations that fester in the dark places. Many fomorians would try to reclaim their ancestral home, but it would not be until the mighty Thrumbolg lead a mighty siege that Mag Tureah would again have a lord; the First Lord. However, the secrets of Mag Tureah were long forgotten, lost to the fomorians when first they were struck down. Undeterred, Thrumbolg has dedicated millenia to deciphering the inner workings of Mag Tureah, his life extended unnaturally long by unknown means, his efforts continually confounded by the inscrutability of the portals.

entries.name: Legacy of Cruelty
entries: Once, Mag Tureah received a distinguished guest in the form of Baba Yaga. While Baba Yaga stayed as his guest, Thrumbolg demanded that she reveal the future to him. At once outraged and delighted by this young upstart's gall, Baba Yaga cursed him with a prophecy, stating that his death would be by the will of his son. Reasoning that if he killed all his sons that he would become immortal, Thrumbolg decreed the deaths of Goibniu the Smith, Conand the Cruel, and Tethra the Mighty.

When word reached Goibniu of the deaths of his two brothers, he realized his peril. With the aid of an unknown patron, Goibniu used his formidable skill in crafting to forge a spear out of his raw fury and will to live. He named this sword Brionac, the Bright One, and with it in hand he went off to confront his father. The battle was long and arduous, and before Giobniu could land the final blow against his father, an assassin struck him down. Before Thrumbolg could claim the spear, though, Brionac was spirited away from Mag Tureah, thus ensuring that his will to slay his father lived on after his death. Now only Brionac can slay Thrumbolg.

monster.name: Elder Carey Hag

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder carey hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Kingsbroom.
entries: The elder carey hag carries a kingsbroom, which functions as a {@item broom of flying}. While holding the broom, she can cast {@spell mass suggestion} at will, targeting only air and water based elementals (including creatures such as {@creature invisible stalker}, {@creature smoke mephit}, and {@creature water weird}). If the broom is lost or destroyed, the elder carey hag must craft another, which takes a year and a day. Only an elder carey hag can use a kingsbroom.

trait.name: Storm Rider
entries: The elder carey hag ignores difficult terrain created by wind and automatically succeeds on saving throws to resist wind based effects and spells.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder carey hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder carey hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder carey hag can use her Thunderous Cackle. She then makes two attacks with her claws.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Thunderous Cackle
entries: Each creature of the elder carey hag's choice that is within 120 feet of the elder carey hag and can hear her must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened} in this way, a creature has disadvantage on all Strength ability checks and saving throws. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the elder carey hag's Thunderous Cackle for the next 24 hours.

legendaryHeader: The elder carey hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The elder carey hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder carey hag makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder carey hag casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Blow Me Down (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder carey hag releases an explosive burst of air. All creatures within 15 feet of the hag must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be pushed 5 feet away from the hag and knocked {@condition prone}.

While sea hags prefer jagged coasts and the coral reefs of the shallows, the carey hags prefer the broad stretches of the skies above the fathomless open ocean. By far the least hideous of the hags, a carey hag resembles an austere middle aged woman in simple, pragmatic clothing. This appearance belies their cruelty. They prowl the ocean skies, searching for victims. They command lightning and wind, and their thunderous voice can sap the will to fight of those who hear it, consigning them to the briny depths.

entries.name: Strict and Unbending
entries: In stark contrast to the chaotic skies, carey hags are rigid and unwavering in their rules. They command air elementals to herd the clouds in their domains in the way that they see fit, not tolerating even a single wisp out of line. They find the flightiness of other fey to be tedious and frustrating, and as such are more likely to be found attended to by devils. They often take husbands, typically fiends and giants, and expect absolute loyalty from their partners.

entries.name: Kind to be Cruel
entries: Though they love drowning seafarers, they have a soft spot for the bold. Those sailors that dare to brave a storm may find that they attract the fickle, matronly affection of a carey hag. Many bold sea captains have found great success from doting carey hags who have calmed storms and laid low their enemies. However, their punishments to their “little dearies” who break the rules are always brutal and absolute.

Most peculiar of all is the carey hag's fondness for children and tiny fairies. Make no mistake, they will not hesitate to kill a child, but they have often taken mercy on the poor child's soul, transforming them into asrai or sylph. No one knows why they do this.

entries.name: Covens
entries: An elder carey hag that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) has a challenge rating of 14 (11,500 XP).

entries.name: An Elder Carey Hag's Lair
entries: Carey hags prefer their homes to be mobile, favoring dilapidated sea faring vessels or rude huts cobbled together on solidified clouds. However, they may occasionally find it beneficial to settle down for a time to work on a delicate project, favoring barren islands and rocky coasts.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A elder carey hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions. Those actions happen on Initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties).

items: The hag electrifies the air within a 15 foot cube that she can see inside her lair. Any creature within that cube must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until initiative count 20 of the following round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful elder carey hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: The skies around a carey hag's lair are always overcast or rainy, and the wind and rain are likely to pick up at a moment's notice. This makes navigating seafaring and skyfaring vessels dangerous, imposing disadvantage on all navigation (survival) checks.

Ghost ships may be glimpsed roaming the waters near a carey hag's lair. Ghost ships may take a variety of appearances. Some may appear as dilapidated ships, masts snapped, sails torn, and hull breached, accompanied by will o wisps or spectral fish. Others may appear to be in perfect repair but burst into flame when approached and continue to sail unabated. Ghost ships may also be manned by {@creature skeletons}, {@creature specters}, fiends, or stranger creatures.

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The deemves hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Bureaucracy
entries: A creature has disadvantage on saving throws against spells cast by the deemves hag if the deemves hag knows the creature's full name and at least two of the following facts about the creature:

items: The creature's age
The creature's race
The creature's astrological sign
The creature's hometown

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deemves hag makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The deemves hag magically polymorphs into a unique humanoid, or back into her true form. Her statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn’t transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.

bonus.name: Doldrums
entries: The deemves hag can activate or deactivate this feature as a bonus action. While active, any creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the deemves hag must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature's is affected as if by the {@spell slow} spell until the beginning of the creature's next turn. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the deemves hag’s Doldrums for the next 24 hours.

Deemves hags were once night hags who made a deal with Adramalech, the Chancellor of Hell and right hand of Asmodeus, in their quest for power. Now they work for the infernal bureaucracy as free agents. They seek to control the people around them, using every advantage and scrap of information that they can get their claws on to exert as much control as they possibly can. In their true form, they appear as dumpy old women with dull red skin and small devilish horns. However, they typically prefer to disguise themselves as humanoids when outside of the Nine Hells. Regardless of what form they take, they always dress themselves in dowdy clothing and strive to appear as harmless as possible.

entries.name: Infernal Bureaucrats
entries: Deemves hags adore bureaucracy, and they delight in all the myriad ways that their power can be abused while still adhering to the letter of the laws that they seek to twist. Adramalech has a certain fondness for these harridans and has them installed as bureaucrats all throughout the Hells. However, the Chancellor is alone in his fondness of these hags, as they love to confound the plots of other devils with malicious application of obscure rules and willful misinterpretation of intent.

entries.name: A Menace on the Material Plane
entries: Many deemves hags have managed to leave the Nine Hells, installing themselves as bureaucracts and political figures in Material Plane worlds so that they can advance their plans. Like every other devil, a deemves hag strives to eventually supplant Asmodeus as the Lord of All Nine Hells. To that end, they sabotage civil structures, ruining the lives of mortals so that they can entrap their souls with promises of reprieve. They obsessively gather information on every creature they encounter, knowing that any piece of knowledge can eventually be used to their advantage.

entries.name: Slow Misery
entries: A deemves hag feels most at home surrounded by irate, miserable people. They love to drain the beauty out of the world around them, forbidding bright colored clothing, elegant architecture, flowers, and other things of loveliness. Their powers can cause a second to seem to drag on for eternity, dilating the misery of those cursed to be in their presence. Even fighting a deemves hag is a tortuous event.

entries.name: Designated Shape
entries: Unlike other hags, a deemves hag cannot disguise herself as just any creature. Rather, she can only transform into a single humanoid form, the appearance of which must be approved by the intricate legal system of Hell. The hag cannot choose another form without going through a long and arduous of filing paperwork and awaiting approval for each individual detail, and as such deemves hags take great pains to prevent their true forms from being associated with their disguised forms.

entries.name: A Deemves Hag's Lair
entries: Deemves hags prefer to lair in or near metropolitan areas, as they prefer to have a hands on approach to spreading misery and controlling the weak. Their homes are always unassuming from the outside, and their magical paraphrenailia is always well hidden.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A deemves hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions. Those actions happen on Initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties).

items: The hag forces all creatures in her lair to reroll initiative. She can choose to exclude herself from this roll.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful deemves hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: People easily misplace important documents in the area, and such documents may be impossible to find without a locate object spell until after they were needed.

entries: When the hag dies, this effect fades after {@dice 1d6} days.

entries.name: Deemves Magic
entries: The magic of a deemves hag is based around their knowledge of their victim in accordance with their Bureaucracy trait.

{@b Flesh Shaping.} The hag can shape a {@creature lemure} into an imperfect clone of a creature with a ritual that takes 1 hour to perform, provided that the hag possesses all the information about the creature detailed in her Bureaucracy trait. The clone has the statistics of a commoner and possesses patchwork knowledge of the creature's memories. It is convincing enough to trick most observers, but people familiar with the creature will be able to detect inconsistencies in the clone's behavior. The hag can revoke the magic that empowers the clone as a free action at any time, causing it to immediately transform back into a {@creature lemure}.

{@b Scrying.} Though a deemves hag cannot cast scrying on her own, many will develop tools such as bowls, teacups, and mirrors which can cast the spell 1 to 3 times per day, while the more cunning may be able to get their hands on a crystal ball or two. When a deemves hag targets a creature with the {@spell scrying} spell, the hag is considered familiar with the target if she knows the target's full name and 1 other fact about it as described in her Bureaucracy trait. If she knows the creature's full name and three other such facts about it, the target's save penalty increases to -7, and if the hag knows all four such facts about the creature it increases to -8.

monster.name: Elder Deemves Hag

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

The creature's race
The creature's astrological sign
The creature's hometown

While active, any creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the elder deemves hag must make a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the elder deemves hag’s Doldrums for the next 24 hours.

entries: If the elder deemves hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder deemves hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder deemves hag makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The elder deemves hag magically polymorphs into a unique humanoid, or back into her true form. Her statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying isn’t transformed. She reverts to her true form if she dies.

legendaryHeader: The elder deemves hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The elder deemves hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder deemves hag makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder deemves hag casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Please Wait Your Turn (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder deemves hag chooses one creature that she can see that has not taken its turn yet this round. The target cannot take its turn or make reactions until after the elder deemves hag's turn this round.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The deep hag's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: Additionally, at the start of each of the deep hag’s turns, roll a d8. The deep hag can then cast the spell rolled as a bonus action on her turn.

entries: If the deep hag rolls a spell she is concentrating on, she can continue to maintain concentration on it. Otherwise, she loses concentration on any spell from this option.

3e: {@spell disguise self} ({@i including the form of a Medium aquatic humanoid})

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The deep hag can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Madness
entries: The deep hag has advantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The deep hag makes three attacks: two with its claws and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 3d4 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

Deep hags are the hags of madness. Residing within the deepest depths of the ocean, they consort with krakens, aboleths, and fouler creatures long forgotten by the sane world. Hideously ugly, their long, bloated, eel-like bodies are perfectly adapted to the depths at which they prefer to reside, and their dozens of needle-like teeth and razor sharp webbed claws enable them to capture and feast on any creature they wish. Preferring the peace and dark of the deep, these hags would be nothing more than a distant horror were it not for the dreams of the surface world that plague them, compelling them to it on moonless or stormy nights to plague its inhabitants with terror and to cure them of their sanity.

entries.name: Madness From the Depths
entries: The deep hags are irrevocably insane, and they spread that madness wherever they go. The sheer weight of their insanity follows them like a stench. The plans that they hatch are incomprehensible to sane minds, relying on wild jumps of logic and impossible coincidences that the hag seems to somehow expect. The magic that they use is even more madenning, and the ways in which they twist the minds and flesh of their victims to create new monstrosities is enough to drive some to insanity just by seeing it.

entries.name: Wild Psionics
entries: A deep hag is naturally psionic, but her madness makes these powers wildly unpredictable. The chaotic inner workings of the hag’s mind cause her innate powers to shift from moment to moment, and it’s anyone’s guess as to which power she will display next. This makes them difficult to fight, as they shift tactics from moment to moment, adapting immediately to whatever power their brains manifest as if planned all along. Their madness even grants them resistance to mental effects, as their continually writhing minds easily wriggle out of attempts to charm or frighten them.

entries.name: A Deep Hag's Lair
entries: A deep hag always makes her lair on or near the ocean floor, preferably at a depth that light cannot reach. However, if compelled to the surface she will construct a temporary lair near the shore, typically in a submerged cavern that she fills with all the strange, maddening things from the great depths.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A deep hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions. Those actions happen on Initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties).

items: The hag draws on the innate magic of her lair, allowing her to exercise a measure of control over her madness. At the beginning of her next turn when she rolls for her random psionic ability, she can roll twice and choose whichever roll she prefers. Alternatively, she can choose to forgo the roll entirely and retain whatever power she currently possesses.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful deep hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Native creatures behave in strange and unnatural ways. Fish and crabs may move in ways that crudely mimic the behavior of land dwelling creatures such as birds or mice, while others may move erratically or behave in self destructive ways.

entries: If the hag dies, this effect fade after {@dice 1d6} days.

monster.name: Elder Deep Hag

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The elder deep hag's innate spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: Additionally, at the start of each of the hag’s turns, roll a {@dice d8}. The elder deep hag can then cast the spell rolled as a bonus action on her turn.

entries: If the elder deep hag rolls a spell she is concentrating on, she can continue to maintain concentration on it. Otherwise, she loses concentration on any spell from this option.

3e: {@spell alter self} ({@i including the form of a Medium aquatic humanoid})

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The elder deep hag can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder deep hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder deep hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder deep hag makes three attacks: two with her claws and one with her bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d4 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

legendaryHeader: The elder deep hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The elder deep hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder deep hag makes one claw or slam attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder deep hag casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Madness (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: All creatures within 30 feet of the elder deep hag must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or gain a form of short term {@variantrule madness} until the end of the elder deep hag's next turn.

Deep hags are the hags of madness. Residing within the deepest depths of the ocean, they consort with krakens, aboleths, and fouler creatures long forgotten by the sane world. Hideously ugly, their long, bloated, eel-like bodies are perfectly adapted to the depths at which they prefer to reside, and their dozens of needle-like teeth and razor sharp webbed claws enable them to capture and feast on any creature they wish. Preferring the peace and dark of the deep, these hags would be nothing more than a distant horror were it not for the dreams of the surface world that plague them, compelling them to it on moonless or stormy nights to plague its inhabitants with terror and to cure them of their sanity.

entries.name: Madness From the Depths
entries: The deep hags are irrevocably insane, and they spread that madness wherever they go. The sheer weight of their insanity follows them like a stench. The plans that they hatch are incomprehensible to sane minds, relying on wild jumps of logic and impossible coincidences that the hag seems to somehow expect. The magic that they use is even more madenning, and the ways in which they twist the minds and flesh of their victims to create new monstrosities is enough to drive some to insanity just by seeing it.

entries.name: Wild Psionics
entries: A deep hag is naturally psionic, but her madness makes these powers wildly unpredictable. The chaotic inner workings of the hag’s mind cause her innate powers to shift from moment to moment, and it’s anyone’s guess as to which power she will display next. This makes them difficult to fight, as they shift tactics from moment to moment, adapting immediately to whatever power their brains manifest as if planned all along. Their madness even grants them resistance to mental effects, as their continually writhing minds easily wriggle out of attempts to charm or frighten them.

entries.name: Covens
entries: An elder deep hag that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) has a challenge rating of 15 (13,000 XP).

entries.name: An Elder Deep Hag's Lair
entries: A elder deep hag always makes her lair on or near the ocean floor, preferably at a depth that light cannot reach. However, if compelled to the surface she will construct a temporary lair near the shore, typically in a submerged cavern that she fills with all the strange, maddening things from the great depths.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: An elder deep hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions. Those actions happen on Initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties).

items: The hag draws on the innate magic of her lair, allowing her to exercise a measure of control over her madness. At the beginning of her next turn when she rolls for her random psionic ability, she can roll twice and choose whichever roll she prefers. Alternatively, she can choose to forgo the roll entirely and retain whatever power she currently possesses.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful deep hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Native creatures behave in strange and unnatural ways. Fish and crabs may move in ways that crudely mimic the behavior of land dwelling creatures such as birds or mice, while others may move erratically or behave in self destructive ways.

entries: If the hag dies, this effect fade after {@dice 1d6} days.

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The dusk hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The dusk hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Nightmare Vision
entries: The dusk hag is plagued every night by prophetic nightmare images. These images can predict the future in strange and unpredictable ways. These dreams serve as plot devices and the dusk hag has no control over what they show.

When the dusk hag touches a humanoid or hits it with a claw attack, she can attempt to pass on her visions to the target for a time. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Charisma saving throw or become the host for the dusk hag’s Nightmare Visions for {@dice 1d4} days. Once the dusk hag has successfully passed on her visions to a creature, she cannot do so again until the visions return to her. While a creature is a host for the visions, the creature experiences the prophetic dreams instead of the dusk hag. A creature experiencing these visions does not receive any benefit from a long rest. These visions can be removed by a {@spell remove curse} or {@spell dispel evil and good} spell or similar magic, at which point the visions will return to the hag.
The dusk hag cannot cast the spells in her Innate Spellcasting feature except for {@spell detect magic} when she does not possess her visions.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

Dusk hags are a strange aberration in hag biology. Occasionally, a night hag will give birth to a dusk hag instead of another night hag, an occurrence that is far more common in Eberron. These dusk hags are immediately identifiable by their yellowish, parchment like skin and their frail, sunken features. Devoid of the innate nastiness and cruelty of their sister kin, dusk hags are not interested in the goals of torment that other hags possess. They would all be immediately slain upon birth were it not for their incredibly useful prophetic dreams.

Dusk hags strive to find the hidden knowledge of the world. They will often parlay with others, trading knowledge, but the knowledge gained from a dusk hag often comes with a price. Dusk hags can induce nightmares in creatures they touch; and they themselves suffer dreams about the past, present, and future.

entries.name: Dreamers
entries: Like night hags, dusk hags possess a unique connection to the realm of dreams. They receive prophetic visions in the form of nightmares that they suffer daily. Though these dreams always provide incredibly useful insight into the future, these hags typically lack the far reaching ambition of other hags and as such aren’t inclined to take advantage of their knowledge. In fact, a dusk hag will eagerly pass on the burden of its dreams to another creature so that she may enjoy a peaceful night’s sleep for once, though her dreams always return to her in the end. They are capable of reaching out to shape the dreams of others, though they must be able to touch their victim in order to pass on their dreams.

entries.name: Sources of Wisdom
entries: Though they do not enjoy their prophetic dreams, they still feel compelled to remember the contents of them. A dusk hag’s lair is filled with innumerable scrolls, hides, books, and other recordings of rambling, nearly incoherent dream imagery. These records are all but unintelligible to any creature other than the dusk hag that wrote them. Stories are filled with accounts of princes and knights that sought out the council of a dusk hag, performing some task for them in exchange for a piece of lore or prophecy long hidden in her cluttered lair. But beware, though always accurate, a dusk hag’s prophecy rarely leads to happiness.

entries.name: Unambitious
entries: Though dusk hags are not cruel, neither are they kind. A dusk hag is an entirely self-interested creature, and given the opportunity they would happily keep to themselves. However, the allure of their prophetic dreams is such that their sister kin will always seek to take advantage of them. It is rare to find a dusk hag not under the control of another hag who uses the insight of their dreams to better enact their plans. These matronly figures will coerce the cooperation of a dusk hag in any way they can, forbidding them from passing off their dreams to another and threatening them with torments of they do not comply. As such, dusk hags rarely feel loyalty to their so called allies and will betray them if given an opportunity.

entries.name: A Dusk Hag's Lair
entries: A dusk hag prefers to make her home in an unassuming, out of the way location, hoping to avoid notice from any nearby locals, though she never houses herself too far from a ready source of humanoids to pass her visions on to. Though dusk hags lack the interest in pursuing far reach plans, they have a very keen interest in protecting their homes, and as a result their lairs are often protected with magical traps and dangerous guardians.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A dusk hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions. Those actions happen on Initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties).

items: All creatures within the lair that the dusk hag can see must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be subjected to the effects of the {@spell compulsion} spell until initiative count 20 of the following round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful dusk hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Rolling banks of fog are common in the area. Visions of lost loved ones or hated enemies can be glimpsed in the fog, and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks made to avoid becoming lost have disadvantage. The resident dusk hag has no difficulty navigating this fog.

monster.name: Elder Dusk Hag

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder dusk hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

entries: The elder dusk hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Nightmare Vision
entries: The elder dusk hag is plagued every night by prophetic nightmare images. These images can predict the future in strange and unpredictable ways. These dreams serve as plot devices and the elder dusk hag has no control over what they show.

When the elder dusk hag touches a humanoid or hits it with a claw attack, she can attempt to pass on her visions to the target for a time. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become the host for the elder dusk hag’s Nightmare Visions for {@dice 1d4} days. Once the elder dusk hag has successfully passed on her visions to a creature, she cannot do so again until the visions return to her. While a creature is a host for the visions, the creature experiences the prophetic dreams instead of the hag. A creature experiencing these visions does not receive any benefit from a long rest. These visions can be removed by a {@spell remove curse} or {@spell dispel evil and good} spell or similar magic, at which point the visions will return to the elder dusk hag.
The elder dusk hag cannot cast the spells in her Innate Spellcasting feature except for {@spell detect magic} when she does not possess her visions.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder dusk hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder dusk hag makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

legendaryHeader: The elder dusk hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The elder dusk hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder dusk hag makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder dusk hag casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Inner Vision (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: All creatures within 30 feet of the elder dusk hag must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become plagued by psychedelic images. A creature that the elder dusk hag has passed its Nightmare Visions trait onto automatically fails this saving throw. Until the end of the elder dusk hag's next turn, all affected creatures are {@condition blinded}.

entries.name: Covens
entries: An elder dusk hag that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) has a challenge rating of 8 (3,900 XP).

entries.name: An Elder Dusk Hag's Lair
entries: An elder dusk hag prefers to make her home in an unassuming, out of the way location, hoping to avoid notice from any nearby locals, though she never houses herself too far from a ready source of humanoids to pass her visions on to. Though dusk hags lack the interest in pursuing far reach plans, they have a very keen interest in protecting their homes, and as a result their lairs are often protected with magical traps and dangerous guardians.
