There are three known varieties of canomorph: the shadurakul, born of shadow mastiffs; the haraknin, born of hell hounds, and the yeshbavhan, born of yeth hounds. Other varieties may exist within the festering pits of the inner planes, the darkest reaches of the Shadowfell, and Feywild, but if they do none have yet lived to tell about them.

A haraknin is a hell hound which has been granted the ability to transform into a humanoid shape, along with the intelligence to speak. A hell hound may be gifted the status a haraknin by its master if it particularly impresses them, though a haraknin may also be created so that better control can be exerted over a pack of hell hounds. In their humanoid form, a haraknin resembles an orc or half-orc with charcoal grey skin, red eyes, and vibrant russet hair. They are violent and ill-tempered, but loyal and obedient to a fault.

entries.name: Dangerous Scouts
entries: A haraknin's skills are best utilized as a scout, since they have incredible mobility in their hound form and excellent aim with both bow and spear in their humanoid forms. They are supplied by their masters with longbows and arrows that bear an insidious poison that slows its targets, making them easy to catch, and their weapon skills enable them to knock their opponents from their feet. They also make excellent prison wardens and hunters.

entries.name: Pack Creatures
entries: A haraknin is most comfortable with subordinates to lead and a master to follow. A haraknin will invariably take control of a pack of other haraknin and hell hounds, possibly supplemented with wolves, worgs, and death dogs, leading them through aggressive dominance and ferocious loyalty. The haraknin will lead this pack in service of whatever master it serves, showing unflinching devotion and unquestioning obedience. As such, haraknin are highly prized as servants in the Nine Hells due to their unwillingness to betray their masters.

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons while in dim light or darkness

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The shadurakul has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Ethereal Awareness
entries: The shadurakul can see ethereal creatures and objects.

trait.name: Shadow Blend
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the shadurakul can use a bonus action to become {@condition invisible}, along with anything it is wearing or carrying. The invisibility lasts until the shadurakul uses a bonus action to end it or until the shadurakul attacks, is in bright light, or is {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Shapechange
entries: The shadurakul can use a bonus action to magically polymorph into its shadow mastiff form or back into its humanoid form. It retains its Intelligence, Charisma, hit points, and this feature, but otherwise uses the statistics of a shadow mastiff. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. It reverts to its shadow mastiff form if it dies.

trait.name: Sunlight Weakness
entries: While in sunlight, the shadurakul has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shadurakul can use its Terrifying Howl. It then makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage, plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Terrifying Howl
entries: The shadurakul howls. Any beast or humanoid within 300 feet of the mastiff and able to hear its howl must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A {@condition frightened} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to any shadurakul's Terrifying Howl for the next 24 hours.

A canomorph is an fiendish hound that has gained the ability to transform into a humanoid form. Typically, it gains this ability from a powerful supernatural being such as an archdevil, an agent of the Raven Queen, or an ancient hag, though some develop this ability on their own.

There are three known varieties of canomorph: the shadurakul, born of shadow mastiffs; the haraknin, born of hell hounds, and the yeshbavhan, born of yeth hounds. Other varieties may exist within the festering pits of the inner planes, the darkest reaches of the Shadowfell, and Feywild, but if they do none have yet lived to tell about them.

The shadurakul are shadow mastiff alphas which have impressed beings of shadow such as the Raven Queen or Shar enough for them to grant the hound even greater intelligence and the ability to take humanoid form. In their humanoid forms, they resemble tall, barrel chested humans with inky blue-black skin, no hair, and cold white eyes. They are contemptuous of the weak and unfaltering in their loyalty to their assigned master.

entries.name: Warriors of Shadow
entries: A shadurakul possesses both physical strength and stealthy cunning in equal measure, and it uses both of these skills to greatest effect possible in service of its master. They command their packs with an iron fist, leading them through the shadows in pursuit of quarries or lurking in the darkness of the realms they've been assigned guardianship of.

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The yeshbavhan has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the yeshbavhan can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Shapechange
entries: The yeshbavhan can use a bonus action to magically polymorph into its yeth hound form or back into its humanoid form. It retains its Intelligence, Charisma, hit points, and this feature, but otherwise uses the statistics of a yeth hound. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. It reverts to its yeth hound form if it dies.

trait.name: Sunlight Banishment
entries: If the yeshbavhan starts its turn in sunlight, it is transported to the Ethereal Plane. While sunlight shines on the spot from which it vanished, the hound must remain in the Deep Ethereal. After sunset, it returns to the Border Ethereal at the same spot, whereupon it typically sets out to find its pack or its master. The hound is visible on the Material Plane while it is in the Border Ethereal, and vice versa, but it can't affect or be affected by anything on the other plane. Once it is adjacent to its master or a pack mate that is on the Material Plane, a yeshbavhan in the Border Ethereal can return to the Material Plane as an action.

trait.name: Telepathic Bond
entries: While the yeshbavhan is on the same plane of existence as its master, it can magically convey what it senses to its master, and the two can communicate telepathically with each other.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The yeshbavhan can use its Baleful Baying. It then makes two greataxe attacks

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) psychic damage if the target is {@condition frightened}.

action.name: Baleful Baying
entries: The yeshbavhan bays magically. Every enemy within 300 feet of the hound that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of the hound's next turn or until the hound is {@condition incapacitated}. A {@condition frightened} target that starts its turn within 30 feet of the hound must use all its movement on that turn to get as far from the hound as possible, must finish the move before taking an action, and must take the most direct route, even if hazards lie that way. A target that successfully saves is immune to the baying of all yeshbavhans and yeth hounds for the next 24 hours.

A canomorph is an fiendish hound that has gained the ability to transform into a humanoid form. Typically, it gains this ability from a powerful supernatural being such as an archdevil, an agent of the Raven Queen, or an ancient hag, though some develop this ability on their own.

There are three known varieties of canomorph: the shadurakul, born of shadow mastiffs; the haraknin, born of hell hounds, and the yeshbavhan, born of yeth hounds. Other varieties may exist within the festering pits of the inner planes, the darkest reaches of the Shadowfell, and Feywild, but if they do none have yet lived to tell about them.

A yeshbavhan is a yeth hound granted the ability to take humanoid form by a powerful fey lord or ancient hag. Even more savage than a typical yeth hound, the greated intelligence that the yeshbavhan has been granted has only served to make it more sadistic and wild. These ferocious beasts appear as frighteningly tall dwarves with night black skin, unkempt beards, and glowing red eyes, and they wield massive greataxes which they swing with frothing, furious glee.

entries.name: Eager Servant
entries: A yeshbavhan eagerly serves its master, joyfully hunting down prey and brutalizing them. They love to watch their prey flee in terror and cannot resist pursuing a creature that runs from them. A yeshbavhan leads its pack on glorious midnight hunts, felling great beasts and men alike, howling their terrible joy to the moon.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The catobleopas harbinger has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The catobleopas harbinger deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the catobleopas harbinger must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take 20 ({@damage 8d4}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the start of the creature's next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature only takes half the damage and is not {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the creature has disadvantage on death saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: If the catoblepas's death ray is available, it makes one attack with its death ray and one with its tail. It can't make both attacks against the same target. Otherwise, it makes one tail attack and one stomp attack.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 7d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the start of the catoblepas's next turn.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. If the catoblepas scores a critical hit against a {@condition prone} target, it rolls the damage dice three times, instead of twice.

action.name: Death Ray {@recharge 5}
entries: The catoblepas targets a creature that it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target instead takes 64 necrotic damage. The target dies if reduced to 0 hit points by this ray.

bonus.name: Inevitable Call
entries: The catoblepas begins humming a deep, sonorous sound. Any humanoid or giant that begins its turn within 120 feet of the catoblepas must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the humming ends. The catoblepas must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue humming. It can stop humming at any time. The humming ends if the catoblepas is {@condition incapacitated}.

While {@condition charmed} by the catoblepas, a target is {@condition incapacitated}. If the {@condition charmed} target is more than 5 ft. away from the catoblepas, the target must move on its turn toward the catoblepas by the most direct route. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the catoblepas, a target can repeat the saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it.
A target that successfully saves is immune to this catoblepas's humming for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Trample
entries: The catoblepas harbinger makes one stomp attack.

legendary.name: Groan (1/Round)
entries: The catoblepas harbinger creates a deep, rumbling groan. All creatures that aren't catoblepas within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. Creatures currently {@condition charmed} by the catoblepas automatically fail this save and cannot attempt to stand until they are no longer {@condition charmed}.

The catoblepas are creatures of death, destruction, and ruin. The catoblepas harbinger is one that has grown huge and fat from the ruin of mortals. These massive, stinking beasts spend most of their time buried in the fetid mud of the swamps that they favor, hibernating until roused from their sleep by an unknown summon. Once awake, a catoblepas harbinger pulls itself free from the mud and begins a long, plodding journey to its destination.

entries.name: The Fall of Man
entries: A catoblepas harbinger is an implacable force. Long before it arrives, it is presaged by the unearthly stench it emits, which is foul enough to wilt flowers as it passes. Its gaze strikes down any creature it sees. Its voice is the voice of despair, sapping the will of mortals with its dolorous humming and casting them to the ground with its unearthly groans. Its tail turns houses into rubble and its feet crushes beasts and men alike. When a catoblepas harbinger walks, a kingdom falls.

monster.name: Dark Naga
languages: Common and the language of its patron (usually Abyssal, Infernal, or Sylvan)

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The naga's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The naga is a 10th level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks), and it needs only verbal components to cast its spells. It regains its expended spell slots when it finishes a short or long rest. The naga has the following warlock spells prepared:

spells: {@spell eldritch blast} ({@i at 5th level, 1d10 + 4 per blast})

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If it dies, the dark naga returns to life in {@dice 1d6} days and regains all its hit points. Only a {@spell wish} spell or the will of its fey patron can prevent this trait from functioning.

trait.name: Storage Sac
entries: As an action, the naga can swallow an object with dimensions that do not exceed 2 feet in any direction. This object is then stored in the naga's storage sac and can be regurgitated as a bonus action. While within the storage sac, the object cannot be magically detected.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The naga makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its tail sting. It can cast a spell in place of making a bite attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Tail Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 31 ({@damage 7d8}) poison damage.

The naga race once served powerful arcane masters. When those masters were lost to the ravages of time, the naga were left adrift without guidance. Though many embraced their new freedom, some yearned for the structure and guidance that they had once enjoyed in their servitude and sought out new masters. These naga found beings of shadow and magic such as the Queen of Air and Darkness, Graz'zt, Acererak, the Raven Queen, and Malagard to whom they pledged their loyalty.

entries.name: Transformed Might
entries: When a naga devotes itself to a new master, they are transformed in flesh and soul. Though they retain their immortal spirit, their bodies are irrecovably tranformed, robbing their fangs of venom but gifting them a stinger dripping with acid. Their former spellcasting is lost and replaced by power implanted in them by their new patrons, whom they must henceforth serve with the same loyalty that they once served their original masters. These new dark naga act as powerful spellcasters and cunning generals for their patrons, enacting their will in the world.

entries.name: Seekers of Power and Lore
entries: Like other naga, dark naga have an insatiable craving for arcane lore. Whenever they find a magical item or a promising piece of magical knowledge, they swallow the item, storing it in a special baglike internal organ to be regurgitated later for better examination. This organ has rubbery protective walls to protect the naga from sharp points, and the walls also have the unusual property of shielding the contents of the stomach from any sort of magical detection.

entries.name: Variant: Spit Poison
entries: Dark naga cannot possess no natural venom. However, they can swallow a contact or injury poison and regurgitate it at a creature in a manner similar to a {@creature guardian naga}. For more on poisons, see {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} pg 257-259. Such a dark naga has the additonal following action:

{@b Spit Poison (Recharges after swallowing one dose of poison)}. {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 10/25 ft., one target. {@h}The target is exposed to a single dose of poison, the type of which is determined by whatever dose of poison the naga had last swallowed.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The dreamweaver can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Web of Dreams
entries: By spending one hour of continuous work, the dreamweaver can construct a web that is no larger than 5 feet by 5 feet. The web is slightly incorporeal, allowing creatures and objects to pass through it without inhibition, and lasts for {@dice 1d4} days. While within 5 feet of the web, a creature had advantage on saving throws against illusion and enchantment spells.

As part of weaving the web, the dreamweaver can replicate the image version of the {@spell minor illusion} spell. This illusion lasts as long as the web persists. The dreamweaver can only have one web made at a time.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the dreamweaver knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The dreamweaver ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition unconscious}. The target wakes up if it takes damage.

Dreamweavers are a species of spider native to the realm of dreams, where they weave vast dreamscapes with their webs. However, by means unknown, a few were brought into the Feywild, where they found an ecological niche. Now they weave illusions in the deep forests, feeding on drifting fancies. Their coloration can vary anywhere from the pale blue of an early morning sky to the black of the darkest night.

entries.name: Dream Eaters
entries: Dreamweavers feed on the stray thoughts and fantasies of sentient beings, catching them in their webs and wrapping them up in silk. Within the dream worlds of the Feywild, food is plentiful, but in the Material Plane these creatures find that food is much harder to come by. Some dreamweavers simply build their webs in the rooms of humanoids, but others will band together into colonies and construct large illusions to lure in prey, which they then put into a deep sleep with their venom, feeding on their dreams until the creature starves to death.

entries.name: Dreamcatchers
entries: These spiders can be trained to catch certain types of dreams, and as such some shamans have learned how to train them to capture nightmares to provide relief to patients ailing from them. However, these same captured dreams can also be used for sinister purposes, making them attractive pets for evil creatures like hags.

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The swarm can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm of dreamweavers can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny insect. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Web of Dreams
entries: By spending one hour of continuous work, the swarm can construct a series of webs that occupy a 30-foot cube. The webs are slightly incorporeal, allowing creatures and objects to pass through it without inhibition, and lasts for 1 week.
Any creature within the webs is immune to the dream spell and cannot be targetted by any divination magic or perceived through scrying.

As part of weaving the web, the dreamweaver can replicate the image version of the minor illusion spell. This illusion lasts as long as the webs persists. The swarm can only create one group of webs at a time.

trait.name: Web Sense
entries: While in contact with a web, the swarm of dreamweavers knows the exact location of any other creature in contact with the same web.

trait.name: Web Walker
entries: The swarm of dreamweavers ignores movement restrictions caused by webbing.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 4d4 + 1}) piercing damage, or 6 ({@damage 2d4 + 1}) piercing damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. Additionally, the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition unconscious}. The target wakes up if it takes damage.

Dreamweavers are a species of spider native to the realm of dreams, where they weave vast dreamscapes with their webs. However, by means unknown, a few were brought into the Feywild, where they found an ecological niche. Now they weave illusions in the deep forests, feeding on drifting fancies. Their coloration can vary anywhere from the pale blue of an early morning sky to the black of the darkest night.

entries.name: Dream Eaters
entries: Dreamweavers feed on the stray thoughts and fantasies of sentient beings, catching them in their webs and wrapping them up in silk. Within the dream worlds of the Feywild, food is plentiful, but in the Material Plane these creatures find that food is much harder to come by. Some dreamweavers simply build their webs in the rooms of humanoids, but others will band together into colonies and construct large illusions to lure in prey, which they then put into a deep sleep with their venom, feeding on their dreams until the creature starves to death.

entries.name: Dreamcatchers
entries: These spiders can be trained to catch certain types of dreams, and as such some shamans have learned how to train them to capture nightmares to provide relief to patients ailing from them. However, these same captured dreams can also be used for sinister purposes, making them attractive pets for evil creatures like hags.

monster.name: Black Willow
senses: tremorsense 120 ft. (from the edge of its roots)

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the black willow remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal willow tree.

trait.name: Limited Mobility
entries: When the tree wishes to move, it must first wrench its roots from the ground and hoist itself up as an action. While it is mobile, the area of the tree's roots is difficult terrain. If the tree wishes to plant itself again, it must use an action to do so.

trait.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: The tree's trunk has a diameter of 10 feet and a height of 20 feet. The canopy extends 15 feet from the trunk, and the roots extend 15 feet from the trunk.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tree makes four attacks with its vine whip.

action.name: Vine Whip
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d4 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Drowsiness
entries: Every humanoid and beast within 60 feet of the tree's trunk must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become overcome with drowsiness, having disadvantage on all attack rolls and skill checks. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. After three successful saves, the effect ends. After three failed saves, the creature becomes {@condition incapacitated} and is incapable of moving from beneath the willow's branches for 1 hour. If a creature has one or more levels of {@condition exhaustion}, they automatically fail on these saving throws. This effect ends if the creature takes any damage. If this effect ends for a creature, it is immune to the tree's Drowsiness action for 24 hours.

An evil tree is imbued with darkness and hatred. Some are born from great tragedies, some are born from arcane meddling, some are born from magical coincidence, and some are just born evil. Regardless of their origins, evil trees are dangerous and cruel.

It is said that the first black willow was born from a seed that was watered by the bitter tears of the Queen of Air and Darkness after she lost her physical form. Now they proliferate through the Feywild and places touched by it, growing from ground watered with tears of terrible sorrow and despair. These trees look like a typical weeping willow, except that their trunks are a deep black and tears gather on their leaves like dew.

entries.name: Feeders of Sorrow
entries: Black willows possess psionic powers shaped by the sorrow that birthed them, and they gain much of their sustenance from the despair they cause. The tears that gather on their leaves attract a wide variety of animals, which they entrap with their powers of drowsiness then slowly feed on their despair for days as the creatures languish. Once the creatures perish, they bury them among their roots to fertilize their soil.

entries.name: Hunger for Sorrow
entries: A black willow gains the most sustenance from the sorrow of humanoids, and they take pains to position themselves near humanoid settlements in the hopes of finding new victims. They move in the dead of night so as not to attract undue attention, and they prefer to position themselves in secluded areas to prevent interference. The wood of these trees is always saturated with tears, and as such they are more resistant to flames than other trees, but they are still vulnerable to axes.

entries.name: Cruel Trees
entries: Though they lack eyes, a black willow can detect any movement near it by means of vibrations in the ground. What's more, their psionic powers enable them to detect any creatures near them and communicate with them, poisoning their minds with sorrow.

entries.name: Bleeding Willow
entries: A bleeding willow is a variant of the black willow that grows from ground watered by blood spilled from great suffering. The bleeding willow appears much the same as a black willow, except that its leaves produce blood instead of tears. These trees gain sustenance from suffering, and when an act of violence is committed under its branches it can unleash all of the suffering and evil that it has witnessed as a devastating mental attack. A bleeding willow has the following reaction instead of the Drowsiness action:

{@b Blasting of Suffering (1/Day).} When an act of violence is committed under the tree's canopy, the tree automatically emits a psionic burst that effects every creature that is not a construct or plant within 30 feet of the tree's trunk. All affected creatures must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be overcome with blind rage and be incapable of moving from beneath the tree's canopy for 1 minute. While enraged, a creature cannot cast spells or perform complicated tasks and must use its action and movement to attempt to make as many melee attacks as it can against the nearest creature that it can see that is not the bleeding willow. A creature can repeat the saving throw whenever it takes damage, ending the effect on a success.

entries.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: Combat with some evil trees is resolved somewhat differently from combat with another creature. The tree has three effective components: its trunk, its canopy, and its roots. A tree's trunk has both a diameter and a height. The canopy extends out in a radius from the top of the tree's trunk. The roots extend out in a radius from the bottom of the tree's trunk. All of the tree's components have the same AC and damage resistances and immunities, unless otherwise noted, but only damage done to the trunk counts as damage done to the creature itself.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the dark cypress remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal cypress tree.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tree makes two claw attacks. If it ends its turn grappling a creature, it can also make a bite attack against the {@condition grappled} target.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage. If the tree successfully hits a creature with two claw attacks in the same turn, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) piercing damage.

bonus.name: Confusion
entries: The tree targets one creature that it can see within 50 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be affected as if by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute.

entries.name: Evil Trees
entries: An evil tree is imbued with darkness and hatred. Some are born from great tragedies, some are born from arcane meddling, some are born from magical coincidence, and some are just born evil. Regardless of their origins, evil trees are dangerous and cruel.

Dark cypress superficially resemble treants, but anyone who sees a dark tree can almost feel the palpable hatred and evil emanating from it. Created from corrupted cypress trees, dark cypress are hateful monsters that love to create pain and suffering. They possess wet, slimy bark which protects them from fire, but their wood is very sensitive to cold, leading them to favor climates with mild winters.

entries.name: Unnatural Origins
entries: Dark cypress were first created by dark magical experimentation from before the Spellplague. A wizard wished for evil servants with the strength of treants. Through dark necromantic experimentation, he succeeded. However, it was only a matter of time before these foul creatures turned on their master. Now they proliferate through dark forests, spreading sorrow wherever they go.

As beings created by arcane magic, dark cypress have little to no connection to nature, and they care nothing for the natural world. Animals instinctively recognize the blasphemous presence of a dark tree and refuse to associate with it, but fiends, undead, and hags find a kindred spirit in these monsters.

entries.name: Cruel to a Fault
entries: A dark cypress enjoys nothing more than causing suffering. They disguise themselves as mundane trees, then wait for a victim to happen upon them, at which point they snatch them up and torture them in whatever way they can. They particularly love to cripple victims and watch them slowly die, but they are always open to new forms of sadism. Unlike other evil trees, dark cypress gain no sustenance from the creatures they slay or the suffering they cause. They kill and torture solely for the pleasure of it.

entries.name: Spreaders of Tragedy
entries: Dark cypress possess a supernatural instinct for how to cause the most tragedy with their actions. A dark cypress innately understands exactly who among a group will mourn the death of their companions the most bitterly and will spare them. They also have a supernatural knack for rooting themselves in exactly the right spot for an unsuspecting child or messenger carrying an important letter to wander across. As a result, hags have a particular affinity for these corrupted trees, especially green hags, night hags, powler hags, and any other hags that have a fondness for tragedy.

entries.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: Combat with some evil trees is resolved somewhat differently from combat with another creature. The tree has three effective components: its trunk, its canopy, and its roots. A tree's trunk has both a diameter and a height. The canopy extends out in a radius from the top of the tree's trunk. The roots extend out in a radius from the bottom of the tree's trunk. All of the tree's components have the same AC and damage resistances and immunities, unless otherwise noted, but only damage done to the trunk counts as damage done to the creature itself.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

monster.name: Night Twist
senses: tremorsense 120 ft. (from the edge of its roots)

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The night twist's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Despair Song
entries: At sundown, the tree begins singing a magical melody, which it continues singing until midnight. Every humanoid within 5 miles of the tree that can hear the song that is not in sunlight must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be affected in one of two ways depending on whether the creature is awake or asleep when it hears the song. The tree must maintain concentration on the song as if with a spell to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the tree is {@condition incapacitated}.

items: If the target is asleep when it fails the saving throw or falls asleep before being exposed to sunlight, its dreams are filled with sorrow and the creature gains no benefit from the rest it is taking.

If the creature is awake when it fails the saving throw, it becomes {@condition charmed} by the night twist. While {@condition charmed} in this way a target is overcome with despair, imposing disadvantage on all attack rolls, skill checks, and saving throws. If the {@condition charmed} target fails its saving throw by more than 5 and is not under the tree's canopy, the target must move on its turn toward the tree by the most direct route. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the tree, a target can repeat the saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw if another creature uses an action to attempt to shake them from the despair. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it. A target that successfully saves is immune to this tree's Despair Song for the next 24 hours..

trait.name: Death Curse
entries: If the night twist is killed, all humanoids that dealt damage to it within the last 24 hours must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become cursed by the night twist. While cursed, the creature is plagued by nightmares of self harm and despair. If the creature dies as a result of self harm while cursed in this way, a new night twist grows from its corpse. A {@spell dispel evil and good} or {@spell remove curse} spell removes this curse.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the night twist remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a dead tree.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The night twist has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: The tree's trunk has a diameter of 10 feet and a height of 20 feet. The canopy extends 15 feet from the trunk, and the roots extend 20 feet from the trunk.

trait.name: Plane Step (1/Day)
entries: By spending one minute concentrating, the tree can cast {@spell plane shift}, affecting itself and any structures and creatures in its branches or on its roots that it wishes. This casting of plane shift can only transfer the tree either from its current plane to Hades or from Hades to a forest in the Prime Material Plane, the Feywild, or the Shadowfell. It cannot plane shift if it is currently day time in its current or destination plane.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tree uses visions of misery three times. It can replace one of its visions of misery attacks by casting {@spell darkness}, {@spell entangle}, or {@spell gust of wind}.

action.name: Visions of Misery
entries: One creature beneath the tree's canopy must make a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 4d10}) psychic damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. Additionally, on a failure, the target becomes {@condition frightened} of another character under the tree's canopy for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened} in this way, the creature cannot voluntarily move out from under the tree's canopy. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to becoming {@condition frightened} by the tree's Visions of Misery for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Evil Trees
entries: An evil tree is imbued with darkness and hatred. Some are born from great tragedies, some are born from arcane meddling, some are born from magical coincidence, and some are just born evil. Regardless of their origins, evil trees are dangerous and cruel.

The night twist is an evil tree native to the Gray Wastes of Hades. Born from the soul of a suicide victim, it carries that despair deep within its wood and yearns to lead others to their death as well. It sings out its sorrow at dusk, calling to the souls of all that can hear it, pulling their hearts toward the empty void within it.

entries.name: Deception and Sorrow
entries: At first glance, a night twist appears to be nothing more than a dead tree. However, creatures approaching it can feel the malice and despair saturating the very air. Instead of sap, its wood is filled with blood, and any attempt to attack it will cause it to lash out with its frightful illusions and gusts of wind.

entries.name: Hungering Trees
entries: A dark cypress enjoys nothing more than causing suffering. They disguise themselves as mundane trees, then wait for a victim to happen upon them, at which point they snatch them up and torture them in whatever way they can. They particularly love to cripple victims and watch them slowly die, but they are always open to new forms of sadism. Unlike other evil trees, dark cypress gain no sustenance from the creatures they slay or the suffering they cause. They kill and torture solely for the pleasure of it.

entries.name: Hag Favored
entries: Due to its ability to travel between the planes, the night twist is coveted by hags as an invaluable ally. A hag that encounters a night twist will endeavor to make herself an ally to the tree. Many people surmise that night twists were created by night hags, but others believe that it was a night twist that first lead the original hags into Hades to become night hags.

entries.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: Combat with some evil trees is resolved somewhat differently from combat with another creature. The tree has three effective components: its trunk, its canopy, and its roots. A tree's trunk has both a diameter and a height. The canopy extends out in a radius from the top of the tree's trunk. The roots extend out in a radius from the bottom of the tree's trunk. All of the tree's components have the same AC and damage resistances and immunities, unless otherwise noted, but only damage done to the trunk counts as damage done to the creature itself.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

monster.name: Umbral Banyan
senses: darkvision 120 ft. tremorsense 120 ft. (from the edge of its roots)

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the umbral banyan remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal banyan tree.

trait.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: The tree's trunk has a diameter of 25 feet and a height of 20 feet. The canopy extends 30 feet from the trunk, and the roots extend 50 feet from the trunk.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tree makes four tendril attacks, one of which can be replaced by the Yank Upward action.

action.name: Tendril
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature under the tree's canopy. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) necrotic damage, and the target’s Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.
If a non-evil humanoid dies from this attack, a new {@creature shadow} rises from the corpse {@dice 1d4} hours later.

action.name: Yank Upward
entries: The tree makes one tendril attack against a creature underneath its canopy. On a successful hit, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 18}) and pulled 20 feet directly upward into the tree's canopy. While being {@condition grappled} in this way, the creature cannot breathe and is automatically subjected a tendril attack at the beginning of each of the tree's turns.

entries.name: Evil Trees
entries: An evil tree is imbued with darkness and hatred. Some are born from great tragedies, some are born from arcane meddling, some are born from magical coincidence, and some are just born evil. Regardless of their origins, evil trees are dangerous and cruel.

Umbral banyans are descended from platlife native to the Shadowfell, adapted to the Material Plane to make use of its abundant resources. These trees are the dark kings at the hearts of dangerous forests, and an umbral banyan's presence will always lead the woods to be haunted by phantoms.

entries.name: Drinking the Dark
entries: They have a unique form of photosynthesis that is still not fully understood. Rather than absorbing sunlight, they gain sustenance from casting shadows. The stronger the light that an umbral banyan obscures, the more sustenance the umbral banyan gains. As such, an umbral banyan cannot flourish on the Shadowfell, as there is no light to cast a shadow with.

entries.name: Shadow Trees
entries: Umbral banyans happily slay humanoids, draining the strength from their bodies and strangling them to death with their aerial roots. Their corpses are then left to dangle in the air as grim trophies, while their shadows rise up to serve the tree.

An umbral banyan possesses an innate connection to the Shadowfell, and as it matures its roots form shadow crossings, which allow the essence of the Shadowfell to leak out, poisoning the natural world with despair. These trees have been known to enwrap other trees and strangle them, leaving the trees as hollow columns. These columns act as especially large shadow crossings, and have even been known to disgorge nightwalkers on rare occasions.

entries.name: Hag Friends
entries: Hags love to create their lairs within the canopy of an umbral banyan due to the easy access the tree provides to the Shadowfell in conjuction with the added defense that it provides. Such a hag forms a mutually beneficial partnership with the banyan, protecting it from any threats that it cannot handle itself. It is believed that an umbral banyan can be created if a mundane banyan tree is used as a hanging tree for many years, and many hags find that possibility extremely enticing.

entries.name: Forest Kings
entries: The roots and branches can extend for miles, manifesting as lesser umbral banyans all connected together into a single huge organism. Each of these banyans acts as an individual but is telepathically connected to every other banyan through roots and branches.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The forest containing an ancient, well established umbral banyan is tainted by the influence of the Shadowfell itself, creating one or more of the following effects.

items: The radius of light produced by non-magical sources is halved while within the forest.
Creatures native to the Shadowfell such as meazels, skulks, sorrowsworn, and shadar kai are found in the forest and are considered native so long as they remain in the forest.
Undead creatures such as shadows, specters, and wraiths are found in great profusion wandering the forest.
For every week a creature spends in the forest, it must make a saving throw against {@table Shadowfell Despair}.

entries: When the umbral banyan dies, these effects fade after {@dice 2d4} years as the Shadowfell's influence slowly trickles away.

entries.name: Tree Dimensions
entries: Combat with some evil trees is resolved somewhat differently from combat with another creature. The tree has three effective components: its trunk, its canopy, and its roots. A tree's trunk has both a diameter and a height. The canopy extends out in a radius from the top of the tree's trunk. The roots extend out in a radius from the bottom of the tree's trunk. All of the tree's components have the same AC and damage resistances and immunities, unless otherwise noted, but only damage done to the trunk counts as damage done to the creature itself.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Brute
entries: A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the hagspawn brute hits with it.

trait.name: Hag Ancestry
entries: The hagspawn brute has advantage on saving throws to resist spells and effects that target humanoids, like {@spell charm person}, a {@creature harpy}'s {@i Luring Song}, or a {@creature ghost}'s {@i Possession}.

trait.name: Ugly
entries: The hagspawn brute has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks and disadvantage of Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks against humanoids that can see you.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hagspawn brute makes two attacks with its maul.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Hagspawn
entries: Hagspawn are the male offspring of hags, or their descendents. A hag gives birth to a hagspawn when she consumes a male infant instead of a female infant. Unlike their sisters, though, a hagspawn does not transform into a hag at puberty. Rather, they become an ugly, hulking humanoid. These hagspawn possess none of the magical abilities of their sisters, but are strong and stubborn, making them useful for little more than thugs and brutes. Hags usually don't bother going through the trouble of birthing a male offspring unless they have a need for a loyal minion.
These are the offspring of hags trained as muscle. They lead the weaker minions of their mother against her enemies.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hagspawn mage is a 5th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). The hagspawn mage has the following sorcerer spells prepared:

trait.name: Hag Ancestry
entries: The hagspawn mage has advantage on saving throws to resist spells and effects that target humanoids, like {@spell charm person}, a {@creature harpy}'s {@i Luring Song}, or a {@creature ghost}'s {@i Possession}.

trait.name: Ugly
entries: The hagspawn mage has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks and disadvantage of Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks against humanoids that can see you.

trait.name: Wild Magic
entries: When the hagspawn expends a spellslot, it must roll from the Wild Magic table.

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

entries.name: Hagspawn
entries: Hagspawn are the male offspring of hags, or their descendents. A hag gives birth to a hagspawn when she consumes a male infant instead of a female infant. Unlike their sisters, though, a hagspawn does not transform into a hag at puberty. Rather, they become an ugly, hulking humanoid. These hagspawn possess none of the magical abilities of their sisters, but are strong and stubborn, making them useful for little more than thugs and brutes. Hags usually don't bother going through the trouble of birthing a male offspring unless they have a need for a loyal minion.

As descendents of hags, hagspawn have an innate aptitude towards magic, and it is not uncommon for them to tap into the well of arcane power in their blood. Sometimes their hag mothers may teach them how to harness this power, but more often than not the hagspawn must develop this power on their own, as if their mother wanted a magically inclined daughter they would have given birth to a hag.

trait.name: Hag Ancestry
entries: The hagspawn thug has advantage on saving throws to resist spells and effects that target humanoids, like {@spell charm person}, a {@creature harpy}'s {@i Luring Song}, or a {@creature ghost}'s {@i Possession}.

trait.name: Ugly
entries: The hagspawn thug has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks and disadvantage of Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks against humanoids that can see you.

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: During its first turn, the hagspawn has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the hagspawn scores against a surprised creature is a critical hit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hagspawn thug makes two attacks with its greatclub.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Hagspawn
entries: Hagspawn are the male offspring of hags, or their descendents. A hag gives birth to a hagspawn when she consumes a male infant instead of a female infant. Unlike their sisters, though, a hagspawn does not transform into a hag at puberty. Rather, they become an ugly, hulking humanoid. These hagspawn possess none of the magical abilities of their sisters, but are strong and stubborn, making them useful for little more than thugs and brutes. Hags usually don't bother going through the trouble of birthing a male offspring unless they have a need for a loyal minion.
These children of hags are trained by their mothers as thieves and infiltrators, stealing items and kidnapping children for the hag's sinister purposes.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The leech toad can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Standing Leap (Frog)
entries: The leech toad's long jump is up to 10 feet and its high jump is up to 5 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Blood Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage, and the toad attaches to the target. While attached, the toad doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the toad's turns, the target loses 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) hit points due to blood loss. The toad can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 10 hit points of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the toad.

action.name: Paralyzing Gaze
entries: One creature of the toad's choice that is within 30 feet of it and can see it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute or until the toad breaks its paralyzing gaze. The toad must use an action on each of its turns to maintain the paralyzing gaze. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Paralyzing Gaze of all leech toads for the next 24 hours.

Leech toads, also known as stirgetoads and bloodeyes, are dangerous toads with bright red eyes, dark bodies, and small horns decorating their heads. They hunt in packs, using the paralyzing power of their gaze attacks to render their victims helpless while they drain their blood.

entries.name: Spell Components
entries: Leech toads are highly sought after by hags, wizards, and other spellcasters for the valuabe role that their body parts can play in magic. Their blood, their hearts, their livers, and the fluid from their eyes all have value as spell components and the crafting of magic items.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The amber ale can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Thought Hunter
entries: The ooze automatically knows the exact position of every creature with an Intelligence of 3 or higher within 30 feet of it, unless those creatures are under the effects of a spell or item that prevents mind reading, such as {@spell mind blank} or a {@item ring of mind shielding}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The amber ale has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) psychic damage. Additionally, the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage at the start of each of its turns and is constantly assaulted with the surface level thoughts of all intelligent creatures near it. If there is only one creature with an Intelligence of 3 or higher within 30 feet of the target, it automatically reads the surface level thoughts of that creature.

However, if there are two or more creatures with an Intelligence of 3 or higher that speaks at least one language within 30 feet of the {@condition poisoned} creature, the target is {@condition deafened} by the cacophony of thoughts and has disadvantage on all Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws. This effect does not apply to creatures with an Intelligence of 2 or lower.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

entries.name: Amber Ale
entries: These rich, honey colored oozes are infused with the powers of a potion of mind reading. Those poisoned by it forced to read the minds of all those around them. Though this can prove useful when only one other creature is nearby, this quickly becomes overwhelming when other creatures approach, as the conflicting thoughts of numerous individuals is a deafening mental cacophony. These oozes possess the ability to detect the thoughts of other creatures as well, but lacking the intelligence to understand these thoughts they are not incapacitated by the chaos of thoughts.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The golden champagne can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golden champagne has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) acid damage. Additionally, the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target begins to levitate above the ground and rises an additional 20 feet higher at the beginning of each of its turns. The {@condition poisoned} creature can move only by pushing or pulling against a fixed object or surface within reach (such as a wall or a ceiling), which allows it to move as if it were climbing. Once the target ceases being {@condition poisoned}, it falls to the ground as normal, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet fallen.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

These pale golden oozes are filled with a corruscating array of bubbles, causing them to make a pleasant fizzing sound as the float serenely through the air. They are infused with the power of a potion of flying. A creature poisoned by this ooze is filled with a strange, bubbly feeling, causing their stomachs to bloat and their bodies to be lifted off the ground, sending them into the air. These creatures are more dangerous in open areas, as their victims can rise up to 100 feet in the air before plummeting.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The ebony lager can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ebony lager has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) acid damage if the ebony lager is frothy. Additionally, the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw at the beginning of each of its turns. On a success, the target stays solid or becomes solid if currently gaseous. If the creature fails, it becomes gaseous until its next turn.

While gaseous, the target's only method of movement is a flying speed of 10 feet. The target can enter and occupy the space of another creature. The target has resistance to nonmagical damage, and it has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws. The target can pass through small holes, narrow openings, and even mere cracks, though it treats liquids as though they were solid surfaces. The target can't fall and remains hovering in the air even when {@condition stunned} or otherwise {@condition incapacitated}.
While in the form of a misty cloud, the target can't talk or manipulate Objects, and any objects or equipment it was holding fall to the ground. The target can't Attack or cast Spells.

bonus.name: Frothy (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The ebony lager can froth itself up for 1 minute. While frothy, the ebony lager is Large sized, can occupy the space of another creature, has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, is resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons, and treats liquids as though they were solid surfaces.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

These thick, darkly colored oozes are infused with the power of a potion of gaseous form. Their victims are forcibly transformed into clouds of vapor, causing their clothing and weapons to fall away, leaving them naked and helpless once the poison wears off. These oozes are capable of frothing their bodies up, increasing their volume and decreasing any damage they take as weapons simply pass through them with barely any harm.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The ivory moonshine can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Damage Transfer
entries: While it is grappling a creature, the ivory moonshine takes only half the damage dealt to it, and the creature {@condition grappled} by the ivory moonshine takes the other half.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ivory moonshine has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Poison
entries: Each time the target takes poison damage from the ooze, it must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target's sight is magically projected to an {@condition invisible} sensor in a random location within 1 mile of it. The target can only see through this sensor and is {@condition blinded} to its surroundings as a result.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage and the ooze attaches to the target. If the target is Medium or smaller, it attaches by engulfing the target's head, and the target is also {@condition blinded} and unable to breathe while the ooze is attached in this way.

While attached to the target, the ooze can attack no other creature except the target but has advantage on its attack rolls. The ooze's speed also becomes 0, it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed, and it moves with the target.
A creature can detach the ooze by making a successful {@dc 13} Strength check as an action. On its turn, the ooze can detach itself from the target by using 5 feet of movement.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

These perfectly clear oozes shimmer with half seen images, appropriate considering that they are infused with the power of a potion of clairvoyance. When a creature is poisoned by this ooze, its vision is thrown from it in a random direction, effectively blinding it to what is around it.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The perfumed liqueur can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The perfumed liqueur has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Perfume
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the ooze must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition charmed} by all creatures it can see. If a creature is of a species and gender the target is normally attracted to, it regards it as its true love while it is Charmed.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

These sweet smelling oozes are infused with a {@item philter of love}. They continually emit a powerful, nauseatingly sweet aroma which causes those that smells it to become overcome with a delirious, all encompassing affection for every creature they lay eyes on.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The ruby merlot can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the ruby merlot or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ruby merlot has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage. Additionally, the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target exhales flames the first time it speaks on its turn, causing it and any creatures within 5 feet of it take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage. The fire ignites flammable objects in the area that aren’t being worn or carried.

action.name: Fire Jet {@recharge 5}
entries: The ooze produces a jet of fire in a 40-foot line to is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Libation Oozes
entries: The libation oozes are one of the strangest forms of ooze in the multiverse. Carrying the sharp scent of alcohol, these gelatinous monsters are imbued with corrupted potions, spreading their effects with their touches. No one knows how they first came about, whether it was by purposeful intention or wild accident, nor is it clear exactly how they have continued to come into existence, but they present a strange hazard to the unwary.

These bright red oozes roil with internal lights and are imbued with a potion of fire breath. Those poisoned by them uncontrollably exhale flames, making them dangerous to themselves and others whenever they speak.

monster.name: Moor Hound
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Creator Dependent
entries: If the moor hound's creator dies, it immediately dies as well.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The moor hound has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The moor hound has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the moor hound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The hound regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the hound begins its turn exposed to sunlight, this trait doesn't function. The hound dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Scent Evil
entries: The hound can determine if a creature is evil or not by sense of smell.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The hound takes 5 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Attack
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 2d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

A moor hound is an evil construct crafted by mud, twigs, and straw harvested from land cursed by a terrible sin. These materials are shaped into a shape resembling a wolf and then animated by the desire of the land itself for vengeance against the evil that wronged it. These hounds then seek out evil individuals, slaughtering them without mercy to assuage the fury of the earth.

entries.name: Nature's Judgment
entries: A dark enough sin, such as the killing of a family member or a rightful king or the defiling of a sacred place, can stain the earth, leading the land itself to cry out for vengeance. Druids and other beings sensitive to the moods of the land may hear this cry and craft moor hounds out of the stain of sin itself, which hunt the night in search of wickedness to purge from the land. Unless ordered to, a moor hound will not attack a non-evil creature, and they can determine and they can smell evil on a creature, so the innocent rarely need to fear moor hound, though their howls are always chilling.

entries.name: Immortal in the Night
entries: Being born out of the dark fury of the land, a moor hound is all but immortal while in the shadows of the night. Any damage dealt to a moor hound is instantly recovered, and even if its body is crushed and scattered it reforms almost immediately. Only exposure to sunlight makes them vulnerable to destruction.

entries.name: Creator Bound
entries: A moor hound's existence is bound to the soul of its creator, and if its creator dies so does it. A moor hound is bound by ancient laws to obey its creator's orders and it will not attack its creator, even if that creator is evil. As a result, hags and evil druids are fond of creating these creatures as hunters and guardians. Many will even go so far as to orchestrate the committing of a sin so heinous as to curse the land, perhaps even committing the sin themselves, just so that they can craft a pack of obedient moor hounds to protect them.

entries.name: Release from Service
entries: If the sin that blights a land is lifted, then the brooding resentment of the land is absolved and the moor hounds that roam it crumble into harmless dirt and twigs. Moor hounds possess a supernatural intuition for when a creature is seeking to right the wrongs that birthed it, and will often protect those that individuals from harm.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

monster.name: Quablyn
languages: can understand languages it knew before being cursed

trait.name: Bound to Obey
entries: The quablyn is bound to obey, to the letter, any order given to it by its master.

trait.name: Telepathic Link
entries: The quablyn is telepathically linked to all quablyns bound to its master on the same plane of existence. Additionally, the quablyn's master can initiate telepathic communication with it so long as they are both on the same plane of existence.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the quablyn can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action. Its stealth bonus is also improved to {@hit 5}.

trait.name: Transformed Child
entries: A quablyn is a transformed child. If {@spell remove curse} is cast on the quablyn, it returns to its true form. If the quablyn dies, its corpse reverts back to its true form.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The quablyn makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

These grotesque creatures resemble swarthy, misshapen goblins at first glance. However, upon closer glance, their plaintive eyes and surprisingly youthful features reveal their true nature. A quablyn is, in actuality, a humanoid child transformed into a hideous, goblin-like monster, often by a hag or other evil fey.

entries.name: Cursed Memories
entries: A quablyn is incapable of disobeying the being that created it, but it retains a vague, nagging awareness of what it used to be. Though its twisted, malformed soul can no longer feel fear, it still feels longing for the life lost to it. It may gather belongings similar to those it had once owned and create rudimentary mimicries of its former home in a vain attempt to satisfy its desire to belong.

entries.name: Lost Souls
entries: If a quablyn's master is killed, it and its fellow quablyns are left masterless. Lacking any real ambition or sense of community, these quablyns will wander until they are slain. Many will attempt to insinuate themselves into the homes of families that remind it of its former life, slaying any other children the family has in an effort to be the only recipient of love. However, if another being is able to assume mastery of them, they unify once more under their new parental replacement.

entries.name: Lingering Hope
entries: If it dies, a quablyn reverts to the form it had before death, revealing the true horror of its death to whatever poor soul killed them. However, a small hope does exist for the child. If the curse on the child is removed, it will return to its true form just as it had been before it was transformed, with its time spent as a quablyn a barely remembered nightmare.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version.
