All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Incorporeal Form (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the shadow asp becomes incorporeal for up to 1 hour. It can resume being corporeal as a free action. It cannot be incorporeal while exposed to bright light.

While incorporeal, the shadow asp is immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage dealt by non-magical weapons and can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the shadow asp can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action. Its stealth bonus is also improved to {@hit 8}.

trait.name: Sunlight Weakness
entries: While in sunlight, the shadow asp has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, if the target fails the saving throw, it becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage at the beginning of each of its turns.
If a humanoid creature dies while {@condition poisoned} by the shadow asp, a shadow rises from the corpse {@dice 1d4} hours later.

A shadow asp is a small, dusky serpent which resides on the Shadowfell and areas touched by that dark place. They are generally shy, non-aggressive creatures, and are more likely to use their incorporeality to escape predators than to fight back, but if backed into a corner will protect themselves with their venomous bites. Any creatures killed by these bites create undead shadows which rise up and protect the shadow asps from further attacks.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Natural Camouflage
entries: While the sporeback toad remains motionless and partially submerged, it is indistinguishable from a timmask covered log.

trait.name: Timmask Immunity
entries: The sporeback toad is immune to the effects of the timmask mushroom's spores.

trait.name: Timmask Symbiosis {@recharge 5}
entries: When the sporeback toad takes damage, the fungi on its back release a cloud of poisonous spores. Each creature within 15 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is under the effects of a {@spell confusion} spell.

action.name: Barbed Tongue
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} by the tongue (escape {@dc 12}). The target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw at the end of the sporeback's turn or be pulled 10 feet toward the sporeback and be knocked {@condition prone}. The tongue has an AC of 8, 5 hit points, and resistance to bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 12}).

The sporeback toad is by far one of the laziest predators in the world. Having developed a symbiotic relationship with timmask mushromms, which always grow in great profusion around its nesting sites, the sporeback need do virtually nothing to ensure its continued safety, as few predators have an interest in trifling with a creature that creature that cultivates the devil's mushroom on its own back. These toads are content to wallow in mud, waiting for a suitable meal to wander nearby before so that it may lash it with its tongue and reel it in.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Satiation
entries: The swarm stops dealing necrotic damage with its Blood Drain attack after dealing 200 points of necrotic damage. It will remain satiated for 12 hours.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The stirge swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny creature. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes one blood drain attack against each creature in its space.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage, plus 15 ({@damage 6d4}) necrotic damage, or 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage, plus 7 ({@damage 3d4}) necrotic damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

Stirge swarms form naturally when stirges reproduce in excess of available food. When this occurs, their instincts to gather in groups becomes overactive and they flock together, forming huge swarms that ravenously attack any creature they encounter, using the safety of numbers to ensure the survival of at least a few. However, evil magic can also prompt them to form these swarms.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The stitched devil's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Aura of Pain
entries: Any creature that ends its turn within 30 feet of the stitched devil must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) psychic damage. Undead, constructs, and hags ignore this effect.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the stitched devil's darkvision.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The stitched devil has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Telepathic Bond
entries: The stitched devil ignores the range restriction on its telepathy when communicating with the hag to which it is bound. The two don't even need to be on the same plane of existence.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The stitched devil makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Teleport
entries: The stitched devil teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the hag to which it is bound. This ignores planar boundaries.

legendary.name: Hooves (Costs 1 Action)
entries: The bloodlance makes one attack with its hooves.

legendary.name: Rampage (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The bloodlance moves up to 25 feet and makes a horn attack.

A stitched devil is a wretched abomination composed of the sewn together flesh of other devils. The first stitched devils were created by Malagard herself prior to her ascension to the throne of Malebolge as a means to make use of the corpses of those devils which fell in the Blood War. Those techniques have since disseminated throughout hag-kind, and now these hideous monsters can be found all throughout the planes in service to their sadistic mistresses.

entries.name: Constant Agony
entries: A stitched devil is composed of many dissimilar parts clumsily assembled into a perverse mockery of infernal life. The final step of their creation involves infusing them with a fluid rendered from the larvae of Hades, a process which causes the disparate limbs of its body to fuse into one creature with a unique personality and spirit. However, the hodgepodge of limbs that the stitched devil is composed of causes the creature incredible agony at all times, and that agony extends from its body into the very air around it.

entries.name: Bound to Serve
entries: A stitched devil is bound to a specific hag by means of a rune sewn into its flesh. The stitched devil will only obey orders from that specific hag and can connect to it telepathically from anywhere in the multiverse. These fiends can even teleport to their mistress's side in an instant no matter how far away she is. As a result, these creations are highly coveted by hags. However, the expense of creating a stitched devil and difficulty inherent in accessing devil flesh makes them rare. Many hags will seek to slay the current owner of a stitched devil, which renders the creature passive and unresistant, allowing them to change its ownership over to them.

trait.name: Dying Curse
entries: When a styrix dies, the creature that dealt the killing blow must succeed on a {@dc 12} Charisma saving throw or contract its dying curse.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The styrix doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: The styrix has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The styrix has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The styrix can use its Frightful Shriek if available. It then makes two attacks: one with its talons and one with its beak.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Frightful Shriek (1/Day)
entries: Each creature of the styrix's choice that is within 120 feet of the styrix and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature {@condition frightened} in this way must spend its movement at the beginning of each turn moving in a random direction. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success

The styrix is a supernatural predatory bird resembling a large owl. Though they appear fairly mundane at first glance, they are both evil and vicious. They sleep hanging upside down like bats during the day, but at night they glide silently through the trees to hunt.

entries.name: Night Hunters
entries: Able to scatter foes with their frightful shrieks, styrix cherish the opportunity to spread fear and terror through a community. They prowl the night, hunting for any lone victims, and swoop down upon them, tearing them with beak and claw. Though they happily eat anything from mice to the entrails of fully grown humanoids, their favored prey is children, and they will go out of their way to separate a child from its family so that it can take its time hunting it down.

entries.name: Nursemaids
entries: The most peculiar aspect of the biology of a styrix is that they nurse their young, like mammals. In fact, it is believed that styrix do not lay eggs of their own, but rather poach the young of real owls and nurse them on their milk, causing them to grow into styrix themselves. Even odder, though, is the fact that sometimes a styrix may bond with a human infant, nursing it with its milk during the night, nurturing the growth of magic in the child. Children nursed by a styrix always show magical talent, and many are guided by their dark nursemaids into lives of wickedness. As such, hags are particularly fond of these creatures, as they can nurse their daughters in their stead, ensuring strong offspring.

entries.name: Dying Curse
entries: A styrix is a terrible curse upon a community. Not only does the creature itself prey on children and livestock alike, but even killing it is a terrible task. The creature that lands the killing blow on a styrix is afflicted with a terrible curse. As such, many myths exist that a styrix should only be killed by a criminal condemned to death.

monster.name: Wastrel
languages: understands Common and Abyssal but can't speak

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The wastrel doesn't provoke opportunity attacks when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Mimicry (Raven)
entries: The wastrel can mimic simple sounds it has heard, such as a person whispering, a baby crying, or an animal chittering. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 14} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

trait.name: Wasting
entries: If the wastrel tastes a creature's blood, including by making a beak attack, it forges a supernatural link between the wastrel and the target so long as the wastrel and the target are within 300 feet of one another. While this bond persists, the target cannot recover hit points from completing a long or short rest, nor can it overcome a disease without magical aid.

If the wastrel moves more than 300 feet away from the target or a {@spell remove curse} spell is cast on the target, this link is broken and the wastrel must taste the creature's blood again to re-establish the bond. The wastrel can only be linked to one creature at a time.

action.name: Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage.

At first glance, a wastrel appears to be a scruffy, sickly raven or crow. However, it is in fact the transformed soul of an abandoned child. The sorrow and bitterness of abandoment have transformed the poor soul into a fiendish bird which craves to see others die just as it did.

entries.name: Wasting Away
entries: When a wastrel tastes the blood of another creature, it creates a magical link. While this link persists, the victim cannot recover health through normal rest and must rely only on magical healing. Wastrels know that they are weak on their own, and as such they prefer to dive in quickly to taste a creature's blood, then keep their distance while their victim slowly succumbs to the weariness of travel.

monster.name: Baba Yaga, Mother of All Witches

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Baba Yaga's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 21}, {@hit 13} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Horrific Appearance
entries: Whenever a creature that can see Baba Yaga starts its turn within 60 feet of her, she can choose to force it to succeed on a {@dc 22} Wisdom saving throw if she is aware of it. On a failure, the creature is {@condition frightened} of Baba Yaga until the beginning of its next turn.
Unless the target is surprised, the target can avert its eyes until the beginning of its next turn. A creature that averts its eyes has disadvantage on attack rolls against Baba Yaga.

trait.name: Nose for Blood
entries: Baba Yaga has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell. Additionally, if she smells a humanoid she can determine their nationality and bloodline. If a creature has blood, then Baba Yaga's melee attacks have advantage on it if it has unhealed slashing, piercing, or fire damage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Baba yaga fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Baba yaga has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: Baba yaga's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Baba yaga regains 5 hit points at the start of her turn.

trait.name: Witch's Cleverness
entries: When Baba Yaga must make a Wisdom saving throw, she automatically succeeds the saving throw if the DC for the save is equal to or lower than her Wisdom score. She performs Wisdom saving throws to end conditions at the beginning of her turn rather than at the end of it. Additionally, she has advantage on all Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) and Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

trait.name: Baba Yaga's Broom
entries: Baba Yaga's famous broom. This broom is made of a rude handful of straw bristles crudely tied to a birch branch. Despite its appearance, though, it is a powerful tool. The broom acts as a {@item broom of flying}. While holding the broom with at least one hand, Baba Yaga can cast the following spells at-will, using her innate spellcasting ability: {@spell counterspell}, {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell gust of wind}, {@spell nondetection}. These spells can only be cast at-will while Baba Yaga holds the broom.
The broom has the same durability as a normal broom. If destroyed or lost, Baba Yaga can replace the broom after one week of dedicated work.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Baba Yaga can use her Cackle if available. She then make three attacks: two attacks with her claws and one with her bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) piercing damage. If Baba Yaga hits the same creature with two consecutive claw attacks, that creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}). While grappling a creature, Baba Yaga can only make weapon attacks against that creature.

action.name: Cackle {@recharge 5}
entries: Each creature of Baba Yaga's choice that is within 120 of her and can hear her must make a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure the creature takes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) psychic damage and is under the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell for one minute. On a success, the creature takes half that damage and suffers no additional effects. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

legendaryHeader: Baba Yaga can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Baba Yaga regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Baba Yaga makes one bite or claw attack.

legendary.name: Crushing Grasp (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: A creature that Baba Yaga is grappling must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage. On a success, the target escapes the grapple.

legendary.name: Evil Eye (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Baba Yaga targets one creature {@condition frightened} by her that she can see. If the target can see her, it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Charisma saving throw or take 22 ({@damage 4d10}) necrotic damage and be under the effects of a {@spell bestow curse} spell for {@dice 1d4} rounds.

legendaryGroup.name: Baba Yaga, Mother of all Witches

entries: She is the witch of every tale. Her grin the spark on the princess' pyre, her laugh the slam of the oven door.

Stories tell in hushed tones of the terror of the countrysides: a skeleton thin old crone who flies about in a mortar and pestle and devours children. She has the strength of an ox, teeth of iron, and the savage appetite of ten full grown men. Her house dances through the forest, shrieking like the grim specter of death itself, and only obeys her commands. Brave heroes have come to her for aid, and those who did not succumb to her appetite learned many things that they sought. She is Baba Yaga, and she is the oldest and most powerful of all the hags.

entries.name: Why Have You Come?
entries: Baba Yaga knows more than almost any other creature in existence, and what she doesn't know she knows how to find out. Many come seeking her aid, but she does not give her help to just anyone. To those who find her, she poses the question: {@b {@i Why have you come?}} If they answer that they came on the behalf of another, then she refuses to speak to them, turning them away or eating them on the spot. However, if they refuse to give a straight answer, she is impressed and will help them for as long as it amuses her.

entries.name: Little Grandmother
entries: As eldest and mightiest of all hags, Baba Yaga enjoys the privilege of the unique title of {@i Little Grandmother}. However, the name has a strange kernel of truth to it. For reasons unknown to all but herself, Baba Yaga will occasionally adopt a child instead of devouring it, raising the whelp as her own before sending them on their way. Though filled with hardship and fear, the time these children spend with Little Grandmother often grants them skills and insight rarely seen in the mortal world, often becoming adventurers. One of the most well-known of these children, in fact, is none other than the author of the Demonomicon, Iggwilv herself.

entries.name: Friends in Low Places
entries: Baba Yaga's knowledge rarely comes cheap, and the price for those with power is even greater. However, her knowledge is invaluable, so many come seeking her wisdom, even demons and devils. Her many deals and bartering has caused her to gain a wide variety of servants, from fiends to fey to aberrations to giants. Archdevils and Demon Princes alike are indebted to her, and those that would try to turn back or break her contracts will find that her vengeance will be both complete and unexpected. Perhaps her most striking servant, however, is the enigmatic solar knight. His origins are a mystery. All that is known about him is that he is loyal to Baba Yaga and that he exerts some sort of power over the sun itself.

entries.name: Baba Yaga's Dancing Hut
entries: Once per day each, the dancing hut can cast {@spell plane shift}, transporting itself and all of its contents to the target plane. In order to do this, the necessary material components for the spell must be in the hut itself.

While within her Dancing Hut, Baba Yaga recovers 15 hit points at the beginning of her turn instead of 5 and can use her Legendary Resistance an additional 2 times. If Baba Yaga is encountered in her Dancing Hut, she has a challenge rating of 25 (75,000 XP).

monster.name: Baba Yaga's Dancing Hut
languages: understands Common and Sylvan but can't speak

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The baba yaga's dancing hut is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an {@i antimagic field}. If targeted by {@i dispel magic}, the baba yaga's dancing hut must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The dancing hut deals double damage to objects, structures and inanimate plant life.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hut makes three Stomp attacks.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

legendaryHeader: The dancing hut can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The dancing hut regains its spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Escape
entries: The dancing hut makes one saving throw to end one effect on it.

legendary.name: Shriek (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dancing hut releases a god awful shriek. Any creature within 60 feet of it that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

The forest is still this night. In the distance, a horrible shrieking pierces the night sky and the crashing sounds of undergrowth being trampled can be heard. A figure looms out of the dark, dancing and twirling like a drunken man, howling without a mouth into the nightsky. It is a cottage, ramshackle and hideous with but one door, spinning about on a pair of massive chicken legs that trample bushes in its path. This is Baba Yaga's dancing hut

entries.name: Spinning and Dancing
entries: Baba Yaga likes to stay mobile, hence why she saw it prudent to create a home with a pair of chicken legs, so that she might travel the worlds freely. She may settle in a single spot for weeks, months, or even years at a time, marking her territory with leering skulls on pikes and twitching scarecrows, to discourage casual visits, but eventually she will uproot her home to send it dancing through the forests and fields once again.

entries.name: Little Hut, Little Hut
entries: Baba Yaga's hut obeys her without question, but it can be tricked. When she is out on business, she leaves her hut with its door turned towards a cliff or an impassable thicket. However, if a clever adventurer does their research, they'll learn the passphrase: Little hut, little hut, turn your door to me! Upon saying that, the hut will rise up on its massive legs and turn to face the speaker, granting them access.

entries.name: Bigger on the Inside
entries: Though it appears to be a modest hut from the outside, on the inside the dancing hut contains nearly infinite space. There are kitchens, slave quarters, bedrooms for guests, stables for her livestock, cellars, and larders, all within a mere 20' wide house. The mad dancing of the house disturbs the insides little, if at all. And somewhere within the dancing hut is a room that contains its beating heart, the source of the enchantment that gives it life.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

from: {@item plate armor|phb} and {@item shield|phb}, cannot be wielding two handed weapons

trait.name: Trampling Charge (Mammoth)
entries: If the solar knight moves at least 20 feet in a straight line toward a target while mounted on a creature with a speed of 40 feet or more and then hits the target with a lance attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must also succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Daylight Step
entries: The solar knight ignores difficult terrain.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day)
entries: If the solar knight fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The solar knight has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The solar knight's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Sun's Breath
entries: The solar knight makes saving throws to end ongoing effects on itself at the beginning of its turn rather than at the end.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The solar knight makes three greatsword attacks or two lance attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage.

action.name: Lance
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, plus 13 ({@damage 3d8}) radiant damage. This weapon has disadvantage on attacks made against targets within 5 feet of the solar knight. It can only wield this weapon one handed while mounted.

If you approach Baba Yaga's home, you will encounter a bright figure in shining white armor astride a glorious white horse at dawn. At noon, you will meet a fantastic figure in rich red armor astride a magnificent red horse. At dusk, you will encounter a somber figure in deep black armor astride a sinister black horse.

entries.name: White Dawn, Red Noon, Black Dusk
entries: It is unclear whether there are three solar knights who patrol Baba Yaga's realm or just one whose appearance changes with the day. Considering the subjective nature of the Feywild, it could very easily be both. Or perhaps that's the wrong question entirely. The only thing known for certain is that the solar knight belongs to Baba Yaga, body and soul.

entries.name: Fallen but Proud
entries: The solar knight was once a celestial, rumored to have been a guardian of the sun itself. How it came to serve Baba Yaga is a mystery, but an even greater mystery is why it does so without qualm. A being without malice in its blood, the solar knight is far more likely to engage in conversation with a stranger than it is to attack on sight, and it always shows the utmost courtesy when doing so. However, it is unswervingly loyal to Baba Yaga and will brook no insult to her or her name, and will challenge those who speak ill of his lady to a duel.

monster.name: Black Agga

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Black Agga's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

3e: {@spell disguise self} ({@i including the form of a Medium humanoid with only two arms})

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Black Agga is a 17th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks, or {@dc 16} and {@hit 8} without her {@i Black Hand}). She regains her expended spell slots when she finishes a short or long rest. She knows the following warlock spells:

spells: {@spell eldritch blast} ({@i 1d10 + 3 per blast, range 300 ft.})

trait.name: Grafted Body Parts
entries: Black Agga has grafted a number of body parts onto herself. If these limbs are severed, they do not grow back, though they can still be reattached.

items: Two {@creature troll} arms are attached to her body in addition to her own two arms, giving her four arms in total. These arms make attacks and damage rolls with a Strength of {@b 18 (+4)}. These grafted arms are capable of providing somatic components for spells.

The jaw of a {@creature pit fiend}, which has replaced Agga's own jaw. The jaw make attacks and deals damage with a Strength of {@b 26 (+8)} and possess the venomous qualities of a {@creature pit fiend}.
The wings of a {@creature young black dragon}, which grant her a flying speed of 80 ft.
Black Agga's right forearm has been replaced with the {@i Black Hand}.

trait.name: Black Hand
entries: Black Agga has replaced her right forearm with the black, mummified forearm of her mother. As part of her oath of service to Vaprak, she murdered her mother and devoured her flesh. While this hand is attached to her, it has the same properties of a {@item +2 rod of the pact keeper}. Because the hand is mummified, it does not die if separated from Black Agga, but it does become non-magical so long as it is out of Black Agga's possession.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: Black Agga has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Black Agga fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Black Agga has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Trollish Regeneration
entries: Black Agga regains 10 hit points at the start of her turn. If Black Agga takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of her next turn. Black Agga dies only if she starts her turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Black Agga makes three attacks: one with her bite and two with her claws. She cannot make a claw attack with the same claw twice in one round.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d6 + 8}) piercing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 21} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target can't regain hit points, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) poison damage at the start of each of its turns. The {@condition poisoned} target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Grafted Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Crushing Hug
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}37 ({@damage 9d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}) if it is a Large or smaller creature. Until the grapple ends, the target takes 37 ({@damage 9d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage at the start of each of Black Aggas' turns. While grappling a creature in this way, Black Agga cannot make attacks with her natural claws. If one or both of her natural arms have been severed, Black Agga can use one or both of her grafted limbs to make the attack, reducing the damage dealt to 25 ({@damage 6d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and the escape DC is reduced to {@dc 18}.

legendaryHeader: Black Agga can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Black Agga regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Claw
entries: Black Agga makes one claw attack. She cannot make a claw attack with the same claw twice in one round.

legendary.name: Regrow Limb (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: If one of Black Aggas' natural limbs has been severed, she can regrow the limb, causing the severed limb to wither and die. She cannot use this action if she has taken fire or acid damage since her last turn.
There is power in hunger, my child. The teeth, the tongue, the blood, they speak the words of strength. Embrace the hunger, dearie.

entries.name: Black Agga, the Voice of Vaprak
entries: Black Agga is an annis hag who has become so much more than her origins. Once she served her mother's coven, kowtowing to the harridan's tyrannical whims. However, she heard the voice of Vaprak in the spilling of entrails and the rip of teeth through flesh. Through perverse auguries she learned to contact that god of violence, and he granted her power in exchange for her service, which she gladly gave. She murdered her mother and devoured her flesh in the honor of the Destroyer, and from that point on she became the Voice of Vaprak.

entries.name: Mouth of the Destroyer
entries: Black Agga has fully embraced Vaprak's philosophy of strength and hunger. She roams far and wide across the world, seeking out tribes of trolls, ogres, orcs, frost giants, and other brutal folk to spread his cannibalistic gospel. As part of her devotion to the Destroyer, she consumes the flesh of trolls, his most favored children. She has been feeding on the flesh of trolls for so long that her flesh has attained the regenerative properties of that foul race of giants.

entries.name: Flesh of Victory
entries: Her body is composed of trophies taken from some of her most impressive victories, including the wings of a black dragon that she slaughtered with her bare hands and the venomous jaw of a mighty pit fiend. Both of her grafted troll arms are taken from troll chieftains who have dared to stand against her. Because of the numerous flesh grafts, Black Agga must frequently ingest a number of potions in order to maintain control over her body.

entries.name: Congregation of Hunger
entries: Her most loyal servants are the trolls of the Gutgnaw tribe, who reside deep within the chill depths of the Frostrot Marsh, where they maintain one of the only permanent shrines to Vaprak in the multiverse. Though she is rarely with the tribe, she is able to keep tabs on the shrine by use of her iron token, and she uses her magic to awe and terrify these superstitious brutes when she visists them. The warriors from the Gutgnaw tribe are infamous among the giantkin as being the most savage and cunning of all trolls, and the current chieftain of is a fanatically devout worshiper of Vaprak. As a sign of Vaprak's favor, he bears the grafted right arm of the dire troll chieftain from whom he wrested control of the tribe.

entries.name: Black Aggas' Lair
entries: Black Agga prefers to lair deep within caves where she practices her dark magic and surrounds herself with loyal worshipers of Vaprak. These caves are littered with the bones and viscera of countless victims, and the air is thick with the otherworldly reek of the Abyss.
If Black Agga is encountered in her lair, she has a challenge rating of 18 (22,000 XP).

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Black Agga takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; Black Agga can't use the same effect two turns in a row.

items: Black Agga imbues one creature that she can see that worships Vaprak with the rage of the Destroyer and directs it to use its reaction to make one melee attack. The rage lasts for 1 minutes or until the creature is {@condition incapacitated} or Black Agga uses this Lair Action on a different creature. While raging, the creature has advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws, it gains a {@b +4} bonus to its damage rolls, and it has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

Black Agga empowers all creatures within her lair that worship Vaprak with the hunger of the Destroyer. Until initiative count 20 of the following round, a creature that worships Vaprak can make a bite attack as a bonus action on its turn. If the creature does not have a bite attack, it gains that attack and uses one of the following options, based on its Size, to determine damage rolls: {@dice 1d4} if it is Small, {@dice 1d4} + its Strength modifier if it is Medium, {@dice 1d6} + its Strength modifier if it is Large, {@dice 2d6} + its Strength modifier if it is Huge, and {@dice 3d6} + its Strength modifier if it is Gargantuan. The creature recovers hit points equal to the piercing damage the bite attack deals.

Black Agga afflicts all creatures within her lair that worship Vaprak with the terror of the Destroyer. When a creature that worships Vaprak makes a successful melee attack against a creature that does not worship Vaprak, the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} by terror until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of Black Aggas lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Beasts and monstrosities in the area are unnaturally aggressive and will attack without warning or provocation.
Occasionally, the smell of sulfur and rotten meat fills the air for a few moments.

entries: When Black Agga dies or leaves the area, these effects fade after {@dice 1d6} days

entries.name: Loathsome Limbs
entries: Black Agga's trollish appetite has given her limbs the same repulsive form of self locomotion as those of a troll. Because of her flesh grafting, these express themselves somewhat differently from trolls. Whenever Black Agga takes at least 15 slashing damage at one time, roll a {@dice d20} to determine what else happens to her:

items: {@b 1-10:} Nothing else happens.
{@b 11-13:} One leg is severed from Black Agga if she has any legs left.
{@b 14-16} One arm is severed from Black Agga if she has any arms left.
{@b 17-18:} One wing is severed from Black Agga if she has any wings left.
{@b 19-20:} Black Agga is decapitated, but Black Agga dies only if her body is reduced to 0 hit points and is unable to regenerate.

entries: Black Agga can reattach one limb on her turn as a bonus action if she has not taken acid or fire damage since her last turn. If Black Agga finishes a short or long rest without reattaching a severed limb or head, the part regrows, except for her grafted limbs. At that point, the severed part dies. Until then, a severed part acts on Black Agga's initiative and has its own action and movement. A severed part has AC 13, 10 hit points, and Black Aggas Regeneration trait.
A severed leg is unable to attack and has a speed of 5 feet.

severed arm has a speed of 5 feet and can make one claw attack on its turn, with disadvantage on the attack roll unless Black Agga can see the arm and its target. Each time Black Agga loses an arm, she loses a claw attack. Black Agga must have at least two arms in order to use her Crushing Hug action.
A severed wing is unable to attack, has a speed of 5 feet, and attempts to escape Black Agga.

If her head is severed, Black Agga loses her bite attack and her body is blinded unless the head can see it. The severed head has a speed of 0 feet and Black Aggas Keen Smell trait. It can make a bite attack but only against a target in its space.

Black Agga cannot fly if she is missing a wing. Black Aggas walking speed is halved if shes missing a leg and doesn't have at least one wing. If she loses both legs and cannot fly, she falls prone. If she has at least two arms, she can crawl. With only one arm, she can still crawl, but her speed is halved. With no arms, legs, or wings, her speed is 0, and she cant benefit from bonuses to speed.

monster.name: Ceithlenn, of the Crooked Teeth

trait.name: Box of Treasures
entries: The Box of Treasures has 10 charges. While she is holding the Box of Treasures, Ceithlenn can use an action to expend 1 charge to cast {@spell augury}. Additionally, she can cast one of the following spells once per day each ({@dc 18}), consuming charges as needed. The spells behave as normal, but with the following aesthetic alterations:

items: {@spell Antilife Shell} {@b (2 charges).} Ceithlenn is surrounded by ghostly spirits of children which prevent affected creatures from passing them.

{@spell Awaken} {@b (1 charge).} Rather than imbuing the target beast or plant with intelligence, this spell instead imbues the targetted creature with the spirit of a child. The awakened creature still obeys Ceithlenn.
{@spell Blight} {@b (1 charge).} When this spell affects a creature, the target can hear the sound of a sobbing child.
{@spell Confusion} {@b (1 charge).} Affected creatures are assaulted by hallucinations of fiendish children attacking them or {@condition frightened} children calling for their help.
{@spell Contagion} {@b (2 charges).} The {@condition invisible} spirit of a child clings to the infected target throughout the duration of the disease.

{@spell Dream} {@b (2 charges).} Ceithlenn always appears in dreams accompanied by blank eyed children. Additionally, while the target is under the effects of the spell, the ghostly figures of children can be seen around the target's sleeping body, staring blankly at it.
{@spell Fog Cloud} {@b (1 charge).} The shapes of children can be seen moving about in the mist, just out of view.
{@spell Hold Person} {@b (1 charge).} The target is {@condition restrained} by the incorporeal spirits of children, which stare pleadingly at it as if begging the target to help them.
{@spell Pass Without Trace} {@b (1 charge).} Shadowy spirits of children accompany the creatures affected by the spell within the veil of shadows and silence produced by the spell.
{@spell Slow} {@b (1 charge).} The area affected by the spell becomes filled with the grasping, desperate spirits of children begging the affected creatures to not leave them.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Ceithlenn fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Ceithlenn has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: Ceithlenn's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Ceithlenn makes two attacks: one with her spear and one with either her bite, touch, or venomous glare.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Venomous Glare
entries: One creature within 60 feet of Ceithlenn that she can see must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failure.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, or 14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage if used with both hands in melee. The target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 17 ({@damage 5d6}) poison damage on a failure or half as much on a success. On a failure, the target also becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is vulnerable to necrotic damage.

action.name: Wretched Bite
entries: Ceithlenn makes one Bite attack. If it hits, her teeth dislodge from her mouth and burrow into the target's flesh, dealing an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage. Additionally, the teeth imbed themselves in the target's flesh until surgically removed with a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check, a process which takes 1 hour of dedicated work. While the teeth are imbedded in the creature's flesh, it is affected as if by a {@spell bestow curse} spell while within 30 feet of Ceithlenn or a creature loyal to her. A {@spell remove curse} spell suppresses this effect for the next 24 hours.
Once Ceithlenn has used this action, she cannot make another Bite attack until she has used an action to expend a charge from her Box of Treasure to replace the teeth in her mouth.

legendaryHeader: Ceithlenn can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Ceithlenn regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack.
entries: Ceithlenn makes one bite, touch, or Venomous Glare.

legendary.name: Magic (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Ceithlenn casts a spell from her Box of Treasures.
She walked the paths of Barovia long before it received that name from Strahd. She remembers what it was like before his evil poisoned the land. And make no mistake, she is poisoned too.

Long before Strahd conquered the land of Barovia and named it after his father, long before the people he conquered lived there, Ceithlenn and her husband ruled the groves and hills of the land as king and queen. A child of Mother Night and the Morninglord, Ceithlenn was a beautiful and perilous archfey queen When mortals discovered her land, she extended her protection to those who showed her and the gods of the land the proper respect.

entries.name: Conquest
entries: When Strahd von Zarovich came to the land, Ceithlenn foresaw that he would lay them low. Still, she and her husband rode out to do battle with the ruthless warlord, and though Ceithlenn's husband was struck down, she was able to escape to her island home, albeit gravely wounded. There she lingered with the meager remnants of her people while the curse of Strahd and the Dark Powers that favored him descended on the land.

entries.name: The Crooked Teeth
entries: The wickedness of Strahd and his lust for power poisoned Barovia when he gained power, and that poison has slowly twisted Ceithlenn and her lands over decades into something wretched and petty. Now she is but a shadow of her former glory, scrounging desperately for every bit of power she can and cursing the people of Barovia who have forgotten her. She sends her agents out into the wilderness of Barovia to capture children, commanding that they sacrifice them to her. Using their innocent souls, Ceithlenn is able to reclaim some of her former power, twisted and perverted though it is.

entries.name: The Island in the Mists
entries: Ceithlenn fears to leave her island, for the land no longer loves her as it once did, the curse of Strahd having caused the stones and trees to forget her name. However, on nights when the mists part to reveal her island of Enniskillen and drift through the forests and the mournful streets of Vallaki, the buried memory of the queen of the land is stirred to the surface. Only on these nights, when the land recalls her name, does Ceithlenn dare to leave her home.

entries.name: Collector of Souls
entries: Ceithlenn knows that the souls of those who die in Barovia are trapped within the mists, and she knows that Strahd can only gain sustenance by feeding on the blood of those with souls. As such, she has devised a plan to starve out Strahd by capturing all the souls within Barovia and binding them to her island of Enniskillen, which she believes Strahd is unable to reach.

entries.name: Ceithlenn's Lair
entries: Ceithlenn makes her home in a cave on the island of Enniskillen. The island lingers in the mists of Lake Zarovich, only appearing when the Dark Powers permit it to do so. When the people of Vallaki see the island of Enniskillen loom through the mists, they shut their doors and bar their windows as the influence of Ceithlenn drifts across the lake once again.

entries.name: Servants of Ceithlenn
entries: Ceithlenn's interests in Barovia are seen to by fey, ghosts, hags, and other lingering spirits of the land. Dryads, quicklings, pixies, sprites, redcaps, and other fey creatures still hear her voice echoing in the mists and enact her commands, though precious few remain in the cursed land of Barovia.

entries.name: Banshee
entries: When Strahd had the dusk elf women of Barovia slaughtered, Ceithlenn was there to catch their fleeing spirits. She corrupted them to her own purposes, transforming them into the banshees that drift listlessly upon her island and accompany her when she travels to the mainland, longing for vengeance against Strahd.

entries.name: Chattering Ivory
entries: A chattering ivory is the skull of a Vistani child still containing its eyes. As an action, Ceithlenn can call on the spirit of skull, animating it as a {@creature flame skull} that can use Vistani curses and the evil eye instead of its Spellcasting option. Vistani curses and evil eye are detailed on paged 28 of {@i Curse of Strahd}.

entries.name: The Hags of Old Bonegrinder
entries: The night hag Morgantha and her two daughters Bella Sunbane anf Offalia Wormwiggle, are among Ceithlenn's most favored servants. Each hag possesses a lesser treasure box constructed by Ceithlenn.

entries.name: Ceithlenn in the Curse of Strahd
entries: Ceithlenn's island home is just north of Vallaki in Lake Zarovich, and her influence reaches all throughout the town. Bluto, the town drunkard, is a servant of Ceithlenn. He hears commands in his dreams and believes that she is a goddess who will reward him generously with bountiful catches of fish.

items: {@b As an Enemy} The Festival of the Blazing Sun presents an opportunity for Ceithlenn to capture all the children of Vallaki. As the downpour that ruins the festival begins, mist rapidly forms and envelops the town and the sounds of the pipes of clean bone begin to drift through the air, calling the children to Lake Zarovich, where they will drown themselves if given the opportunity. Any adults that attempt to stop the children are stopped by the fey that arrive with the mists. If the hags of Old Bonegrinder have not yet been killed, then they act as the heralds of Ceithlenn, announcing her imminent arrival to terrify the people of the town by appearing in the wicker sun in a burst of green, eldritch fire. If, however, they are killed prior to the party arriving in the town, then the party finds evidence of the plans for the Festival of the Blazing Sun, including a replica of the wicker sun beside the windmill that they were going to use to teleport into the wicker son of the festival (this can be determined with a successful {@dc 15} Arcana check and an hour of study).

{@b As an Ally.} Ceithlenn presents a unique opportunity for an ally, as she knows a great deal about Strahd and can provide answers to any questions that the characters have. However, she will almost never deal directly with players, as she fears to leave her home. Instead, she prefers to guide their actions by means of her agents. For this purpose, she tends to favor the hags of Old Bonegrinder. Morgantha and her daughters each have the ability to answer one question by means of the lesser treasure boxes they possess, and they may provide the players with unique tools if so inclined.

monster.name: Malagard, the Hag Countess

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that arent silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Malagard's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 21}, {@hit 13} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: Malagard fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Malagard has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: Malagard's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Umbilical Reliance
entries: A shriveled, pulsing umbilical cord trails out of Malagard's stomach, leading down the twisting tunnels of Magoth Thym. This cord cannot extend more than 100 feet outside of the entrance of Magoth Thym. While the cord remains intact, Malagard regains 10 hit points at the start of her turn. If she takes radiant damage, this trait doesnt function at the start of her next turn.

If Malagard is struck by a {@item vorpal sword}, the wielder can cut her umbilical cord instead of dealing damage. If her umbilical cord is cut, Malagard does not recover hit points and instead takes 10 points of necrotic damage at the start of her turn. Malagard dies only if she starts her turn with 0 hit points and isn't connected to the umbilical cord.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Malagard makes three attacks: two with her claws and one with her bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. The target is also afflicted by the {@spell contagion} spell ({@dc 21}. any disease, Malagard's choice). If the target succeeds on its saving throws against the spell, it is immune to infection from this bite for 24 hours.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage. Malagard can cast {@spell bestow curse} on the target as part of this attack.

legendaryHeader: Malagard can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Malagard regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Witch Touch
entries: Malagard makes one claw attack or casts {@spell magic missile}.

legendary.name: Umbilical Trip (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Malagard lashes out with her umbilical cord, causing the portion extending 30 feet out from her to swing 10 feet in one direction. All creatures in the path of the cord must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.
Revenge is the blood of the multiverse, and I shall drink it all.

Malagard has always been an aberration in the hierarchy of the Nine Hells. The night hag caught the eye of Moloch, former ruler of the Sixth Layer of Baator, while visiting the Nine Hells on the business of the Soul Trade. He noticed her cunning and made her his advisor, a choice he would come to regret. Through Malagard's machinations, Moloch was eventually deposed from his position of rulership and cast out from the Nine Hells, leaving the night hag herself to claim the position of ruler of Malebolge, making her the only non-devil to ever hold such a position.

entries.name: Fall From Power
entries: For many centuries, Malagard ruled the sixth layer of Baator from within a fortress built in a massive bolder that perpetually rolled down the vertiginous cliffs of the layer, continually confounding her rivals with her unpredictability. Unfortunately for Malagard, none could have predicted her fate. She was deposed from her throne when she mysteriously swelled to unbelievable size and ruptured, coating the layer with her skin and viscera, transforming Malebolge into a realm of pus filled lakes and suppurating flesh. Asmodeus's daughter Glasya was installed in her place, and has ruled ever since.

entries.name: Lingering Will
entries: Though Glasya has reigned over Malebolge for centuries, she still fears the retribution of the Hag Countess. The flesh that once coated the layer was always treacherous to devils, and even though most of it has been harvested for various purposes, a few isolated heaths of cancerous tumors and forests of tangled hair remain, spawning wild monsters and resisting all efforts by devils to remove them. Glasya fears that Malagard may have found a way to safeguard against her own death. Little does she know how true that is.

entries.name: The Hag's Plan
entries: Malagard's death was not the end for her. Malagard had not claimed the throne of Malebolge out of ambition for rulership of that miserable place. Rather, she sought the secrets that she knew were hidden beneath the cliffs and slopes of that plane. Long she searched for these secrets, delving into lore forbidden even by the devils, until she learned of a place on Malebolge that devils themselves fear to approach: Magoth Thym.

entries.name: Ancient Evil
entries: Deep in the caverns of Magoth Thym sleeps something older than the devils. Older than the Hells. Even older than the Lower Planes themselves. A shapeless evil, more ancient than rational thought, sleeps fitfully beneath the plane, crying a horrific, soundless cries as it dreams and causing avalanches when it stirs. Kin to both Zargon the Returner and the Queen of Chaos, the hungry darkness is the true shape of evil from before law and chaos divided the multiverse. This was the secret that Malagard sought, and it was with this primeval wickedness that she made a pact.

entries.name: The Decay of Hell
entries: When Malagard died and her guts and flesh were strewn about her home, her lingering, enraged spirit was caught by the unknowable evil that she had bargained with. Over many years it crafted her a new body from her pulsing flesh. Now she reclaims her power bit by bit, while her plots erode the grasp of Asmodeus on Hell, dragging it ever closer to the primeval darkness from which it once sprung. The mouths of Magoth Thym vomit up horrors to spread madness and chaos throughout the Hells.

entries.name: Malagard's Lair
entries: Malagard remains bound to Magoth Thym, unable to leave the realm until her resurrection is complete. Her flesh is strewn about the insides of the cavern, and it continually pulses and oozes pus, bile, sweat, and fouler fluids.

monster.name: Kalabon

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: telepathy 120 ft. (only with Glasya, Malagard, and other kalabon)

trait.name: Combine
entries: By using its movement and action on its turn, the kalabon can combine with three other kalabon to form a {@creature kalabon wart} with hit points equal to the combined total of the constituent kalabon that formed it.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the kalabon must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all kalabon for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kalabon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage.

reaction.name: The Greater Good
entries: If the kalabon is in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard, it sacrifices itself to grant half of its current hit points to Malagard or any other kalabon in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard.

When Malagard was first cast down and her flesh strewn across Malebolge, fragments of her spirit were scatted throughout her heaving corpse. These fragments took hold in her suppurating flesh, ripping themselves free from the ground and shambling forth, creating the kalabon, wretched little misshappen fiends forever tormented by the psychic screams of the hag from whom they were born.

entries.name: Endless Agony
entries: The kalabon are born from Malagard's agony, and they experience it constantly. Even with her having regained physical form, they will not know true peace until Malagard achieves full resurrection. Until then they remain in constant pain, seeking the comfort of each other's company, gathering together in pathetically weeping piles of flesh and melding together into larger amalgams of flesh in a vain attempt to approximate the feeling of completeness that they crave.

entries.name: Two Mistresses
entries: Even with the partial resurrection of their mistress, kalabon are still bound by the immutable laws of magic to obey the ruling lord of Malebolge, Glasya, whom they despise more than anything. The kalabon that roam Magoth Thym have nothing to fear from her or any other devil, for the nature of Magoth Thym holds the devils at bay, but those kalabon residing in the remaining forests of hair elsewhere on Malebolge live in constant terror that she will arrive and command them to assist in the destruction of what little remains of Malagard's flesh.

monster.name: Kalabon Wart

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: telepathy 120 ft. (only with Glasya, Malagard, and other kalabon)

trait.name: Combine
entries: By using its movement and action on its turn, the kalabon wart can combine with another kalabon wart to form a {@creature kalabon ulcer} with hit points equal to the combined total of the constituent kalabon warts that formed it.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the kalabon must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all kalabon for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kalabon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kalabon makes two tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Divide
entries: The kalabon wart divides itself into four kalabon, which can appear in any spaces the kalabon wart had occupied as well as any unoccupied spaces within 5 feet of it. The new kalabon act immediately but can only use the {@action Dash} action this round. If the kalabon wart has half its hit points or fewer, half of the kalabon it divides into are dead.

reaction.name: The Greater Good
entries: If the kalabon is in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard, it sacrifices itself to grant half of its current hit points to Malagard or any other kalabon in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard.

When Malagard was first cast down and her flesh strewn across Malebolge, fragments of her spirit were scatted throughout her heaving corpse. These fragments took hold in her suppurating flesh, ripping themselves free from the ground and shambling forth, creating the kalabon, wretched little misshappen fiends forever tormented by the psychic screams of the hag from whom they were born.

entries.name: Endless Agony
entries: The kalabon are born from Malagard's agony, and they experience it constantly. Even with her having regained physical form, they will not know true peace until Malagard achieves full resurrection. Until then they remain in constant pain, seeking the comfort of each other's company, gathering together in pathetically weeping piles of flesh and melding together into larger amalgams of flesh in a vain attempt to approximate the feeling of completeness that they crave.

entries.name: Two Mistresses
entries: Even with the partial resurrection of their mistress, kalabon are still bound by the immutable laws of magic to obey the ruling lord of Malebolge, Glasya, whom they despise more than anything. The kalabon that roam Magoth Thym have nothing to fear from her or any other devil, for the nature of Magoth Thym holds the devils at bay, but those kalabon residing in the remaining forests of hair elsewhere on Malebolge live in constant terror that she will arrive and command them to assist in the destruction of what little remains of Malagard's flesh.

A kalabon wart is a grouping of four to seven kalabon which have fused together into a larger creature for the sake of protection. About the size of a hulking, misshapen humanoid, these repulsive monsters lumber through the undergrowth of tumorous forests, seeking anything to vent their rage against.

monster.name: Kalabon Swarm

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: telepathy 120 ft. (only with Glasya, Malagard, and other kalabon)

trait.name: Combine
entries: By using its movement and action on its turn, the swarm can combine with three other kalabon swarms or {@creature kalabon ulcer}s to form a {@creature kalabon cancer} with hit points equal to the combined total of the constituent kalabon that formed it. Alternatively, it can form itself into a kalabon ulcer.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the kalabon must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all kalabon for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kalabon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The kalabon swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny creature. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The swarm makes one tentacles attack against each creature in its space.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target in the swarm's space. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer.

reaction.name: The Greater Good
entries: If the kalabon is in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard, it sacrifices itself to grant half of its current hit points to Malagard or any other kalabon in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard.

When Malagard was first cast down and her flesh strewn across Malebolge, fragments of her spirit were scatted throughout her heaving corpse. These fragments took hold in her suppurating flesh, ripping themselves free from the ground and shambling forth, creating the kalabon, wretched little misshappen fiends forever tormented by the psychic screams of the hag from whom they were born.

entries.name: Endless Agony
entries: The kalabon are born from Malagard's agony, and they experience it constantly. Even with her having regained physical form, they will not know true peace until Malagard achieves full resurrection. Until then they remain in constant pain, seeking the comfort of each other's company, gathering together in pathetically weeping piles of flesh and melding together into larger amalgams of flesh in a vain attempt to approximate the feeling of completeness that they crave.

entries.name: Two Mistresses
entries: Even with the partial resurrection of their mistress, kalabon are still bound by the immutable laws of magic to obey the ruling lord of Malebolge, Glasya, whom they despise more than anything. The kalabon that roam Magoth Thym have nothing to fear from her or any other devil, for the nature of Magoth Thym holds the devils at bay, but those kalabon residing in the remaining forests of hair elsewhere on Malebolge live in constant terror that she will arrive and command them to assist in the destruction of what little remains of Malagard's flesh.

Kalabon feel most comfortable in groups. These swarms of kalabon constitue anywhere from 8 to 20 kalabon all rushing together as a semi-cohesive whole. However, they are far more likely to meld their flesh together into warts, ulcers, and cancers, but if under the threat of death they will break apart into these swarms in order to better flee into the undergrowth and assure the survival of as many of them as possible.

monster.name: Kalabon Ulcer

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: telepathy 120 ft. (only with Glasya, Malagard, and other kalabon)

trait.name: Combine
entries: By using its movement and action on its turn, the kalabon ulcer can combine with three other kalabon ulcers to form a {@creature kalabon cancer} with hit points equal to the combined total of the constituent kalabon ulcers that formed it.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the kalabon must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all kalabon for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kalabon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kalabon makes three tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Vomit Bile {@recharge 6}
entries: The kalabon vomits a 15-foot cone of bile. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage and 21 ({@damage 6d6}) poison damage on a failure or half as much on a success.

action.name: Divide
entries: The kalabon ulcer divides itself into a {@creature kalabon swarm} with the same number of hit points as itself, which appears in its space. The new swarm can act immediately but can only use the {@action Dash} action this round.

reaction.name: The Greater Good
entries: If the kalabon is in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard, it sacrifices itself to grant half of its current hit points to Malagard or any other kalabon in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard.

When Malagard was first cast down and her flesh strewn across Malebolge, fragments of her spirit were scatted throughout her heaving corpse. These fragments took hold in her suppurating flesh, ripping themselves free from the ground and shambling forth, creating the kalabon, wretched little misshappen fiends forever tormented by the psychic screams of the hag from whom they were born.

entries.name: Endless Agony
entries: The kalabon are born from Malagard's agony, and they experience it constantly. Even with her having regained physical form, they will not know true peace until Malagard achieves full resurrection. Until then they remain in constant pain, seeking the comfort of each other's company, gathering together in pathetically weeping piles of flesh and melding together into larger amalgams of flesh in a vain attempt to approximate the feeling of completeness that they crave.

entries.name: Two Mistresses
entries: Even with the partial resurrection of their mistress, kalabon are still bound by the immutable laws of magic to obey the ruling lord of Malebolge, Glasya, whom they despise more than anything. The kalabon that roam Magoth Thym have nothing to fear from her or any other devil, for the nature of Magoth Thym holds the devils at bay, but those kalabon residing in the remaining forests of hair elsewhere on Malebolge live in constant terror that she will arrive and command them to assist in the destruction of what little remains of Malagard's flesh.

A kalabon ulcer is a grouping of eight to thirty kalabon which have fused together into a bulging, ogre sized monstrosity. Far more formidable than their constituent parts, these ulcers are a howling, bile spewing force of destruction.

monster.name: Kalabon Cancer

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: telepathy 120 ft. (only with Glasya, Malagard, and other kalabon)

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the kalabon must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the stench of all kalabon for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kalabon has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kalabon makes four tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 3d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage.

action.name: Vomit Bile {@recharge 6}
entries: The kalabon vomits a 30-foot cone of bile. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 6d8}) acid damage and 27 ({@damage 6d8}) poison damage on a failure or half as much on a success.

action.name: Divide
entries: The kalabon cancer divides itself into four {@creature kalabon swarm}s, which appear in any spaces the kalabon cancer had occupied as well as any spaces within 5 feet of it.
