The new kalabon swarms act immediately but can only use the {@action Dash} action this round. The hit points of the kalabon cancer are divided evenly among the swarms.

reaction.name: The Greater Good
entries: If the kalabon is in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard, it sacrifices itself to grant half of its current hit points to Malagard or any other kalabon in direct contact with the flesh of Malagard.

When Malagard was first cast down and her flesh strewn across Malebolge, fragments of her spirit were scatted throughout her heaving corpse. These fragments took hold in her suppurating flesh, ripping themselves free from the ground and shambling forth, creating the kalabon, wretched little misshappen fiends forever tormented by the psychic screams of the hag from whom they were born.

entries.name: Endless Agony
entries: The kalabon are born from Malagard's agony, and they experience it constantly. Even with her having regained physical form, they will not know true peace until Malagard achieves full resurrection. Until then they remain in constant pain, seeking the comfort of each other's company, gathering together in pathetically weeping piles of flesh and melding together into larger amalgams of flesh in a vain attempt to approximate the feeling of completeness that they crave.

entries.name: Two Mistresses
entries: Even with the partial resurrection of their mistress, kalabon are still bound by the immutable laws of magic to obey the ruling lord of Malebolge, Glasya, whom they despise more than anything. The kalabon that roam Magoth Thym have nothing to fear from her or any other devil, for the nature of Magoth Thym holds the devils at bay, but those kalabon residing in the remaining forests of hair elsewhere on Malebolge live in constant terror that she will arrive and command them to assist in the destruction of what little remains of Malagard's flesh.

A kalabon cancer is a grouping of thirty or more kalabon which have fused together into a monstrous pile of heaving, groaning flesh larger than an elephant. Able to vomit fountains of bile and possessing incredible power, these howling nightmares ward all but the strongest devils away from the forests of hair.

trait.name: Acidic Body
entries: A creature that touches the bile wrapped in beauty or begins its turn grappling the bile wrapped in beauty or being {@condition grappled} by it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) acid damage.

trait.name: Corrode Metal
entries: Any nonmagical weapon made of metal that hits the bile wrapped in beauty corrodes. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to −5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal that hits the bile wrapped in beauty is destroyed after dealing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bile wrapped in beauty makes two touch attacks.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage, and if the target is wearing nonmagical metal armor, its armor is partly corroded and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. The armor is destroyed if the penalty reduces its AC to 10. If the bile wrapped in beauty hits the target with two touch attacks in the same turn, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}).

action.name: Vomit Bile {@recharge 6}
entries: The bile wrapped in beauty spews out a corrosive bile, targeting one creature that it can see within 60 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) acid damage, or half as much on a success. Unless the target avoids taking any of this damage, the creature gains a {@table Lingering Injuries||Horrible Scar}.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: The bile wrapped in beauty covers itself and anything it is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes it look like another creature of her general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if the bile wrapped in beauty attacks, takes a bonus action to end it, or if it dies.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern that the bile wrapped in beauty is disguised.

When a lie is told within the Feywild to disguise evil intentions, a bile wrapped in beauty may be born, rising from mud when night next falls. These fey are hideous, misshapen things covered in sores that drip with a highly acid pus, but they possess the ability to magically conceal their hideousness behind illusions of beauty. These wretched monsters hate all beautiful things and seek to ruin any beauty they encounter, making them natural allies of hags and demons. They are especially dangerous for their ability to dissolve weapons that touch them and permanently scar their victims with their corrosive bile.

trait.name: False Appearance (Treant)
entries: While the blight remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a melon.

trait.name: Tendrils
entries: The blight can have up to six tendrils at a time. The blight can attach or detach up to six tendrils to blights or undead within 10 feet of it as a bonus action. A creature regains 1 hit point at the start of its turn for each tendril attached to it, increasing to 5 hit points per tendril if the melon blight is attached to a creature with its Blood Drain action. If the creature takes fire damage, this recovery doesn't occur at the start of the creature's next turn. A creature with a tendril attached dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

A tendril can extend up to 30 feet. Each tendril can be attacked (AC 20; 10 hit points; immunity to poison and psychic damage). Destroying a tendril deals no damage to the blight, which can extrude a replacement tendril on its next turn. A tendril can also be broken if a creature takes an action and succeeds on a {@dc 15} Strength check against it.

action.name: Tendrils
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) slashing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 10}).

action.name: Blood Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d6 + 1}) necrotic damage, and the blight attaches to the target for as long as it remains grappling it. While attached, the blight doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the blight's turns, the target loses 8 ({@damage 2d6 + 1}) hit points due to blood loss.

entries.name: Blight
entries: The influence of a Gulthias tree corrupts all it touches as it spreads through a woodland, giving birth to the wretched creatures known as blights. However, what happens when this corruption spreads into the fields and gardens of mortals? Thus are born the vegetable blights, horrific fruits and gourds that thirst for blood.

During the day, a melon blight looks like a large cantaloupe or watermelon. However, when night falls it lifts itself up from the earth on twisting vines to roam in search of prey. When dawn arrives, the melon blight returns to its patch repulsively swollen with blood.

entries.name: Blood Bag
entries: melon blight has a grotesque symbiotic relationship with undead and other blights. It can attach long tendrils to these creature to pump empowering blood into them, causing them to regenerate from otherwise fatal wounds. Only fire can stay this effect.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the blight remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a pumpkin.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: When the blight dies, it explodes in a 15-foot radius burst of blood and pulp. All blights and undead within this radius recover 15 hit points and gain advantage on attack rolls for 1 minute.

action.name: Blood Drain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) piercing damage, plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage, and the blight recovers hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

entries.name: Blight
entries: The influence of a Gulthias tree corrupts all it touches as it spreads through a woodland, giving birth to the wretched creatures known as blights. However, what happens when this corruption spreads into the fields and gardens of mortals? Thus are born the vegetable blights, horrific fruits and gourds that thirst for blood.

Until it starts moving, a pumpkin blight appears to simply be an award winning pumpkin. However, when called by its thirst for blood, this monstrous gourd roams the night on tottering vines, its jagged, slavering maw dripping slimy pulp. These monsters gleefully devour beasts and humanoids alike, draining them of their blood to fill its ever swelling body. Most repulsive of all, though, is the explosion of gore and pulp the results from their deaths, empowering undead and other blights around them with strength and vitality.

monster.name: Dearg-due
languages: the languages it knew in life

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: If the dearg-due isn't in sunlight or running water, it can use its action to polymorph into a Medium cloud of mist, or back into its true form. While in mist form, the dearg-due can't take any actions, speak, or manipulate objects. It is weightless, has a flying speed of 20 feet, can hover, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. In addition, if air can pass through a space, the mist can do so without squeezing, and it can't pass through water. It has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and it is immune to all nonmagical damage, except the damage it takes from sunlight.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the dearg-due fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The dearg-due regains 20 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the dearg-due takes radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the dearg-due's next turn.

trait.name: Dearg-due Weaknesses
entries: The dearg-due has the following flaws:

items: {@b Forbiddance.} The dearg-due can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.
{@b Sentimentality.} If bound with rose vines, the deargdue takes 20 acid damage at the start of its turn and cannot take on its mist shape or sing.

{@b Stones Upon the Grave.} If a stone weighing 10 pounds or more is placed on the dearg-due's chest or on top of its resting place while the dearg-due is {@condition incapacitated} in it, the dearg-due is {@condition paralyzed} until the stone is removed.
{@b Sunlight Hypersensitivity.} The dearg-due takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dearg-due makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite attack or a Gasping Kiss.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. Instead of dealing damage, the dearg-due can grapple the target (escape {@dc 17}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the dearg-due regains hit points equal to that amount. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. A humanoid slain in this way and then buried in the ground rises the following night as a vampire spawn under the dearg-due's control.

action.name: Gasping Kiss {@recharge 5}
entries: The dearg-due touches one creature it can see within 5 feet of it that is either willing, {@condition grappled} by the dearg-due, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) acid damage. On a failure, it also runs out of breath and can't speak for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Alluring Song
entries: The dearg-due sings a magical melody. Every humanoid and giant within 300 feet of the deargdue that can hear the song must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the song ends. The dearg-due must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the dearg-due is {@condition incapacitated}.

While {@condition charmed} by the dearg-due, a target regards the dearg-due as a trusted friend to be heeded and protected. Although the target isn't under the deargdue's control, it takes the dearg-due's requests or actions in the most favorable way it can. Whenever a target takes damage from a source other than the dearg-due, a target can repeat the saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it.

A target that successfully saves is immune to this dearg-due's song for the next 24 hours. However, if a target remains {@condition charmed} for 5 continuous minutes, it is {@condition charmed} for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The dearg-due moves up to its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: The dearg-due makes one unarmed strike.

legendary.name: Deadly Touch (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The dearg-due makes one bite attack or gasping kiss.

A dearg-due is a vampire touched by the Feywild. Existing in a constant state of yearning hunger, a dearg-due craves food, love, breath, all the pleasures of the flesh denied to it by its undeath. They lurk among the mists, craving a warmth that they cannot have.

entries.name: Born From Tragedy
entries: Once, there was a peasant girl who loved a peasant boy with all her heart, as he loved her. However, the girl's father sold her as a bride to a wealthy man for a hefty price, for she was also beautiful and beloved by the town. The rich man was cruel, and soon she fell into despair and began to starve herself. In her dark dreams she cried out in despair and rage, and her cries were heard by the Prince of Hearts, the archfey of passion. Her story moved him, and he granted her the curse of undeath so that she might visit her vengeance upon her cruel husband and her greedy father. Her bloodlust could not be quenched, though, and soon her wrath was unleashed on the entire town. It was not until her true love struck her down that the bloodshed finally ended.

entries.name: Yearning
entries: A dearg-due may spontaneously form when a person starved of both food and love succumbs to despair and yearns to enact vengeance on those who wronged them. From that moment, they seek to feed the bottomless desire for companionship and comfort that eats away at them. They sing their yearning songs to lure their victims into their deadly embrace before stealing their breath with their kiss and draining them of blood. However, they remain eternally unsatisfied and will continue to desperately try to quench their craving. Only roses can restrain them in their frenzy, as the touch of roses is painful to the dearg-due.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A dearg-due does not require air.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region surrounding a dearg-due's is warped by the creature's unnatural presence, creating any of the following effects:

items: Bloodthorn plants may grow unexpectedly within the area.
Plants within 500 feet of the lair wither, and their stems and branches become twisted and thorny.
Shadows cast within 500 feet of the lair seem abnormally gaunt and sometimes move as though alive.
A creeping fog clings to the ground within 500 feet of the vampire's lair. The fog occasionally takes eerie forms, such as grasping claws and writhing serpents.

entries: If the dearg-due is destroyed, these effect fade within {@dice 2d6} days.

entries.name: Bloodthorns
entries: Also known as the vampire rose, bloodthorn appears to be a normal bush of white roses at first glance. However, this lovely appearance disguises the bloodthorn's vampiric hunger. Disguised as a rosebush, it ensnares unsuspecting victims and drains them of their fluids, turning its white roses blood red.

A 5-foot by 5-foot by 5-foot patch of bloodthorn has AC 11, 25 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage, and immunity to lightning, poison, and psychic damage. The bloodthorn emits a hypnotic fragrance which enfeebles those that smell it. Any creatures within 5 feet of the bloodthorn with a sense of smell that are not constructs or undead have disadvantage on Strength saving throws and ability checks.

If a warm blooded creature moves within 5 feet of the bloodhthorn, the bloodthorn lashes out with its thorny vines, making a melee weapon attack at {@hit 5}. If the attack succeeds, the target becomes restrained by the thorny vines. While restrained by these vines, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage and 5 ({@damage 2d4}) necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns, and the bloodthorn recovers hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

A creature restrained by the vines or one that can touch the creature can use its action to make a {@dc 13} Strength check. On a success, the target is freed. Alternatively, if the bloodthorn takes 10 slashing damage in one turn, a creature can be freed from it. If any portion of a vampire rose is successfully severed while it drains a victim’s blood, the flower lets out a horrifying shriek and blood sprays out of the cut stalk.

A bloodthorn bush has {@dice 4d6} white flowers. For every 5 points of necrotic damage it deals, one of its flowers turns red. Once all its flowers are red, the bloodthorn becomes passive for one week, during which time it ceases to emit its hypnotic fragrance and will not attempt to ensnare new victims.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The briarwitch dryad's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Curse of Thorns
entries: Plant-life surrounding the dryad is filled with thorns and sharp branches. For every 5 feet of movement a creature expends to move through an area occupied by thick vegetation within 60 feet of the dryad, it takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) slashing damage. A creature currently {@condition restrained} by plant-life within 60 feet of the dryad takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage at the start of its turn. This does not stack with damage from pre-existing thorns.

trait.name: Green Step
entries: Once on its turn, the dryad can use 10 feet of its movement to step magically into one living tree within its reach or area of thick vegetation that it occupies and emerge from a second living tree or area of thick vegetation within 60 feet of the first tree, appearing in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the second tree or within the area of thick vegetation. For the purposes of this effect, a tree must be Large or bigger and an area of thick vegetation much occupy a 5-foot square an impose a movement penalty.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The briarwitch dryad has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Thorny Body
entries: At the start of each of its turns, the dryad deals 5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage to any creature grappling it.

trait.name: Undergrowth Stride
entries: The dryad ignores movement restrictions created by plantlife, including that created by {@spell plant growth}, ignores damage from thorns, including from {@spell wall of thorns}, and cannot be pushed, pulled, or {@condition restrained} by vines or other plantlife, such as with {@spell thorn whip} or {@spell entangle}. Additionally, ranged and reach attacks that she makes can pass through areas of heavy undergrowth unimpeded, including through a {@i wall of thorns}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dryad makes two unarmed strikes. In place of one of its unarmed strikes, the dryad can cast an at will spell.

action.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fey Charm
entries: The dryad targets one humanoid or beast that it can see within 30 feet of itself. If the target can see the dryad, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed}. The {@condition charmed} creature regards the dryad as someone to be feared and obeyed. The target isn't under the dryad's control, though the dryad has advantage on {@skill Persuasion} and {@skill Intimidation} checks made against the target.

Each time the dryad or its allies do anything harmful to the target, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Otherwise, the effect lasts 24 hours or until the dryad dies, is on a different plane of existence from the target, or ends the effect as a bonus action. If a target's saving throw is successful, the target is immune to the dryad's Fey Charm for the next 24 hours.
The dryad can have no more than three humanoids and up to ten beasts {@condition charmed} at a time.

Dryads are spirits of woodlands, of the realms of green twilight that mortalkind may not tread. They live amid seclusion and beauty, and though they are lovely themselves, they are dangerous and not to be trifled with.

Some dryads may take on the role of guardians of their forests. Enraged by the constant depredations of hunters and loggers, these dryads seek out the dark hidden hearts of their forests, finding in its shadowy depths the magic and cunning needed to defend their realms from the destructive touch of mortals. These are the thorn ringed briarwitches, whose forests are known as cursed, haunted places.

entries.name: Witchkin
entries: A briarwitch's magic is similar to that of hags in many ways. For starters, a briarwitch can join a coven with hags. A briarwitch dryad that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) and has a challenge rating of 10 (3,900 XP). The briarwitch can also create weird magic items such as those described in {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters}.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rhyzalich dryad's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Necrotic Tree Stride
entries: Once on its turn, the rhyzalich dryad can use 10 feet of movement to step magically into one living tree within reach and emerge from a second living tree within 60 feet of the first tree, appearing in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the second tree. Both trees must be Large or bigger. In the process, both trees take 15 necrotic damage and the dryad regains 30 hit points.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The rhyzalich dryad regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the rhyzalich dryad takes fire or radiant damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the rhyzalich dryad's next turn. The rhyzalich dryad dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: When reduced to 0 hit points, the dryad crumbles into dead leaves. If its phylactery tree remains alive, the dryad gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body regrows from fungi and dead plant matter within 5 feet of the phylactery tree.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the rhyzalich dryad fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rhyzalich dryad has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The rhyzalich dryad has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

action.name: Rotting Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) necrotic damage and the dryad recovers hit points equal to the amount of necrotic damage dealt. Additionally, the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. Plant creatures take maximum damage from this attack.

A humanoid slain by this attack rises 24 hours later as a {@creature zombie} under the dryad's control, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed. If the creature has 5 or more hit dice, it is instead animated as a {@creature ghoul}.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: The dryad covers itself and anything it is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes it look like another creature of its general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if the dryad takes a bonus action to end it or if it dies.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, the dryad could appear to have smooth skin, but someone touching it would feel its rough lichen. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern that the dryad is disguised.

action.name: Spore Kiss (3/Day)
entries: The dryad touches one {@condition restrained} or {@condition incapacitated} humanoid, beast, fey, or plant within 5 feet of it, infiltrating its body with spores. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw against this magic or become infected with a disease for the next 24 hours. While infected in this way, the creature is {@condition charmed} by the dryad and can't be reinfected by these spores. Although the target isn't under the dryad's control, it takes the dryad's requests or actions in the most favorable way it can.

legendary.name: Pacify
entries: The rhyzalich dryad casts {@spell hold person}.

legendary.name: Exert Will
entries: One creature {@condition charmed} by the rhyzalich dryad that it can see must use its {@action reaction} to move up to its speed as she directs or to make a weapon attack against a target that she designates.

legendary.name: Rotting Touch (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The rhyzalich dryad uses Rotting Touch.

entries.name: Dryads
entries: Dryads are spirits of woodlands, of the realms of green twilight that mortalkind may not tread. They live amid seclusion and beauty, and though they are lovely themselves, they are dangerous and not to be trifled with.

Beneath the soil of every forest is an intricate network of fungal filaments, connecting together every tree, bush, and flower into a single cohesive whole. These fibers draw nutrients from the decaying matter in the soil, supplying them to all the plants of the forest, continuing the cycle of life and death that keeps a forest enduring eternal. However, this unifying network can be abused. As a dryad approaches the end of their life, they may find themselves overcome with fear of death. Unwilling to return to the soil from which they were born, they choose to instead harness the network of fungi within that soil for their own dark purposes, becoming a rhyzalich dryad.

entries.name: Hunger for Life
entries: Through dark rituals, a dryad can imbue itself and the tree it calls its home with fungi to create a dark symbiosis of life and death. This ritual twists the nature of the fungi that already suffuses the soil, harnessing them to drain all life and vitality from the soil and surrounding trees to prolong the dryad's existence. Over many centuries the dryad's forest withers away as all life is drained from the soil. Eventually, nothing will be left beyond a withered tree at the center of a barren field of sickly fungi.

entries.name: The Rhyzalich Dryad's Grove
entries: The rhyzalich dryad's lair is its grove, or what remains of it. Located at the center of a gradually spreading blight of infection on the forest's face, the dryad's grove is a place of sickened plant-life and poisonous fungi.

entries.name: The Rhyzalich Dryad's Tree
entries: The heart of the rhyzalich dryad's grove is its tree. The tree is a Huge plant with the following statistics:

items: {@b Armor Class:} 16
{@b Hit Points:} 75
{@b Damage Threshold:} 10
{@b Damage Immunities:} necrotic, poison, psychic
{@b Damage Resistances:} piercing
{@b Damage Vulnerabilities:} fire

{@b Regeneration.} The tree recovers 10 hit points on initiative count 20 of each round. If the tree had taken fire or radiant damage in the previous round, this trait doesn't function. The tree dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The aorial's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The aorial has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: The aorial takes 5 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Poison Spray
entries: The aorial projects a puff of noxious gas at a creature within 10 feet of it. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 3d12}) poison damage.

action.name: Whispering Wind
entries: The aorial begins whispering hateful words. Any sleeping creatures within 10 feet of it can hear the whispering in their dreams for as long as the whispering persists, causing its dreams to become unsettling and filled with dread. If this effect persists for at least 1 hour, the target gains no benefit from its rest, and it suffers a -1 penalty to all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until it takes another long rest. A {@spell protection from evil and good} spell cast on the target prevents this contact, as does a {@spell magic circle}.

action.name: Mist Form
entries: If the aorial isn't in sunlight, it can use its action to polymorph into a Small cloud of mist or back into its true form.

While in mist form, the aorial can't take any actions, speak, or manipulate objects. It is weightless, has a flying speed of 20 feet, can hover, and can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. In addition, if air can pass through a space, the mist can do so without squeezing, and it can't pass through water. It has advantage on Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution saving throws, and it is immune to all nonmagical damage, except the damage it takes from sunlight.

Fairies are the small folk of the fey realms. Encompassing pixies, sprites, and other diminutive spirits, fairies are expressions of mischief and the natural world. The best of their ilk tend to nature diligently, helping the seasons pass, over seeing the movement of winds and rivers, and protecting wild animals from undue harm while simultaneously playing harmless pranks on any who cross them. However, many fairies become corrupted, either by a taint in the land or by their own dark hearts, and become evil expressions of the cruel humor of nature.

These hateful fairies, also known as mist sylphs, have dragonfly wings that buzz with a harsh staccato when they fly. It's said that the first aorials were servants of the Queen of Air and Darkness whose tongues were too loose about the Gloaming Queen's secrets. As punishment, she made it so that their wings would buzz harshly whenever they flew, letting all around know that they were being spied on, and made the sun a deadly enemy to them. Now these cruel fey buzz through the night time world, spreading vicious whispers and hateful lies.

entries.name: They Come With the Fog
entries: Aorials emerge with the mist, as their ability to transform into wisps of vapor allows them to effortlessly disguise themselves in fogbanks. However, they move slowly while in mist form and can neither speak nor cast spells, meaning that they must return to their physical forms if they want to spread the misery that they so love. Aorials love to spy on mortals, listening in on private conversations and underhanded dealings to gather information. Once their victims fall asleep, the aorials then infiltrate their homes so that they may implant both true gossip and foul lies into their dreams. These victims wake ill rested the following morning, irritable and plagued by half remembered dreams and a vague suspicion that someone close has been lying to them.

action.name: Spear (Bite in Beast Form)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Magic Hand
entries: The bevhensie targets a creature or unattended object within 10 feet of it with a spectral, floating hand. A creature must be Medium or smaller to be affected by this magic, and an object can weigh up to 10 pounds. If the creature fails on a {@dc 10} Strength saving throw, it is pushed 1 foot away from the bevhensie. If the target is an object, the bevhensie can manipulate it as if with a mage hand spell with a range of 10 feet.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The bevhensie magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks, casts a spell, or begins laughing, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the bevhensie wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

action.name: Shapechange
entries: The bevhensie can polymorph into a beast form that resembles a weasel (speed 30 ft.), a snake (30 ft., climb 30 ft.), or a frog (40 ft., swim 40 ft.), or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in each form, except for the speed changes noted. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

reaction.name: Cruel Laughter (1/Day)
entries: When a creature within 30 feet of the bevhensie fails an attack roll, a saving throw, or otherwise experiences misfortune, the bevhensie begins laughing hysterically for up to 1 minute, during which time it is {@condition incapacitated}. It can stop laughing as an action.

All creatures with an Intelligence score of 5 or more within 30 feet of the bevhensie that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw or begin laughing uncontrollably for as long as the bevhensie continues laughing. The creature falls {@condition prone}, becoming {@condition incapacitated} and unable to stand up for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, and each time it takes damage, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. The target has advantage on the saving throw if it's triggered by damage. On a success, the effect ends.

The bevhensie are descendants of a clan of sprites who had the audacity to laugh at Titania herself. As punishment, she banished them from their homelands and revoked their status. Plagued by bitterness and wanting revenge, they pleaded for help from Baba Yaga. Finding their plight amusing and their audacity delightful, Baba Yaga granted them the power to spread misery through their magic and laughter. Now the bevhensie exist as nomads, spending their days traveling the world and causing misfortune for all they encounter.

entries.name: Vain
entries: The bevhensie still retain their love of finery from when they resided in the Summer Court, favoring garish clothing in ostentatious shades of red, green, and blue. However, when they wish to avoid notice they can transform into the shape of a weasel, a tree snake, or a frog, though their forms always possess the same bold colors that they favor. They often take these forms when acting as the familiar for witches, which are among the only creatures that they show any respect for in deference to the boon granted to them by Baba Yaga.

entries.name: Thoughtless Cruelty
entries: Bevhensie take extreme pleasure in spreading misery. They love to arrange accidents and misfortunes to befall creatures, the more tragic and gruesome the better. A bevhensie likes nothing better than pushing an elderly grandmother down a flight of stairs or dropping a heavy book on the head of a child. Most horrific of all, the hysterical laughter of the bevhensie magically compells all around it to join in, prompting the loved ones of the poor injured soul to fall into raucous fits of laughter at the sight of their terrible misfortune.

entries.name: Variant: Bevhensie Familiar
entries: Bevhensie have no loyalty to any creature but themselves and love to see everyone fail, including their own master, making them poor familiars to any creatures that are not witches. However, a spellcaster may wind up with a bevhensie familiar through an arcane accident or by the whims of a patron with a dark sense of humor. These fairies will serve their masters loyally for as long as doing so amuses them, but eventually they will grow bored and seek out new entertainment. To witches and hags, however, they show a greater degree of respect.

{@b Familiar.} The bevhensie can serve another creature as a familiar, forming a telepathic bond with its willing master. While the two are bonded, the master can sense what the bevhensie senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other. At any time and for any reason, the bevhensie can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

monster.name: Boowray
languages: Sylvan and the primary language of the creature it is bound to

trait.name: Willful
entries: The boowray is immune to any effects that would control its mind or behavior, such as the {@spell command} and {@spell suggestion} spells.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The boowray can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The boowray has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bond to Victim
entries: The boowray binds itself to a humanoid creature within 5 feet of fit. The boowray remains bound to the creature until it is on a different plane of existence from the target, ends the effect as a bonus action, binds itself to another creature, or the bond is broken with a {@spell dispel evil and good} spell. While bound to a creature, the boowray understands and speaks the creature's primary language, can sense its emotional state and knows the direction and distance to the creature.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The boowray magically turns {@condition invisible} until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the pixie wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

action.name: Whisper
entries: The boowary whispers a message to a creature within 120 feet of it. The target (and only the target) hears the message and can reply in a whisper that only the boowray can hear.

The boowray must have line of sight to the target unless the target is a creature that the boowray is bonded to, in which case this message can be transmitted through solid objects. Magical silence, 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, a thin sheet of lead, or 3 feet of wood blocks the message.

The boowray is an incorporeal fairy with green, translucent flesh, bright yellow eyes, and leaves for hair, surrounded by the sharp smells of herbs such as parsley, rosemary, or mint. Though it appears harmless, it is in actuality an evil spirit of the land that delights in corrupting the innocent and inspiring good folk to evil actions. Once it chooses a victim, it whispers wicked advice into their ear, slowly turning them towards evil acts.

entries.name: Tithe Child
entries: Every seven years, the Summer Court must pay a tithe to Hell in the form of seven fair souls. When these souls are sacrificed, boowray are born from where the flames of Hell touch the fertile earth of the Feywild. Though not innately beholden to Hell, the boowray still possess the innate desire to corrupt the souls of all that they meet, which makes them very useful allies to devils, succubi, night hags, and other entities of the Lower Planes that seek to corrupt goodness.

entries.name: Helpful at First
entries: When a boowray selects a victim, they magically bond themselves to their target. They then follow the target, magically whispering helpful advice into the creature's ear under the guise of a guardian spirit or other benevolent entity. Once they have earned their victim's trust, they begin to prey upon that victim's weaknesses, feeding into their resentment, jealousy, greed, pride, or whatever flaw the creature possesses, compelling them to gradually become the worst version of themselves.

entries.name: People of the Land
entries: A boowray does not pursue the corruption of its victims solely for the sake of mischief. When a creature that a boowray has corrupted eventually dies, a new brood of boowray are born from its rotting corpse. These boowray settle in the land that they were born in, becoming guardians of the earth and corrupters of mortals. These fairies get along well with other fairies, bearing no enmity to them, and will likely join their communities.

entries.name: Variant: Boowray Familiar
entries: Boowray can be found in the service to mortal spellcasters, acting as advisors, spies, and familiars. A boowray urges its master to acts of evil. Boowrays may be granted to a mortal in service to an evil archfey, but some devils have garnered the loyalty of these infernally touched creatures, enabling them to bestow them to servants that please them or that they deem more susceptible to deception from an innocent seeming fairy.

{@b Familiar.} The boowray can serve another creature as a familiar, forming a telepathic bond with its willing master. While the two are bonded, the master can sense what the boowray senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other. While the boowray is within 10 feet of its master, the master shares the boowray's Magic Resistance trait. At any time and for any reason, the boowray can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

ac.condition: acts as a {@item studded leather armor|phb}

trait.name: Thorny Hide
entries: Any creature that tries to grab the terropo without its permission is automatically hit as if with the terropo's Thorn Javelin attack unless wearing thick gloves.

action.name: Thorn Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage in melee, or at range, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. If its saving throw result is 5 or lower, the {@condition poisoned} target falls {@condition unconscious} for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

action.name: Conjure Spirit Mount
entries: The terropo summons a fey spirit to act as a mount in a space within 5 feet of the terropo. The mount is a fey and uses the stats of one of the following creatures: bat, cat, frog (toad), hawk, lizard, owl, rat, raven, or weasel. The mount obeys orders given to it by the terropo and cannot be {@condition charmed}, acts on the terropo's initiative, and disappears if more than 5 feet away from the terropo. The terropo can use the senses of its mount as its own. The terropo can use its action to dismiss its mount or change its shape into one of the other forms it could take.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The terropo magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the terropo wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it. If the terropo is riding a mount that it has summoned with its Conjure Spirit Mount action, the mount also becomes invisibile.

The terropo are a mean spirited off shoot of sprites. They are tiny, rough skinned peoples with long, pointed fingers and toes, but their most distinguishing features are a brace of bony spines sprouting from their backs where sprites would have their wings. These spines produce the same venom that sprites coat their weapons in and can be removed and used like javelins, growing back within just a few hours. With the thorn armor that they wear further accentuating their spines, the terropo are a fierce and deadly foe of intruders into their realms.

entries.name: Ancient Failure
entries: Long ago, a tribe of sprites were charged with the protection of the Queen of Air and Darkness's pet fawn, a task which they failed in. The Gloaming Queen was furious, and to preserve the honor of the tribe their chieftain offered her life. Standing before the Queen of Air and Darkness she tore her own wings from her body and drank the poison that her people brew to defend their lands. Impressed by this display of self-sacrifice, the Gloaming Queen saved the chieftain's life and declared that she and her people would be responsible for the small beasts of the world henceforth. Thus they became the terropo.

entries.name: Protectors of the Small
entries: The terropo are responsible for the protection of all small creatures throughout the woods in which they live, and it is their duty to drive away hunters and monsters that would despoil their homes. Lacking wings, they are aided in this by the spirit mounts they can conjure, extensions of the terropo's soul which can take the form of small beasts. The terropo ride these spirit mounts in pursuit of any creature that would dare intrude on their territory, setting gruesome traps and using the bones of past intruders to build their homes.

trait.name: Aura of Moonlight
entries: The fenhound sheds dim light in a 30-foot radius. Any creatures within this area cannot benefit from invisibility, and if it is transformed or disguised by illusion magic its true form is revealed while within the light.

trait.name: Ethereal Jaunt
entries: As a bonus action, the fenhound can magically shift from the Material Plane to the Ethereal Plane, or vice versa.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The fenhound has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The fenhound's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The fenhound has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the fenhound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Supernatural Hearing and Smell
entries: The fenhound has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell, and these senses extend 60 feet into the Ethereal Plane when it is on a coterminous plane, and vice versa. Additionally, the hound can detect if a creature has committed an evil act within the last week.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: If the fenhound is killed, it disappears in a 10-foot radius burst of glittering dust. Any creature touched by this dust becomes marked for one year. While marked, all fenhounds within 100 miles of the creature are aware of it and can track it without fail.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) psychic damage if the target is evil or has committed an evil act within the last week.

Fenhounds are a rare and mysterious breed of fey. They appear as huge, powerfully built mastiffs enveloped in an eerie pale yellow nimbus of moonlight. They roam the nights during full moons to hunt down evil-doers. Their origins are not well understood. Some say that they are born from the land itself when it can no longer tolerate the weight of the sins that stain it. Others believe that they are created from moonlight by the elven god Shevarash to punish wickedness. Yet more posit that they were bred by the celestial archfey Vaeros from blink dog and yeth hound stock to combat evil done in the dark. All that is known for certain is that they are implacable foes any that would commit acts of cruelty under cover of night.

entries.name: Moonlight
entries: Fenhounds despise all evil-doers and they possess the ability to track the scent of creatures that have committed sins recently, pursuing them relentlessly until their quarry succumbs to exhaustion and their merciless jaws. Evil creatures cannot hide from a fenhound as their noses can detect sin, while invisibility and illusion magic are revealed by the auras of gentle moonlight they produce. Even traveling into the ethereal plane cannot save a fenhound's quarry from them, as they possess the ability to step into the ethereal plane at will. As such, fenhounds are especially hated by night hags, and Cegilune has a standing reward for the heads of slaughtered fenhounds.

entries.name: Savage Justice
entries: Fenhounds do not care about whether a creature is good or evil. They only care about punishing sinners. When the full moon rises, fenhounds hunt down the creature that has committed the most egregious sin that they can find, hunting them without mercy. Fleeing a pack of fenhounds is all but hopeless, but fighting one is even worse, for those that slay a fenhound become marked for the next year, doomed to be hunted by baying hounds whenever the full moon graces the sky.

monster.name: Filth Son

immune.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Berserk
entries: Whenever the filth son starts its turn with 50 hit points or fewer, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 6, the filth son goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the filth son attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the filth son attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the filth son goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

The filth son's creator, if within 60 feet of the berserk filth son, can try to calm it by speaking firmly and persuasively. The filth son must be able to hear its creator, who must take an action to make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. If the check succeeds, the filth son ceases being berserk. If it takes damage while still at 50 hit points or fewer, the filth son might go berserk again.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The filth son has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The filth son's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Poison Absorption
entries: Whenever the filth son is subjected to poison damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the poison damage dealt.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the filth son must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the filth son's stench for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The filth son makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

A filth son is one of the most disgusting creations ever devised by hag kind. A lumbering construct the size of a troll made of twigs, mud, moldy clothes, dung, and rotten bones, a filth son is a walking, stinking heap of foulness. These repulsive monstrosities are parodies of golems, made of constantly decaying refuse rather than the immutable mater of a golem, requiring frequent repairs. Most wretched of all, however, is that the filth son is animated not with an elemental spirit, but rather with the trapped spirit of a mortal. Denied their rightful afterlife and imprisoned in a rotting, stinking shell, these spirits invariably go mad, able only to obey their hag mothers with unthinking devotion.

resist.note: damage from non-magical attacks not made with silvered weapons

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The feral yowler has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The feral yowler can use its yowl of fear if available. It can then make two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Yowl of Fear {@recharge 6}
entries: The feral yowler bays magically. Every enemy within 300 feet of the hound that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of the yowler's next turn or until the hound is {@condition incapacitated}. A {@condition frightened} target that starts its turn within 30 feet of the yowler must use all its movement on that turn to get as far from the yowler as possible, must finish the move before taking an action, and must take the most direct route, even if hazards lie that way. A target that successfully saves is immune to the yowling of all feral yowlers for the next 24 hours.

bonus.name: Displacement (Recharges After a Long or Short Rest)
entries: The feral yowler begins projecting a magical illusion that makes it appear to be standing near its actual location, causing attack rolls against it to have disadvantage. If it is hit by an attack, this trait is disrupted until the end of its next turn. This effect lasts for up to 1 minute or until the feral yowler is {@condition incapacitated}, its speed is reduced to 0, it is exposed to sunlight, or its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell).

A feral yowler looks like a muscular panther devoid of hair, with paper thin skin marred by wretched sores. Though possessing a terrible grace, pain is clearly etched in their every movement, and cruelty drips from their swollen fangs. They roam dark places across the planes in hunt of prey to satisfy their unending desire for cruelty.

entries.name: An Eye for an Eye, a Hound for a Hound
entries: Long ago, there was a powerful archfey named Mastiphal who was renown for his hunting prowess. He boasted that his displacer beasts could out hunt even the yeth hounds of the Queen of Air and Darkness herself. Hearing of this boast, the Gloaming Queen challenged this archfey to the Wild Hunt. However, just as her hounds were about to claim victory, the deceitful Mastiphal shot them with a poisoned arrow and claimed victory.

Enraged by this treachery and despondent over the death of her prized hounds, the Queen of Air and Darkness committed a blasphemy which she still pays for even today. She wrenched the dying souls of her yeth hounds from their bodies and plunged them into the flayed bodies of Mastiphal's prized displacer beasts, and with abominable necromancy she fused them into one unholy whole, which promptly set upon their master, tearing him to shreds. These wretched monsters, twisted by dark magic, in eternal pain, and unable to die, still roam the Feywild masterless and without reprieve.

entries.name: Foul Crossbreed
entries: A feral yowler shows its tragic lineage in the powers that it retains from both parents. Its wild, unholy yowling fills those that hear it with fear, and it possesses the ability to momentarily displace an image of itself to confuse its enemies. Additionally, the necromantic power used to create it renders it immune to many of the powers of undeath itself. Though they cannot breed true, many death cults, necromancers, and hags have discovered the secrets of creating more of these poor beasts, ensuring that some always roam the Feywild, no matter how much the hunters of the Seelie and Unseelie Courts alike try to wipe them out.

monster.name: Gruesome Lurker
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting (Psionics)
headerEntries: The lurker's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Distort Body
entries: The lurker can fit its body into any space that a Small creature could fit through without squeezing.

trait.name: Psychic Defense
entries: The lurker's AC includes its Wisdom modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lurker makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) slashing damage. Instead of dealing damage, it can grapple the target if the target is {@condition frightened} (escape {@dc 10}). The lurker can't make attacks while grappling a creature.

action.name: Shadow Jump {@recharge 5}
entries: The lurker, any equipment it is wearing or carrying, and any creature it is grappling teleport to an unoccupied space within 60 feet of it, provided that the starting space and the destination are in dim light or darkness. The destination need not be within line of sight.

A gruesome lurker is a dangerous variety of scarecrow empowered with psionic abilities by means of the desiccated head of a mortal kept within it. Taller than a common scarecrow, a gruesome lurker towers at a lanky 9 feet tall. These monsters use their psionic powers and disturbing ability to contort their lanky bodies to terrify their victims before grabbing them and pulling them into the shadows to feed on their fear.

entries.name: Rare Ritual
entries: Crafting a gruesome lurker is no small undertaking. A suitably intelligent victim must be found first, one whose desiccated brain will be powerful enough to grant the lurker its psionic abilities. Then the lurker must be constructed, a process which necessitates many strange techniques and exotic material like meenlock guts and shadar-kai blood. Finally, a strong enough dark spirit must be bound to the body to empower it, a task not for the faint of heart. Though the rituals are hard to discover, many hags, witches, and evil druids know how to construct these sadistic monsters to do their dark bidding.

monster.name: Grandmother Griselda

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Griselda's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

1e: {@spell dominate monster} ({@i against an evil-aligned creature only})

trait.name: Book of Vile Darkness
entries: Grandmother Griselda is attuned to the book of vile darkness. While within 10 feet of the book, creatures with a challenge rating of 0, as well as plants that aren't creatures, drop to 0 hit points, potions are diluted and become non-magical, and holy water is destroyed. Additionally, while the book is on her person, she can cast the spells in her Innate Spellcasting marked with a tilde (~).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Griselda fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: Griselda can mimic animal sounds and humanoid voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 18} Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If she has a phylactery, Griselda gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the phylactery.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Griselda has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Weird Magic: Tick Tock Clock
entries: Griselda keeps a magic clock in the cavity in her chest left by her heart, which continually ticks and must be periodically wound up again. The ticking of this clock imposes disadvantage on Griselda's Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks. If Griselda dies or fails to rewind the clock, the clock shatters and casts {@spell circle of death} ({@dc 18}) centered on itself.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: Griselda covers herself and anything she is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes her look like another creature of her general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if Griselda takes a bonus action to end it or if she dies.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, Griselda could appear to have smooth skin, but someone touching her would feel her rough flesh. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 20} Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to discern that Griselda is disguised.

action.name: Invisible Passage
entries: Griselda magically turns {@condition invisible} until she attacks or casts a spell, or until her concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). While {@condition invisible}, she leaves no physical evidence of her passage, so she can be tracked only by magic. Any equipment she wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with her.

bonus.name: Shriek (1/Day)
entries: Griselda releases a furious shriek, provided that she isn't in sunlight. This shriek has no effect on constructs, undead, and other hags. All other creatures within 30 feet of her that can hear her must make a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw. On a failure, a creature has disadvantage on saving throws against effects that Griselda creates for 1 minute.

bonus.name: Wraithfom
entries: Griselda magically transforms into an incorporeal, wraith-like form, or back into her physical form. Any equipment she is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. In wraithform, Griselda gains the statistics of a {@creature specter}, but retains her hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma, as well as her Rejuvenation and Shriek traits.

legendaryHeader: Griselda can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Griselda regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Griselda makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Griselda hag casts {@spell bestow curse} ({@dc 18}).

legendary.name: Invisible Escape (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Griselda uses her Invisible Passage action.

Grandmother Griselda is an ancient {@creature green hag} who long ago discovered the {@item book of vile darkness}. With its foul knowledge she achieved lichdom and now seeks to steal the mantle of divinity from Vecna himself. To that end she is accruing a vast store of arcane knowledge in the wizard tower that she has claimed as her lair.

entries.name: Hidden Heart
entries: Griselda has secreted her phylactery away in the skull of a dracolich, the blue dragon Irrargos. This dragon sought the immortality of lichdom, but in his arrogance he did not realize that Griselda was binding him to her service in the process. Now Griselda has imprisoned him in a demiplane to protect her heart, leaving him with a meager hoard to count.

monster.name: Jack Around
languages: Sylvan and any one language (usually Common)

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The jack's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Deceptive Nature
entries: Until it shows its teeth, the jack appears to be humanoid. Even magic that would determine what type of creature it is detects it as a normal humanoid.

trait.name: Feign Enchantment
entries: If a jack is targeted by a spell from the enchantment school, it absorbs the magic, suffering no effects of the spell, learning the nature of the spell, and gaining a number of temporary hit points equal to twice the spell's level. However, all magical means of detection indicate that the jack is under the effects of the spell. Spells to detect the magic the target is affected by, such as {@spell identify}, indicate that the jack is under the effects of the spell. The caster of {@spell zone of truth} will detect the jack failing its saving throw. If targeted by {@spell dominate person}, the jack can choose to allow a telepathic link to be forged, which it can sever as a free action at any time. The jack may choose to behave as if it is under the influence of the spell, which can only be detected by a successful Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check contested by the jack's Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The jack makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target has disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage.

entries.name: Jacks
entries: Jacks are an especially mischievous variety of fey born from mortals. In its natural form, a jack is a formless spirit, roaming without a body through the Feywild and those realms touched by it. A jack comes into its own when it finds a suitable mortal vessel, which it possesses and molds to its own ends. Some jacks merely borrow a vessel's body for a night, others possess an unborn infant and twist its flesh to its own sinister ends. Humanoids that carry the spirit of a jack are evident by their strange powers and uncanny behavior.

The jack around is a conniving schemer and trickster that masquerades as a fool. Created when a jack spirit attaches itself to a humanoid filled with resentment towards those who consider themselves better than it, a jack around's ultimate goal is to create mischief and destroy the reputations of those who believe themselves better than them. In their day to day interactions, they appear humanoid in every way. However, when excited by the success of a plot or angered by the discovery of one of their deceptions, their mouths widen and fill with needle-like teeth capable of delivering a mind altering venom. Some jack arounds work for powerful fey that wish to place a destabilizing element in a city or royal court, while others simply cause mischief for the pleasure of it.

entries.name: Playing the Fool
entries: The jack around are not strong, so their greatest defense is misdirection. They play harmless, pathetic fools at every opportunity, affecting lisps and bizarre vocal tics to make themselves appear idiotic and engaging in pratfalls and buffoonery to appear clumsy. They use clothing or magic to disguise their rather distinctive mouths to avoid alarming people. Most cunning of all, a jack around is naturally immune to enchantment magic, and can pretend to fall victim to it in order to further its own goals.

trait.name: Deceptive Nature
entries: When not using its powers, the jack appears to be a normal humanoid.

trait.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The jolly jack can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Scepter
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become momentarily overcome with giggles, rendering it {@condition stunned} until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Cruel Joke
entries: The jack tells an insult filled joke at the expense of a creature that can hear it within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 4d4}) psychic damage and have disadvantage on all attack rolls it makes before the end of its next turn.

action.name: Unholy Jest {@recharge 6}
entries: The jack performs a prat fall or performs some other humorous action. All creatures with an Intelligence score of 5 or more within 30 feet of the jack that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or begin laughing uncontrollably. The creature falls {@condition prone}, becoming {@condition incapacitated} and unable to stand up for the duration. At the end of each of its turns, and each time it takes damage, the target can make another Wisdom saving throw. The target has advantage on the saving throw if it's triggered by damage. On a success, the effect ends. When the effect ends on it, the creature gains one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

reaction.name: Empathic Drain
entries: The jack targets one creature that is currently laughing or giggling within 30 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw. On a failure, the target's maximum hit points are reduced by 7 ({@damage 2d6}) and the jack recovers the same amount of hit points.

entries.name: Jacks
entries: Jacks are an especially mischievous variety of fey born from mortals. In its natural form, a jack is a formless spirit, roaming without a body through the Feywild and those realms touched by it. A jack comes into its own when it finds a suitable mortal vessel, which it possesses and molds to its own ends. Some jacks merely borrow a vessel's body for a night, others possess an unborn infant and twist its flesh to its own sinister ends. Humanoids that carry the spirit of a jack are evident by their strange powers and uncanny behavior.

A jolly jack is created when a jack spirit possesses a mortal who becomes convinced that all existence is one big cosmic joke. The idea that life has no meaning and, by extension, neither does death. That beauty and joy and sorrow are all just jokes that we play on ourselves. That ultimately there is no truth, that right and wrong are just lies, that good and evil are just words. That all concepts of meaning are just delusions, and only naive fools accept them. This embrace of nihilism opens the mind to an insidious spirit which infects a mortal, transforming them into a twisted sadist bent only on chaos.

entries.name: The Killing Joke
entries: In its day to day life, a jolly jack appears to be a normal mortal. However, when the urge for mischief overtakes them their skin becomes an unnatural bleached white, their mouths twist into a frightening rictus grin, and they don the clothes of a mad jester. They roam the streets in search of victims, performing pratfalls and telling cruel jokes that force those that hear them to laugh hysterically while the jack drains the life from their bodies. Their victims are left as withered husks, their faces twisted into grinning death masks.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the springheel jack is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the springheel jack instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Feather Fall
entries: So long as the springheel Jack is not {@condition restrained}, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition unconscious}, it takes no damage from falling any distance.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the springheel jack moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Springheel Leap
entries: The springheel Jack's long jump is up to 60 ft. and its high jump is up to 50 ft., with or without a running start, and creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attacks made on it when it jumps.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The springheel Jack's AC includes its Charisma modifier.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The springheel Jack can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fiery Spittle {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the springheel Jack's choice that is within 60 feet of the springheel Jack and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the springheel Jack's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Jacks
entries: Jacks are an especially mischievous variety of fey born from mortals. In its natural form, a jack is a formless spirit, roaming without a body through the Feywild and those realms touched by it. A jack comes into its own when it finds a suitable mortal vessel, which it possesses and molds to its own ends. Some jacks merely borrow a vessel's body for a night, others possess an unborn infant and twist its flesh to its own sinister ends. Humanoids that carry the spirit of a jack are evident by their strange powers and uncanny behavior.

High society is glamorous, filled with all the comforts of wealth. Those that sit at the very top, who control the monopolies and own the slums, make their money off the backs of the poor. They take and take and take without concern for the lives they ruin. From this nest of indolence and greed is born the spirit of the springheel jack, a living impulse of sociopathy that possesses the callous members of high society to compel them to kill the lower class for sport.

entries.name: The First Kill
entries: Possession takes time. It starts with the spirit simply whispering hatred into the back of the noble's mind. It isn't until the noble finally succumbs that the spirit can finally possess its target. Once possessed, the spirit transforms its host, making their appearance fiendish and cruel, causing their foreheads to sprout curved horns and their eyes to gleam with a cruel light. Those possessed by the spirit of the springheel jack will typically use magical spells and amulets to disguise their fiendish appearance. Interestingly, tieflings cannot be possessed by the spirit of the springheel jack, perhaps somehow due to their fiendish ancestry.

entries.name: Violence for Violence Sake
entries: The spirit of the springheel jack does not overtake the mind of its host. The possessed noble still has full agency of their actions. However, the power granted to them by the spirit residing in them reveals their true nature, drawing out the cruelty and bloodthirstiness already innate in their souls. The springheel jack is a killer without consequence. It can leap effortlessly out of melee and land without a scratch from any height. It can dodge fire and lightning as easily as it spits fire at the poor, allowing it to evade any attempt to stop its fun. Only silver can frighten a springheel jack, as it burns their skin at even just a touch. Observant visitors to the springheel's home will notice that no silver can be found anywhere in its house.

monster.name: Spryjack
languages: understands the languages of its host

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the jack is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the jack instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: As a bonus action, the jack can take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action or perform an action with its mage hand.

trait.name: Dissolve
entries: When the jack dies, its body dissolves into motes of psionic energy.

trait.name: Mage Hand Legerdemain (Psionics)
entries: The jack's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast {@spell mage hand}, requiring no components. The hand it creates is {@condition invisible}, and it can perform the following special actions with it:

items: The jack can stow one object the hand is holding in a container worn or carried by another creature.
The jack can retrieve an object in a container worn or carried by another creature.
The jack can use thieves' tools to pick lock and disarm traps at range.

entries: The jack can perform one of these tasks without being noticed by a creature if it succeeds on a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check contested by the creature's Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

trait.name: Host Bound
entries: The jack is bound to a single humanoid creature. Entering or exiting its host through its mouth takes an action. While the jack remains active outside of its host, its host cannot be woken up by any means. If the jack's host is killed, the jack immediately dies. If the jack is killed, its host is affected as if with the {@spell feeblemind} spell. The jack can only be safely removed from its host with a {@spell dispel evil and good} spell or similar magic. If the host's Intelligence is reduced to 1 while the jack is still inside of it, the jack starves to death in {@dice 1d4} days unless the stat is restored.

action.name: Multiattack
