entries: The springheel Jack can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Fiery Spittle {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the springheel Jack's choice that is within 60 feet of the springheel Jack and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the springheel Jack's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The jack makes two club attacks.

action.name: Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Swallow Treasure.
entries: The jack swallows one item it is currently holding, storing it in an extradimensional space. The jack can swallow an item up to two feet wide, and can hold up to 500 pounds, not exceeding a volume of 64 cubic feet. It can regurgitate an item in its stomach as an action.

If the jack's stomach contents are overloaded, or if it is killed, its contents are scattered in the Astral Plane. Breathing creatures inside the stomach can survive up to a number of minutes equal to 10 divided by the number of creatures (minimum 1 minute), after which time they begin to suffocate.

entries.name: Jacks
entries: Jacks are an especially mischievous variety of fey born from mortals. In its natural form, a jack is a formless spirit, roaming without a body through the Feywild and those realms touched by it. A jack comes into its own when it finds a suitable mortal vessel, which it possesses and molds to its own ends. Some jacks merely borrow a vessel's body for a night, others possess an unborn infant and twist its flesh to its own sinister ends. Humanoids that carry the spirit of a jack are evident by their strange powers and uncanny behavior.

A spryjack is a fey that is born when a jack spirit infects a person overcome with greed and envy. The spirit lodges itself into the chest of its host and grows into tiny, monkey-like fey about the size of a cat. These fey feed on the avarice and resentment of their host until strong enough to venture out, clambering out of their host's mouth at night to engage in theft, vandalism, and sabotage. Anything that their host desires, they desire. Anything that their host hates, they hate.

entries.name: Cunning Thief
entries: Spryjacks, despite their small size, are exceptionally good thieves. Tiny and quick, a spryjack's agility allows it to easily dodge many attacks, while their psionic powers enable them to acquire treasures or plant damning evidence without being noticed. Any items that they steal are stored in their stomachs to be enjoyed later. Even if captured, spryjacks possess surprising physical strength.

entries.name: Host Dependent
entries: A spryjack is entirely dependent on its host, and the attentive can even hear it if they press their ears to the host's chest. Lacking digestive systems, a spryjack does not need to eat so long as its host remains alive and thinking, though they die immediately if their host dies. This bond goes both ways, as if the spryjack dies, its host's mind is broken

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The bocanach can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bocanach makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage. If the bocanach hits the same target with two claw attacks in one turn, the bocanach can latch onto the target. While latched onto a target, the bocanach has a speed of 0, moves with the target, and can only make weapon attacks against that target. At the beginning of each of the target's turns, it must move up to its speed in a direction of the bocanach's choice. The bocanach can release a target at any time. The bocanach can be removed from a target by means of a {@spell protection from evil and good} spell or similar magic.

bonus.name: Howling Fury
entries: The bocanach begins producing a shrieking howl which is audible for 600 feet. All creatures within 120 feet of the bocanach that can hear it have advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls until the start of the bocanach's next turn. Additionally, when a creature that can hear the bocanach begins its turn, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become filled with supernatural rage until the start of its next turn. While enraged in this way, the creature has advantage on Strength saving throws and must use its action to make as many melee weapon attacks as possible.

reaction.name: Empowered by Violence
entries: When a critical hit is rolled on an attack roll made by a creature within 30 feet of the bocanach, the bocanach recovers hit points equal to the bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage dealt by the attack.

entries.name: Mishocair Ghosts
entries: The mischocair are the restless spirits of elves that died burdened by grief, rage, sorrow, or their own sins. Banshees are among the most well known of the mishocair, but many other varieties exist, both in the Feywild and beyond.

The bocanach are the souls of elves that died in battle. Still too wrapped up in the fury and agony of combat to pass on, these furious wind spirits perpetuate the violence that created them, gaining power from bloodshed and spreading rage and fury with their howling screams.

trait.name: Detect Life
entries: The cariad ysbryd can magically sense the presence of living creatures up to 5 miles away that are not undead or constructs. It knows the general direction they are in but not their exact locations

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The cariad ysbryd can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) lightning damage.

action.name: Song
entries: The cariad ysbryd sings a magical melody. Every non-construct within 300 feet of the cariad ysbryd that can hear the song ceases being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed} by other creatures. Additionally, the cariad ysbryd can force any creatures that hear the song to succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the song ends. The cariad ysbryd must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the cariad ysbryd is {@condition incapacitated}.
As part of the song, the cariad ysbryd can apply one of the following additional effects to the song:

items: {@b Becalming Song.} While {@condition charmed} by the cariad ysbryd, a target is indifferent towards all creatures it is normally hostile towards and can't attack or target any creature with harmful abilities, spells, or other magical effects.

{@b Rebuking Song.} While {@condition charmed} by the cariad ysbryd, an evil-aligned target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw at the start of each turn or take 5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage and be {@condition stunned} until the start of its next turn.

{@b Healing Song (1/Day).} All non-evil creatures that hear the song can choose to sing along with it. Those that do are cured of any poisons, diseases, or curses that they are currently suffering from, as well as any supernatural despair or rage, and recover {@dice 1d8} hit points at the start of each turn.

entries: Whenever it takes damage from a source other than the cariad ysbryd, a target can repeat the saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. If a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it. A target that successfully saves is immune to the {@condition charmed||charming} effect of this cariad ysbryd's song for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Mishocair Ghosts
entries: The mischocair are the restless spirits of elves that died burdened by grief, rage, sorrow, or their own sins. Banshees are among the most well known of the mishocair, but many other varieties exist, both in the Feywild and beyond.

A cariad ysbryd is what happens when a banshee comes to repent its sins and, wishing for repentance, pleads to Sehanine Moonbow under the full moon. If Sehanine judges them worthy of her mercy she touches them with her outstretched hand, purging the hatred and horror from their spirit and placing a divine song within them. These spirits then devote themselves to proving themselves worthy of returning to Arvandor and re-entering the cycle of elven reincarnation.

entries.name: Song of Sorrow
entries: Cariad Ysbryd is a beautiful sight, though its beauty is tinged with melancholy. They drift through the world, forever seeking redemption for their past sins, singing their bittersweet song. The song of the cariad ysbryd carries with it all the grief and joy that come from life and the regrets and successes it brings. Those who have known sorrow in their lives will find that they know the words to the song as if they were always buried in their hearts, and those that choose to sing along find the burdens upon their soul lifted for a time amidst their joyful weeping.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Spawn Hungry Grass
entries: When the fear gorta kills a humanoid, a patch of hungry grass is created in the space where the body falls (see in info section).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The fear gorta makes two fist attacks.

action.name: Fists
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Blessing for Alms (Recharges after a Long or Short Rest)
entries: The fear gorta targets up to eight creatures it can see. Once before a target finishes a long rest, it can choose to re-roll a failed skill check, attack roll, or saving throw.

action.name: Create Hungry Grass (Recharges after a Long or Short Rest)
entries: A patch of hungry grass grows from the spot that the fear gorta is standing in.

entries.name: Mishocair Ghosts
entries: The mischocair are the restless spirits of elves that died burdened by grief, rage, sorrow, or their own sins. Banshees are among the most well known of the mishocair, but many other varieties exist, both in the Feywild and beyond.

A fear gorta is a ghost created from the kind of despair that is only born from hope, from the knowledge that you will never stop hoping for a respite that will never come, from hating your own hope but being unable to let go of it. These wandering spirits appear as emaciated corpses, their hands outstretched to plead for relief from their suffering.

entries.name: Yearning Hunger
entries: The fear gorta is cursed with an unnatural yearning for emotional comfort. These undead roam the world in search of these comforts, begging travelers for these comforts. Those that take pity on the spirit may receive a boon of good fortune, but those that refuse the fear gorta's pleas may find themselves throttled to death by cold hands. Where the fear gorta travels, grass that bears its same yearning sprouts in its wake, spreading its curse.
Each fear gorta craves some different form of comfort. Roll for a fear gorta's craving from the Cravings table below or choose your own.

entries.caption: Cravings
colLabels: At least once per hour I must...
rows: Eat at least one pound of food.
Hear at least 5 minutes of enjoyable music.
Receive at least 15 minutes of friendly physical contact with a living creature.
Become intoxicated on alcohol or a narcotic.
Receive verbal validation from at least three trusted figures.

entries.name: Hungry Grass
entries: Hungry grass is a form of grass that appears to be normal grass but carries the same yearning hunger that curses the fear gorta. A patch of hungry grass is 10 feet by 10 feet, and the grass grows up to 2 feet tall. When the patch is disturbed by wind or a creature moving through it, it releases pollen in an invisible 5-foot radius cloud. A creature in that cloud must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become infected with a disease called Fear Gorta Yearning.

{@b Fear Gorta Yearning.} While infected with this disease, a creature is afflicted with an unnatural craving for comfort (rolled from the Cravings table). If the creature does not satiate that craving at least once per hour, its maximum hit points are reduced by {@dice 1d10}. If a creature is reduced to 0 hit points by this, it dies. An elf or half elf killed by this becomes a fear gorta 1 hour after death.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Fade in the Light
entries: While the lhiannan shee is in bright light, it is translucent and it is ephemeral, preventing it from being able to wear or carry anything and rendering it immune to being {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained}.

trait.name: Feed on Inspiration
entries: At the start of the lhiannan shee's turn, it regenerates hit points based on unexpended inspiration dice possessed by all creatures within 30 feet of it as long as it has at least 1 hit point. To determine this value, roll the dice as if they were being expended, adding that value to the lhiannan shee's hit points. This does not consume the inspiration dice.
When a creature expends an inspiration die within 30 feet of the lhiannan shee, it takes damage equal to the value rolled by the inspiration die.

trait.name: Sense Divination
entries: The lhiannan shee automatically becomes aware of any spells from the divination school that are active within 30 feet of it.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The lhiannan shee's AC includes its Charisma modifier.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 2d4}) psychic damage and the target is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Draining Kiss
entries: The lhiannan shee kisses a creature {@condition charmed} by it or a willing creature. The target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw against this magic, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

action.name: Charm
entries: The lhiannan shee targets one humanoid that it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the lhiannan shee, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be magically {@condition charmed}. The {@condition charmed} creature regards the lhiannan shee as a trusted friend to be heeded and protected. Although the target isn't under the lhiannan shee's control, it takes the lhiannan shee's requests or actions in the most favorable way it can.

Each time the lhiannan shee or its allies do anything harmful to the target, it can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Otherwise, the effect lasts 24 hours or until the lhiannan shee dies, is on a different plane of existence from the target, or ends the effect as a bonus action. If a target's saving throw is successful, the target is immune to the lhiannan shee's Charm for the next 24 hours.
The lhiannan shee can have no more than one humanoid {@condition charmed} at a time.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The lhiannan shee magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the lhiannan shee wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

entries.name: Mishocair Ghosts
entries: The mischocair are the restless spirits of elves that died burdened by grief, rage, sorrow, or their own sins. Banshees are among the most well known of the mishocair, but many other varieties exist, both in the Feywild and beyond.

A lhiannan shee is an elven soul burdened by jealous obsession, a being so consumed by a desire to possess and control all beauty that even death could not free it from its curse. A lhiannan shee appears as a beautiful elf, one whose every movement is etched with grace and poise. They pretend to be muses to poets, bards, and artists, but instead of guiding them into creating new works they feed on the creativity and inspiration of their victim until they have nothing left to give.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered or made of yew

vulnerable.note: damage from weapons made of yew wood

trait.name: Acid Clouds
entries: When the saugh takes slashing or piercing damage, a cloud of acid erupts from its flesh, dealing 5 ({@dice 1d10}) acid to all creatures within 5 feet of it. If the weapon that dealt the damage was made of yew, this trait does not function.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Returning Terror
entries: Unless its body is destroyed in a fire, the saugh recovers all hit points in {@dice 1d6} days, returning in its wandering spirit form (see Wandering Spirit).

trait.name: Yew Smoke Forbiddance
entries: The saugh cannot voluntarily approach within 60 feet of burning yew wood. While within 60 feet of burning yew wood, the saugh has disadvantage on attack rolls, saving throws, and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The saugh makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

bonus.name: Wandering Spirit
entries: The saugh's spirit leaves its body as a {@creature wraith} with the saugh's Yew Smoke Forbiddance trait, appearing in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of it. The spirit can re-enter its body while within 5 feet of it as a bonus action. It retains its hit points no matter which form it takes. While its spirit is away from its body, the body is {@condition incapacitated} and has a speed of 0 ft. The body and spirit share hit points. While in wandering spirit form, the saugh can enter the corpse of another elf, turning that into its new body.

entries.name: Mishocair Ghosts
entries: The mischocair are the restless spirits of elves that died burdened by grief, rage, sorrow, or their own sins. Banshees are among the most well known of the mishocair, but many other varieties exist, both in the Feywild and beyond.

A saugh is born from an elven soul that fears change, one which was at once unable to find contentment in its own life but also clings so desperately to that life that it cannot return to the cycle of elven reincarnation. Change is an intrinsic part of the elven soul, though, and this refusal to move on is an innate violation of the nature of their soul, which is twisted into a wandering spirit. These wandering spirits, the saugh, desperately possess corpses in the vain hope of prolonging their time on earth.

entries.name: Borrowed Flesh
entries: A saugh without a body constantly feels the call of reincarnation tugging at its soul, spurring it to frantically seek a new body to inhabit to extend its existence. Once it finds, or makes, a new vessel it imbues the flesh with unnatural strength and durability, making them frighteningly strong and almost impossible to injure. Even those that do injure the saugh's flesh will discover that the breaks in their skin vomit foul acidic vapors, making them perilous to fight. However, their bodies always decay in the end, forcing them to constantly seek out new vessels. So long as they possess a body, even death is only temporary, as their spirits cling to their flesh. Only the destruction of their flesh in fire can loosen the saugh's grip on it, finally returning them to the cycle of reincarnation.

entries.name: Yew Weakness
entries: Yew is a tree that symbolizes death and rebirth, and the saugh fear it. Weapons made of yew overcome the unnatural toughness of the saugh's flesh, and their very touch cauterizes injuries on contact, preventing the flesh from spilling acid into the air. The smoke of yew is a terrible poison to a saugh, and they will not willingly approach it. Those that must hunt a saugh always strive to do so with yew wood on hand.

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: The moonrat can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Lunar Empowerment
entries: The moonrat is empowered by moonlight. If it has not been exposed to moonlight within the last hour, or if the sun is in the sky, the moonrat uses the statistics of a common rat, except that it retains its hit points and Constitution score. The moonrat is immune to damage from {@spell moonbeam}, and when exposed to {@i moonbeam} or light from a full moon, the moonrat has advantage on all attack rolls for the next hour.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The moonrat has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Rat Tongue
entries: The moonrat can communicate with rats and giant rats.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage.

Moonrats are a variety of rat which receive power from the touch of moonlight. During the day, a moonrat appears to be a mundane rat. It possesses no distinguishing characteristics to set it apart from a typical rat, making them impossible to identify. Even their intelligence is on par with mundane rats, possessing only slightly more cunning than their lesser kin. However, when exposed to moonlight, their strength and intelligence multiply, granting them frightening physical power for a creature of their size and an evil intellect to match. They then use their small size and unassuming appearance to wreak all sorts of havoc on humanoid settlements totally free of suspicion.

entries.name: Society by Night
entries: Moonrats begin their lives as mundane rats, often being born from mundane rat parents. However, when they first venture from their den and see the moon, the magic of their bloodline awakens and they come into their own power. These moonrats form societies with both the mundane rats of their homes and other moonrats, controlling their lesser kin through their cunning and greater strength. Those moonrats with a particularly strong connection to their ancestry may even develop sorcerous powers, becoming alphas among the pack.

entries.name: Hag Made
entries: The first moonrats were created by the elder hag Cegilune, the Moon Crone, as a means of sowing discord in the world, and she and other hags still make use of these creatures from time to time. Though little more than beasts during the day, moonrats still remember much of what they have heard, making them excellent spies and saboteurs. Additionally, particularly loyal moonrats may be rewarded with arcane magic by their mistresses, becoming moonrat barons.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The moonrat alpha is a 3rd-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 11}, {@hit 3} to hit with spell attacks). The moonrat alpha has the following sorcerer spells prepared:

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: The moonrat alpha can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Lunar Empowerment
entries: The moonrat alpha is empowered by moonlight. If it has not been exposed to moonlight within the last hour, or if the sun is in the sky, the moonrat alpha uses the statistics of a common rat, except that it retains its hit points and Constitution score. The moonrat alpha is immune to damage from {@spell moonbeam}, and when exposed to {@i moonbeam} or light from a full moon, the moonrat alpha has advantage on all attack rolls for the next hour.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The moonrat alpha has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Rat Tongue
entries: The moonrat alpha can communicate with rats and giant rats.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

Moonrats are a variety of rat which receive power from the touch of moonlight. During the day, a moonrat appears to be a mundane rat. It possesses no distinguishing characteristics to set it apart from a typical rat, making them impossible to identify. Even their intelligence is on par with mundane rats, possessing only slightly more cunning than their lesser kin. However, when exposed to moonlight, their strength and intelligence multiply, granting them frightening physical power for a creature of their size and an evil intellect to match. They then use their small size and unassuming appearance to wreak all sorts of havoc on humanoid settlements totally free of suspicion.

entries.name: Society by Night
entries: Moonrats begin their lives as mundane rats, often being born from mundane rat parents. However, when they first venture from their den and see the moon, the magic of their bloodline awakens and they come into their own power. These moonrats form societies with both the mundane rats of their homes and other moonrats, controlling their lesser kin through their cunning and greater strength. Those moonrats with a particularly strong connection to their ancestry may even develop sorcerous powers, becoming alphas among the pack.

entries.name: Hag Made
entries: The first moonrats were created by the elder hag Cegilune, the Moon Crone, as a means of sowing discord in the world, and she and other hags still make use of these creatures from time to time. Though little more than beasts during the day, moonrats still remember much of what they have heard, making them excellent spies and saboteurs. Additionally, particularly loyal moonrats may be rewarded with arcane magic by their mistresses, becoming moonrat barons.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The moonrat baron is a 7th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). The moonrat alpha has the following warlock spells prepared:

spells: {@spell eldritch blast} ({@i at 5th level, 1d10 + 3 per blast})

trait.name: Cunning Action
entries: The moonrat baron can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

trait.name: Lunar Empowerment
entries: The moonrat baron is empowered by moonlight. If it has not been exposed to moonlight within the last hour, or if the sun is in the sky, the moonrat baron uses the statistics of a common rat, except that it retains its hit points and Constitution score. The moonrat baron is immune to damage from {@spell moonbeam}, and when exposed to {@i moonbeam} or light from a full moon, the moonrat baron has advantage on all attack rolls for the next hour.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The moonrat baron has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Rat Tongue
entries: The moonrat baron can communicate with rats and giant rats.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The moonrat picks one of two actions: either it makes two bite attacks, or it casts a spell from its spell list.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

Moonrats are a variety of rat which receive power from the touch of moonlight. During the day, a moonrat appears to be a mundane rat. It possesses no distinguishing characteristics to set it apart from a typical rat, making them impossible to identify. Even their intelligence is on par with mundane rats, possessing only slightly more cunning than their lesser kin. However, when exposed to moonlight, their strength and intelligence multiply, granting them frightening physical power for a creature of their size and an evil intellect to match. They then use their small size and unassuming appearance to wreak all sorts of havoc on humanoid settlements totally free of suspicion.

entries.name: Society by Night
entries: Moonrats begin their lives as mundane rats, often being born from mundane rat parents. However, when they first venture from their den and see the moon, the magic of their bloodline awakens and they come into their own power. These moonrats form societies with both the mundane rats of their homes and other moonrats, controlling their lesser kin through their cunning and greater strength. Those moonrats with a particularly strong connection to their ancestry may even develop sorcerous powers, becoming alphas among the pack.

entries.name: Hag Made
entries: The first moonrats were created by the elder hag Cegilune, the Moon Crone, as a means of sowing discord in the world, and she and other hags still make use of these creatures from time to time. Though little more than beasts during the day, moonrats still remember much of what they have heard, making them excellent spies and saboteurs. Additionally, particularly loyal moonrats may be rewarded with arcane magic by their mistresses, becoming moonrat barons.

fly.condition: (only when the sun is not in the sky)

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered (only while incorporeal)

trait.name: Incorporeality
entries: The pooka and any creatures that are riding and equipment that either of them are carrying become incorporeal. While incorporeal, the creature can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object. Additionally, the creature is resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered and is immune to the {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} conditions. The pooka can end this effect at any time. This effect ends immediately if the creature is exposed to sunlight. If the rider dismounts from the pooka, the effect ends for it.

action.name: Hooves
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The pooka magically polymorphs into a {@creature giant eagle}, a {@creature goat}, a {@creature mastiff}, a unique {@creature goblin}, or back into its true form. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. While in another form, the pooka retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, languages, and this action, but otherwise uses the statistics of the new form.

The pooka are among the most highly prized steeds of the Feywild. These horse-like fey are tireless mounts, needing neither sleep nor rest. They are particularly sought after by the eladrin of the Gloaming Court, which favor these fey as mounts for the Wild Hunt, as their ability to fly and turn incorporeal during the night makes them invaluable during that night time hunt.

entries.name: Wild but Tameable
entries: Pooka are highly sought after as mounts, but to gain a pooka mount is no simple matter. A lone pooka is willful and proud, clever and mischievous, and it will not suffer just any rider. Its ability to transform makes a pooka difficult to find, as it can appear as a wretched little goblin, a mangy hound, an evil eyed goat, or a majestic eagle. Even once one has been found, they prove challenging to tame. Restraints will not work against a creature that can pass through rope with a thought, and creatures that attempt to do so may find themselves trampled mercilessly by unforgiving hooves. Only by approaching the pooka as an equal and proving yourself worthy of its service will you garner its loyalty, and once given that loyalty is for life.

entries.name: Mounts of the Hunters
entries: Most fey courts have a stable of pooka from which the lords and ladies can select their favored mounts. These pooka are well tended to, given every luxury that they could want in exchange for their service. However, it is not just the sidhe and eladrin who favor pooka. Hobgoblins possess an unexpected affinity for pooka, and many of the soldiers of the goblin kingdom of Nachtur have powerful bonds with pooka.

entries.name: Pooka Mounts
entries: At the DM's discretion, a pooka can be summoned as a mount with the find greater steed spell. Pooka are typically favored as mounts by paladins that either work at night or travel in the Feywild, as the sun is always low in the sky in the Feywild, allowing pooka to fly and become incorporeal freely.

The DM might choose to require a character looking to recruit a pooka as a mount to first tame the pooka. This might be represented in a number of ways. The summoned pooka might require its potential master to answer a series of riddles, or to stay on its back through a number of obstacles, or find a particular item, or even simply engage it in clever discussion.

trait.name: Necrotic Absorption
entries: Whenever the rotvine defiler is subjected to necrotic damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the necrotic damage dealt.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The defiler's weapon attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to non-magical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Grymtouched
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the rotvine defiler as undead. The rotvine defiler also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rotvine defiler has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Despoil
entries: As an action, the defiler can plant itself in the ground. Over the course of the next hour, it suffuses the area surrounding it with unholy power, replicating the {@spell hallow} spell centered on itself. The effects of this spell excludes elementals, fiends, and undead. Additionally, when a creature that does not worship Moander enters the affected area, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until it leaves the area. It can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect early on a success. While despoiling an area, the defiler has a speed of 0 ft. It can uproot itself as an action, ending the effect.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The defiler makes three attacks with its tendrils.

action.name: Tendrils
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}) if it is a Large or smaller creature. A creature takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage at the start of each turn it begins {@condition grappled} by the defiler. The defiler can only have three creatures {@condition grappled} at a time.

action.name: Unhallow {@recharge 6}
entries: The defiler touches an area affected by the {@spell hallow} spell within 5 feet of it. The defiler makes an ability check ({@hit 10} to hit) with a a DC equal to 10 + the level of the spell slot used to cast the spell. On a success, the {@spell hallow} effect is dispelled.

action.name: Create Zombie
entries: The defiler turns one humanoid corpse in the area it is defiling into a {@creature zombie}.

A rotvine defiler is a horrific elemental creature born from the touch of Moander, the Darkbringer. Appearing as a lumbering mass of earth, mud, and rotting plant-life, a rotvine defiler is the power of nature corrupted into a shambling monstrosity. It's believed that the first rotvine defilers were spawned by Murgremir, the Rotting Hill, a former primordial that became an earth spirit until the poisonous dreams of Moander rotted its soul. Now these pieces of living, unclean earth may be born from any fertile ground tainted by the touch of undeath, driven by the corruption of their soil to continually roam in search of new places to defile.

monster.name: Drowned Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the rusalka as undead. The rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The drowned rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The drowned rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Drowning Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. The target must also succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or run out of breath and be unable to speak for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.
If a creature fails its saving throw against this attack three times during the course of an hour, it immediately drops to 0 hit points.

reaction.name: Curse of Returning
entries: When a living creature that the drowned rusalka is allied with is reduced to 0 hit points within 60 feet of it, the drowned rusalka summons the creature's spirit as a {@creature specter} in the space of its corpse or in the nearest unoccupied space. The {@i specter} is under the drowned rusalka's control and remains for {@dice 2d4} rounds before fading away.

To the uninitiated, these mournful, incorporeal spirits appear to be ghosts. However, they are not undead, though it is a very fine distinction. A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

entries.name: Cruel Irony
entries: When it is created, a rusalka is bound to the fate that brought its mortal existence to a close, dooming them to exist in a state of perpetual torment until released from their bonds of service. Their bond with the element that they were rescued from gives them unique powers with which they can serve their cruel patrons.

entries.name: Patron Bound
entries: A rusalka is bound to serve the fey that created it. The fey could be a powerful archfey, a cunning hag, a decadent eladrin lord, or any other being of the Feywild in possession of the knowledge of how to bind a dying soul to their service. The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

A drowned rusalka is created from the soul of a mortal that was rescued from a death by drowning. Though they reside beneath the water, these spirits are forever tormented by unquenchable thirst. When they attack, they steal the breath of their victims and attempt to drag them into their waters to join them in their torment. Even their allies are at risk, as a rusalka's desperate loneliness compels it to drag the spirits of its allies back from death itself.

monster.name: Martyred Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the martyred rusalka as undead. The martyred rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The martyred rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The martyred rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Indicting Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. The target sheds dim light in a 5-foot radius and can't become {@condition invisible} until the end of the martyred rusalka's next turn, and the next attack made against the target has advantage while the light persists.

If a creature is hit by this attack three times within the same hour, it becomes marked by the handprint of the martyred rusalka for the next hour, even if the martyred rusalka is destroyed. While marked, any creatures allied to the martyred rusalka can see the handprint on the target, regardless of illusions or invisibility.

reaction.name: Curse of Interdiction
entries: When a creature that the martyred rusalka is allied with is reduced to 0 hit points, the creature that reduced the martyred rusalka's ally to 0 hit points must succeed on a {@dc 12} Charisma saving throw if it is within 60 feet of the martyred rusalka and the martyred rusalka can see it. On a failure, the target becomes cursed for 1 minute, during which time it cannot attack or target any creature with harmful abilities, spells, or other magical effects. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.

A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

A martyred rusalka is born from the soul of a mortal who was killed for their beliefs. These spirits burn with righteous anger and seek to mark all wrongdoers with their burning touch, branding them for all to see.

monster.name: Plagued Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the plagued rusalka as undead. The plagued rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The plagued rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The plagued rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Sickening Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and the target is {@condition poisoned} until the end of the plagued rusalka's next turn.
If a creature is hit by this attack three times within the same hour, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution or be afflicted by a disease as if with the {@spell contagion} spell.

reaction.name: Curse of Feebleness
entries: When a creature that the plagued rusalka is allied with is reduced to 0 hit points, the creature that reduced the plagued rusalka's ally to 0 hit points must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw if it is within 60 feet of the plagued rusalka and the plagued rusalka can see it. On a failure the target becomes weakened for 1 minute, during which time the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.

To the uninitiated, these mournful, incorporeal spirits appear to be ghosts. However, they are not undead, though it is a very fine distinction. A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

The fey could be a powerful archfey, a cunning hag, a decadent eladrin lord, or any other being of the Feywild in possession of the knowledge of how to bind a dying soul to their service. The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Disease is a merciless killer, and those whose death is assured by sickness may desperately seek an escape. Sadly, though they escape oblivion when they become a plagued rusalka, they do not escape their pain. These wretched spirits are forever tormented by the suffering of diseases, and they spread that suffering to all creatures that they touch.

monster.name: Scorched Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the scorched rusalka as undead. The scorched rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The scorched rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The scorched rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bedlam Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become bewildered until the end of the scorched rusalka's next turn. While bewildered, the target must start its turn by using all its movement to move in a random direction. To determine the direction, roll a {@dice d8} and assign a direction to each die face.
If a creature fails its saving throw against this attack three times within the same hour, it becomes afflicted with the {@spell confusion} spell.

reaction.name: Curse of Retribution
entries: When a creature that the scorched rusalka is allied with is reduced to 0 hit points, the creature that reduced the scorched rusalka's ally to 0 hit points becomes engulfed in flames if it is within 60 feet of the rusalka and the scorched rusalka can see it. The target must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw, taking 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage on a failure or half as much on a success. Additionally, the target ignites on a failure. Until a creature takes an action to douse the fire, the target takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns.

To the uninitiated, these mournful, incorporeal spirits appear to be ghosts. However, they are not undead, though it is a very fine distinction. A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

Their bond with the element that they were rescued from gives them unique powers with which they can serve their cruel patrons.

entries: A rusalka is bound to serve the fey that created it. The fey could be a powerful archfey, a cunning hag, a decadent eladrin lord, or any other being of the Feywild in possession of the knowledge of how to bind a dying soul to their service. The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

These spirits are made from those who were doomed to die in flames. The memories of who they once were continually fade away like dying coals, and only the joy of igniting flames rekindle those memories to light.

monster.name: Starved Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the starved rusalka as undead. The starved rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The starved rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The starved rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Wasting Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage and the target's Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.
If a is hit by this attack three times within the same hour, it cannot recover hit points for 1 hour.

reaction.name: Curse of Hunger
entries: When a creature that is not an construct, elemental, or undead within 60 feet of the rusalka is reduced to 0 hit points, the starved rusalka recovers hit points equal to the creature's hit dice. If the creature was the starved rusalka's ally, it recovers the maximum hit points possible from the hit dice value.

To the uninitiated, these mournful, incorporeal spirits appear to be ghosts. However, they are not undead, though it is a very fine distinction. A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

entries.name: Cruel Irony
entries: When it is created, a rusalka is bound to the fate that brought its mortal existence to a close, dooming them to exist in a state of perpetual torment until released from their bonds of service. Their bond with the element that they were rescued from gives them unique powers with which they can serve their cruel patrons.

entries.name: Patron Bound
entries: A rusalka is bound to serve the fey that created it. The fey could be a powerful archfey, a cunning hag, a decadent eladrin lord, or any other being of the Feywild in possession of the knowledge of how to bind a dying soul to their service. The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

Hunger is a terrible affliction, and to die from hunger is slow and painful. A starved rusalka exists in a constant state of hunger. It attempts to devours the lives of all it touches to satisfy the unquenchable craving within its soul.

trait.name: Contaminate
entries: Food or drink brought within 30 feet of the harridan becomes contaminated with {@disease Sewer Plague}.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The rylkar harridan regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the rylkar harridan takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the rylkar harridan's next turn. The rylkar harridan dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Spawn Swarm
entries: When the harridan takes fire damage, it spawns one {@creature rylkspawn swarm} in a space within 5 feet of it for every 5 hit points of fire damage taken.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The harridan can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d4 + 5}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease Filth Fever|PHB} for 24 hours. While infected with {@i Filth Fever}, a creature has disadvantage on Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and attack rolls that use Strength. If a creature's saving throw is successful, it is immune to {@i Filth Fever} for 24 hours. The disease lasts until cured with magic.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each non-rylkar creature of the harridan's choice that is within 120 feet of the harridan and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the harridan's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

reaction.name: Poison Potion
entries: The harridan targets one potion that it can see within 60 feet of it that a creature is about to ingest. If the potion is of a rarity of very rare or less, it becomes a {@item potion of poison}.

Rylkar are among the most foul and hateful creatures in existence. Though they superficially appear to be rats, they are in actuality monstrous, unnatural creatures of disease and slaughter. These wretched monsters lair in sewers and caverns, ravenously devouring all that they can and spreading their foul plague until all that was once living near their homes is dead and devoured. Then they simply move on.

entries.name: Born from Fire
entries: At the center of every rylkar nest is the harridan, a hideously swollen, rat-like monster the size of an elephant. This repulsive creature sits stinking deep beneath the ground, devouring all food brought to her to slake her unnatural hunger. The harridan is the key to the swarm's survival, as when fire is pressed into her flesh it erupts into blisters and boils filled with writhing swarms of rylkspawn. These rylkspawn, if they avoid their mother's insatiable hunger, devour one another until they finally mature into either madclaws, the insane foragers and hunters of the nest, or tormentors, the vicious warriors of the nest.

entries.name: Hag Born
entries: Rylkar are not natural creatures. A rylkar swarm is born as the direct result of the actions of a hag, who uses her magic to create a rylkar harridan to plague the world. It is said that the first rylkar harridan was a hag who used profane magic to transform herself into the wretched monster, giving up her mind so that she might become a being of pure hatred and destruction. Since then, other hags have discovered the means of creating harridans, and while many prefer to perform the ritual on others to preserve their own intelligence, some view the act of becoming a harridan as the ultimate act of evil, embracing the loss of identity like some perverse form of enlightenment.

A rylkar harridan is the temperamental mother of her swarm, a being of insatiable hunger and unimaginable cruelty. They sit at the center of their nests, languishing in their own filth and devouring all food brought to them by their madclaw consorts. Though their eyes are invariably clawed out by their young, leaving weeping empty sockets in their place, their hearing and sense of smell grants them surprisingly good awareness, allowing them to seek out and devour any intruders, or their own young if their hunger demands it.

The rylkar den is a network of twisting tunnels, both naturally occurring and dug out by madclaws, filled with foul stench, vile excretions, and hungry mouths. The madclaws and tormentors range further and further from the nest as they gradually strip the land of resources, placing the nest at the center of a gradually spreading circle of death and disease.

When at least four rylkar defend their den together, they can call on the environment to aid them. The group must include at least one madclaw or tormentor. When determining the difficulty of such an encounter, consider the lair to be one additional creature of challenge rating 1.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Fire Absorption
entries: Whenever the rylkar madclaw is subjected to fire damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the fire damage dealt.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The rylkar madclaw has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the rylkar madclaw's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease Filth Fever} for 24 hours. While infected with {@i Filth Fever}, a creature has disadvantage on Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and attack rolls that use Strength. If a creature's saving throw is successful, it is immune to {@i Filth Fever} for 24 hours. The disease lasts until cured with magic.

action.name: Mad Shriek (Recharges After a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The rylkar madclaw unleashes a horrific shriek. Each non-rylkar that is within 60 feet of the rylkar madclaw and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become affected by the {@spell confusion} spell for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the Mad Shrieks of all rylkar madclaws for the next 24 hours.

Rylkar are among the most foul and hateful creatures in existence. Though they superficially appear to be rats, they are in actuality monstrous, unnatural creatures of disease and slaughter. These wretched monsters lair in sewers and caverns, ravenously devouring all that they can and spreading their foul plague until all that was once living near their homes is dead and devoured. Then they simply move on.

entries.name: Born from Fire
entries: At the center of every rylkar nest is the harridan, a hideously swollen, rat-like monster the size of an elephant. This repulsive creature sits stinking deep beneath the ground, devouring all food brought to her to slake her unnatural hunger. The harridan is the key to the swarm's survival, as when fire is pressed into her flesh it erupts into blisters and boils filled with writhing swarms of rylkspawn. These rylkspawn, if they avoid their mother's insatiable hunger, devour one another until they finally mature into either madclaws, the insane foragers and hunters of the nest, or tormentors, the vicious warriors of the nest.

entries.name: Hag Born
entries: Rylkar are not natural creatures. A rylkar swarm is born as the direct result of the actions of a hag, who uses her magic to create a rylkar harridan to plague the world. It is said that the first rylkar harridan was a hag who used profane magic to transform herself into the wretched monster, giving up her mind so that she might become a being of pure hatred and destruction. Since then, other hags have discovered the means of creating harridans, and while many prefer to perform the ritual on others to preserve their own intelligence, some view the act of becoming a harridan as the ultimate act of evil, embracing the loss of identity like some perverse form of enlightenment.

The madclaws are the most common members of a rylkar nest. Small and agile, these dog-sized rat-like creatures possess a cackling shriek that inflicts madness on their victims and a disturbing pack mentality which enables them to overwhelm startlingly large prey. They attend to the harridan in her lair, gather food, dig new tunnels, search for fire to create new spawn, and scout for new potential homes when they've scoured their homes of all life.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Fire Absorption
entries: Whenever the rylkar tormentor is subjected to fire damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the fire damage dealt.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the rylkar tormentor moves at least 20 feet straight toward a Medium or smaller creature and then hits it with a bite attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the rylkar tormentor can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rylkar tormentor can use its Hate Shriek if available. It then makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease Filth Fever} for 24 hours. While infected with {@i Filth Fever}, a creature has disadvantage on Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and attack rolls that use Strength. If a creature's saving throw is successful, it is immune to {@i Filth Fever} for 24 hours. The disease lasts until cured with magic.

action.name: Hate Shriek {@recharge 6}
entries: The rylkar tormentor unleashes a hateful shriek. Each non-harridan rylkar that is within 60 feet of the rylkar tormentor and can hear it is empowered by fury for 1 minute. This includes the rylkar tormentor itself. An empowered rylkar adds an additional {@dice 1d4} to its attack rolls.

Rylkar are among the most foul and hateful creatures in existence. Though they superficially appear to be rats, they are in actuality monstrous, unnatural creatures of disease and slaughter. These wretched monsters lair in sewers and caverns, ravenously devouring all that they can and spreading their foul plague until all that was once living near their homes is dead and devoured. Then they simply move on.

entries.name: Born from Fire
entries: At the center of every rylkar nest is the harridan, a hideously swollen, rat-like monster the size of an elephant. This repulsive creature sits stinking deep beneath the ground, devouring all food brought to her to slake her unnatural hunger. The harridan is the key to the swarm's survival, as when fire is pressed into her flesh it erupts into blisters and boils filled with writhing swarms of rylkspawn. These rylkspawn, if they avoid their mother's insatiable hunger, devour one another until they finally mature into either madclaws, the insane foragers and hunters of the nest, or tormentors, the vicious warriors of the nest.

entries.name: Hag Born
entries: Rylkar are not natural creatures. A rylkar swarm is born as the direct result of the actions of a hag, who uses her magic to create a rylkar harridan to plague the world. It is said that the first rylkar harridan was a hag who used profane magic to transform herself into the wretched monster, giving up her mind so that she might become a being of pure hatred and destruction. Since then, other hags have discovered the means of creating harridans, and while many prefer to perform the ritual on others to preserve their own intelligence, some view the act of becoming a harridan as the ultimate act of evil, embracing the loss of identity like some perverse form of enlightenment.

The tormentors are the soldiers of a rylkar nest. They guard the tunnels that lead into into their den, protect the harridan and the swarms of rylkspawn that she produces, and accompany the madclaws on their raids against particularly difficult targets. They have no love for any living creature, including their own kin, and they will not hesitate to devour a madclaw or the squirming rylkspawn that they guard.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Seething
entries: Once it enters combat, the swarm deals 10 slashing damage to itself at the end of its turn if it did not make an attack on that turn. This damage ignores resistance, and it cannot reduce the swarm to 0 hit points. The Hate Shriek of a rylkar tormentor or the Mad Shriek of a rylkar madclaw can halt the swarm from damaging itself for 1 minute.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The rylkspawn swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny rat. The swarm can't regain hit points or gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Terror Musk
entries: Any non-rylkar that starts its turn within 10 feet of the swarm must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creatued is {@condition frightened} of all rylkar. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the Terror Musk of all rylkspawn swarms for 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rylkspawn swarm makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bites
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) piercing damage, or 5 ({@damage 2d4}) damage if the swarm has half its hit points or fewer. Additionally, the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease Filth Fever} for 24 hours. While infected with {@i Filth Fever}, a creature has disadvantage on Strength checks, Strength saving throws, and attack rolls that use Strength. If a creature's saving throw is successful, it is immune to {@i Filth Fever} for 24 hours. The disease lasts until cured with magic.

action.name: Maturation
entries: The rylkspawn in the swarm begin devouring one another until only one remains. The swarm cannot move or take reactions until the start of its next turn, at which point the final rylkspawn devours its last broodmate and transforms into a mature rylkar, the variety of which is determined by how much damage the swarm has dealt via a combination of its bites attack or and its Seething trait. If it has dealt 30 damage, it becomes a {@creature rylkar madclaw}. If it has dealt 60 damage, it becomes a {@creature rylkar tormentor}.

Rylkar are among the most foul and hateful creatures in existence. Though they superficially appear to be rats, they are in actuality monstrous, unnatural creatures of disease and slaughter. These wretched monsters lair in sewers and caverns, ravenously devouring all that they can and spreading their foul plague until all that was once living near their homes is dead and devoured. Then they simply move on.

entries.name: Born from Fire
entries: At the center of every rylkar nest is the harridan, a hideously swollen, rat-like monster the size of an elephant. This repulsive creature sits stinking deep beneath the ground, devouring all food brought to her to slake her unnatural hunger. The harridan is the key to the swarm's survival, as when fire is pressed into her flesh it erupts into blisters and boils filled with writhing swarms of rylkspawn. These rylkspawn, if they avoid their mother's insatiable hunger, devour one another until they finally mature into either madclaws, the insane foragers and hunters of the nest, or tormentors, the vicious warriors of the nest.

entries.name: Hag Born
entries: Rylkar are not natural creatures. A rylkar swarm is born as the direct result of the actions of a hag, who uses her magic to create a rylkar harridan to plague the world. It is said that the first rylkar harridan was a hag who used profane magic to transform herself into the wretched monster, giving up her mind so that she might become a being of pure hatred and destruction. Since then, other hags have discovered the means of creating harridans, and while many prefer to perform the ritual on others to preserve their own intelligence, some view the act of becoming a harridan as the ultimate act of evil, embracing the loss of identity like some perverse form of enlightenment.

When a madclaw finds a new source of fire, it captures it and brings it to the harridan of its nest. The flame is plunged into the harridan's twitching flesh, which rapidly bubbles up into massive blisters and bursts into swarms of writhing, naked rylkpawn. No one could mistake this horrific, seething mass of creatures for a swarm of natural rats. Twisted, malformed, and diseased, these monsters produce a musk which fills any who smell them with terror.

entries.name: Hunger
entries: Rylkspawn are born hungry and vicious. They attack any living creature they encounter without a trace of self preservation, overwhelming their victims with the sheer number of shrieking mouths. When no prey present themselves, the swarm turns on itself, rapidly devouring one another until finally just one remains, becoming an adult madclaw or tormentor.

entries.name: New Mother
entries: If a harridan devours a living humanoid infant, the next rylkspawn swarm will contain a nascent harridan which quickly begins to devour its siblings, soon maturing into an adolescent harridan. If this new harridan can escape her mother's hunger, it strikes out on its own with a small escort of its siblings and starts a new nest. However, because madclaws rarely bring live prey back to the nest, this is an exceedingly rare occurrence.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Horrific Appearance
entries: Any humanoid that starts its turn within 30 feet of the bargda and can see the bargda's true form must make a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if the bargda is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the bargda's Horrific Appearance for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The bargda has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bargda makes three weapon attacks: one with its ram, one with its bite, and one with either its ram or its greatclub.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or contract {@i Bargda Fever} for 7 days. While infected with {@i Bargda Fever}, a creature's reflexes are slowed, imposing disadvantage on initiative rolls and Dexterity saving throws and skill checks, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) necrotic damage.

A bargda is a wretched creature. They look like satyrs the size of trolls, their faces and bodies horrifically twisted as if by plague and cancer. Their uneven mouths ooze with rotten drool, and their bandy legs limp and stumble as they walk. They drag wooden clubs clumsily lashed with bone in their swollen hands, searching for food or victims to vent their agonized fury against. The love for beauty and music that lives in all satyr souls is all but extinguished in them, and they find pleasure in little beyond cruelty and savagery. Only among the fomorians do they find any sort of acceptance.

entries.name: Twisted and Diseased
entries: Bargda truly are among the most wretched of creatures. So twisted by deformity that they can barely run, a bargda's only hope at enjoying the taste of meat is through traps. However, even once they capture their prey, they cannot immediately enjoy their meal. Their digestive systems are weak and cannot break down food that has not begun to decompose. A bargda's larder is filled with food that it has left to ripen.

entries.name: Followers of the Horned King
entries: The first bargda were once satyrs who followed Oberon, the Green Lord. They joined in his wandering, glorying in the beauty of the hunt and the savage joy of bloodshed. Soon their bloodlust grew so great that they began to worship the demon lord Baphomet, who granted them the hunting skills of a minotaur. However, when they hunted down Oberon's daughter, his vengeance was swift and absolute. He cursed them with hideous physical deformities, making every step an agony and causing them to be unable to enjoy the blood of a fresh kill. Now any satyrs that so offend an archfey may find themselves similarly cursed to everlasting pain.

entries.name: Rough Music
entries: Bargda are supernaturally attracted to resentment. Small enclaves of bargda may form near a village in which a man savagely beats his wife and children, or a city with a growing paranoia, or a kingdom where a tyrant leaves his people to starve. Bargda can smell the tension rising, and when that tension reaches a breaking point is when they play the rough music.

The rough music is the only form of music left alive in a bargda's withered soul. It is the song of slow resentment boiling over, of vengeance and rage and thoughtless fury, the voice of the angry mob. It is as likely to turn against a child killer as it is against an old woman mistaken for an evil witch. When the rough music echoes down from the hills, a mob is formed and frustration becomes violence.

Once the mob settles and peace returns, the bargda collect the aftermath. The bones of the dead become tools in rituals to Baphomet, the flesh becomes sacrifices, and the memory of the violence becomes power. Strange gifts may be bestowed upon the players of the rough music.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The gabharchinn has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gabharchinn can begin its War Chant if it is raging. It then makes three weapon attacks: one with its ram and two with its handaxe.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage white raging.

action.name: Handaxe
