entries: Any non-eladrin creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of the eladrin paletouched hunter must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to any eladrin paletouched hunter's Fearsome Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The eladrin paletouched hunter makes four weapon attacks

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

bonus.name: Fey Step {@recharge 5}
entries: The eladrin paletouched hunter teleports to an unoccupied space that it can see within 30 feet of it.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The eladrin paletouched hunter adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the eladrin paletouched hunter must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon. If the creature making the attack against the eladrin paletouched hunter is within 5 feet of it, it also takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) cold damage.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The eladrin paletouched hunter makes one weapons attack.

legendary.name: Cast a spell
entries: The eladrin paletouched hunter casts a spell from its at will list in its innate spellcasting ability.

legendary.name: Fey Step (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: If the eladrin paletouched hunter didn't use its fey step and it has it recharged, it uses fey step.

The eladrin who live within the Feywild form their own kingdoms, but these kingdoms must pay homage to the archfey that hold sway near them. As such, tithes of goods such as food and gems must be paid to the various courts, but they must also pay tithes of their finest warriors, spellcasters, and artists. Those who are sworn to the service of the Summer Court or the Gloaming Court can be certain to live in beauty and luxury for the rest of their days. However, to those sworn to the Prince of Frost, a sadder fate awaits.

entries.name: Heart of Ice
entries: When an eladrin is sworn to his service, the Prince of Frost cuts out the heart of his new servant and replaces it with a heart made of ice and stone. With their hearts so replaced, these paletouched eladrin forget love, warmth, and joy. Totally devoid of emotion, these elves can be swayed by neither beauty nor fear. They no longer suffer hunger, nor do their bodies tire from exertion or lack of sleep. In short, they becomes the perfect servants for the Pale Prince.

The paletouched hunters are among the Prince of Frost's favored warriors. The Pale Prince turns to these cold-hearted rangers when the wants someone killed or captured, trusting their masterful tracking skills and cool logic to overcome any foes they might encounter. The approach of these warriors is presaged by the howling of wind and a sense of unrestrained terror.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The eladrin's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The eladrin paletouched mage is a 15th level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). The eladrin paletouched hunter has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Hopeless Presence
entries: Any non-eladrin creature that starts its turn within 60 feet of the eladrin must make a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition charmed} for 1 minute. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the creature can't attack or target any creature with harmful abilities, spells, or other magical effects. The {@condition charmed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to any eladrin's Hopeless Presence or Sorrowful Presence for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the eladrin paletouched mage fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The eladrin paletouched mage has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The eladrin paletouched mage casts two cantrips.

action.name: Chill Touch (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 10} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage, and the target can't regain hit points until the start of the eladrin paletouched mage's next turn. If the target is undead, it has disadvantage on attack rolls against the eladrin paletouched mage until the end of the eladrin paletouched mage's next turn.

action.name: Ray of Frost (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage and the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of the eladrin paletouched mage's next turn.

action.name: Shocking Grasp (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) lightning damage and the target can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. This attack has advantage if the target is wearing armor made of metal.

bonus.name: Fey Step {@recharge 5}
entries: The eladrin paletouched mage teleports to an unoccupied space that it can see within 30 feet of it.

reaction.name: Frigid Rebuke
entries: When the eladrin paletouched mage takes damage from a creature the eladrin paletouched mage can see within 60 feet of it, the eladrin paletouched mage can force that creature to succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage. If the creature is wearing metal armor, it has disadvantage on this saving throw. If the saving throw fails by more than 5, the target is also {@condition restrained} by frost until the start of its next turn.

legendary.name: Cast cantrip
entries: The eladrin paletouched mage casts one of its cantrips.

legendary.name: Fey Step (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: If the eladrin paletouched mage didn't use its fey step and it has it recharged, it uses fey step.

legendary.name: Cast spell (Costs 1-2 Actions)
entries: The eladrin paletouched mage uses a spell slot to cast a 1st- or 2nd- level spell that it has prepared. Doing so costs 1 legendary action per level of the spell.

The eladrin who live within the Feywild form their own kingdoms, but these kingdoms must pay homage to the archfey that hold sway near them. As such, tithes of goods such as food and gems must be paid to the various courts, but they must also pay tithes of their finest warriors, spellcasters, and artists. Those who are sworn to the service of the Summer Court or the Gloaming Court can be certain to live in beauty and luxury for the rest of their days. However, to those sworn to the Prince of Frost, a sadder fate awaits.

entries.name: Heart of Ice
entries: When an eladrin is sworn to his service, the Prince of Frost cuts out the heart of his new servant and replaces it with a heart made of ice and stone. With their hearts so replaced, these paletouched eladrin forget love, warmth, and joy. Totally devoid of emotion, these elves can be swayed by neither beauty nor fear. They no longer suffer hunger, nor do their bodies tire from exertion or lack of sleep. In short, they becomes the perfect servants for the Pale Prince.

The Prince of Frost's Palace of Frozen Tears is largely empty, reflecting its master's desire for solitude. However, it is not totally without other occupants. A scant few mages of incredible power and skill reside within its lonely towers, quietly engaging in arcane research amid their own numb despair. When called upon by their lord, these sages provide the Pale Prince with their coldly calculating counsel and assist him in crafting spells of incredible magnitude.

entries.name: Arcane Might
entries: The paletouched mages are more than just sages. Able to take to the air at will, these powerful spellcasters can unleash elemental fury from the safety of the air, pelting their foes with both ice and lightning while remaining out of reach. They are also responsible for the protection of the Palace of Frozen Tears, supplying it with both undead defenders and arcane protections. These eladrin are not limited only to the Palace of Frozen Tears, though, and some might serve their lord elsewhere in the Feywild, acting as envoys for the Pale Prince in eladrin courts or hunting for rare arcane artifacts.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The frost faerie's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12} {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Ice Wings
entries: If the frost faerie takes fire damage, its wings melt and it loses its flying speed until it can make new wings for itself during a short rest.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The frost faerie has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Superior Invisibility
entries: The frost faerie magically turns {@condition invisible} until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the frost wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

Fairies are the little spirits of the Feywild. Of these, the pixies and sprites are the most well known, but many other varieties of fairies exist in the Feywild. It's widely believed that when an infant first laughs, that laugh is born into a new fairy in the Feywild. Whether or not that is true is a hotly debated topic among scholars. Howver, it is clear that even the harsh winter of the fey has its own fairy denizens.

These snow loving fairies are spirits of winter and just as kind and fun loving as their pixie summer-kin, though they are not quite as aware of the needs of warm blooded creatures. They encase delicate leaves in a layer of frost to protect them from the harsh winter cold and frolic with arctic foxes and snow white hares, delighting in the wonders of winter. Though good-natured, these fey will happily serve cruel winter fey, as that is the natural order of fey.

The pixies of temperate climates may become frosts during winter, as if putting on their winter fashion, only to return to being pixies come spring, while those that live in arctic regions will remain as frosts all year round, even if they enter a warmer climate.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 40/160 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. If its saving throw result is 5 or lower, the {@condition poisoned} target falls {@condition unconscious} for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The koropokkuru magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the koropokkuru wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

Elusive but helpful, koropokkuru are much more inclined to lend aid to mortals than their warm climate cousins. They make their homes underneath butterbur plants and are fond of fishing. They will invisibly aid mortals in small but significant ways, but should the mortals try to find or capture their fey guardians, the koropokkuru will take offense and leave.

entries.name: Variant: Koropokkuru Familiar
entries: {@b Familiar.} While the koropokkuru is within 10 feet of its master, its master automatically succeeds on saving throws to resist cold damage and the effects of extreme cold

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rime sprite's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The rime sprite can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Ice Swim
entries: The rime sprite treats ice and snow as liquid water for the purposes of movement and breathing.

action.name: Ray of Frost
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage and the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of the rime sprite's next turn.

action.name: Snow Flurry (3/Day)
entries: The rime sprite creates a 10- foot radius sphere of whirling snow centered on itself, heavily obscuring the area. The flurry lasts until the start of its next turn.

The mischievous rime sprite is the bane of sailors and fishermen alike. These tiny fey look like animated ice statues of beautiful or handsome elves with snow for hair, and they derive great delight in tormenting humanoids who live and work on the water of arctic coastlines.

entries.name: Mischievous.
entries: Most rime sprites remain content playing harmless jokes on people, such as freezing unattended drinks, entangling people and boats in patches of seaweed, or creating minor images of valued personal objects afloat just out of reach in the water. Rime sprites are easy to anger, though, and if they even think that they are being threatened, their jokes quickly turn deadly and cruel.

entries.name: Rime Sprites in Icewind Dale
entries: Auril uses {@creature rime sprite||rime sprites|TFC} to tend to her ice statues, and these fey prefer to reside within these beautiful creations. If one of Auril's ice statues is damaged, {@dice 1d4} {@creature rime sprite||rime sprites|TFC} will emerge from the statue and attack the offending creature, though they flee if one of their number is killed. These rime sprites will likely team up with the {@creature ice mephit} Söpo to cause more misery for the party, using their illusions and fog clouds to confuse and mislead the party.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The befana hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Skilled
entries: All befana hags are proficient in the following tools, adding +2 to any skill check made with them: {@item Brewer's Supplies}, {@item carpenter's tools}, {@item cobbler's tools}, {@item cook's utensils}, {@item healer's kit}, {@item herbalism kit}, {@item jeweler's tools}, {@item leatherworker's tools}, {@item potter's tools}, {@item tinker's tools}, {@item weaver's tools}, and {@item woodcarver's tools}.

trait.name: Befana Items
entries: The befana hag is equipped with a broom and a large woven hamper.

items: {@b Broom.} The {@creature befana hag's broom|TheFeyCompendium} is loyal only to the befana hag that created it and can act autonomously or be wielded as a weapon or as a {@item broom of flying} if willing.

{@b Hamper.} This hamper functions as a {@item bag of holding}, but its dimensions are approximately 2- foot by 2-foot by 4-foot and only the befana hag that made the hamper can retrieve any desired item from the hamper with an action. Any other creature must perform a successful DC Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to find a specified item in a number of minutes {@dice 3d12} – the searcher's Intelligence modifier. If destroyed, a new hamper takes a year and a day to construct.

action.name: Broomstick
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

A befana hag possesses one of the kindest hearts in existence, and she desires nothing more than to spread kindness and good cheer to the cold and hungry. Appearing as little more than a withered old woman bent over under a heavy hamper, these hags roam the winter in search of those who need them most, bringing them gifts of toys, food, and firewood. These hags love to bring joy and good cheer, and are always ready with a clever joke or an uplifting bit of advice.

entries.name: The Kindly Hags
entries: A befana hag spends her free time gathering firewood, cooking hearty meals, and crafting peculiar and delightful toys. These are packed securely into the magic hamper on her back, which can contain an almost endless supply of objects, so that she can deliver them to the poor and needy on her magic broom. The majority of the space in a befana hag's hamper is occupied by bundles of firewood and bags of coal. However, a befana hag always stores a good deal of food and a few magical items within her hamper as well.

entries.name: Crafty
entries: Befana hags are naturally skilled at craftsmanship, and their homes are littered with the detritus of innumerable projects. Dolls, figures, and miniature houses fill all available shelf space in a befana hag's home, waiting to be gifted to just the right little boy or girl. Every toy a befana hag crafted contains a little spark of magic. A doll will perform chores for good little girls. A teddy bear will sing songs to a little boy when he's lonely or frightened. A carving of a star may glow in the dark with a soft light that only a child can see.

entries.name: Foes of the Cold
entries: Befana hags are the deadly enemies of the cruel hags of winter such as bheur hags, marzanna hags, and gryla hags. Though not as physically powerful as these winter hags, a befana hag is cunning. Their greatest skill is the empowerment of others, and many heroes have overthrown wicked tyrants or defeated terrible monsters because of the magical items and wise advice of a befana hag. Other hags always think twice before attacking a befana hag, as there's no telling just what she may have hidden in her hamper.

entries.name: A Befana Hag's Lair
entries: A befana hag prefers to lair in out of the way mountains with easy access to the materials she needs for crafting. Her lair will always be well hidden, disguised by both magical and mundane means, though there will always be charms that allow the lost or lonely to end up on their doorsteps. Though unassuming from the outside, a befana hag's lair will always be warm and cozy within.

A befana hag's home will always have guardians. Animated tables, rugs of smothering, fire pokers with the statistics of flying swords, and other {@spell animated objects} are likely to be found guarding a befana hag's home.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A befana hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions.

items: The hag commands one construct within her lair that is loyal to her to use its reaction to make one melee attack.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful befana hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Inanimate objects such as tree stumps and rocks are prone to speaking and may act as guides to lost individuals.

entries: When the hag dies, these effect fades after {@dice 1d10} days.

monster.name: Elder Befana Hag

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder befana hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Skilled
entries: All befana hags are proficient in the following tools, adding +4 to any skill check made with them: {@item Brewer's Supplies}, {@item carpenter's tools}, {@item cobbler's tools}, {@item cook's utensils}, {@item healer's kit}, {@item herbalism kit}, {@item jeweler's tools}, {@item leatherworker's tools}, {@item potter's tools}, {@item tinker's tools}, {@item weaver's tools}, and {@item woodcarver's tools}.

trait.name: Befana Items
entries: The elder befana hag is equipped with a broom and a large woven hamper.

items: {@b Broom.} The broom's statistics are detailed on the following page. It is loyal only to the elder befana hag that created it and can act autonomously or be wielded as a weapon or as a {@item broom of flying} if willing.

{@b Hamper.} This hamper functions as a {@item bag of holding}, but its dimensions are approximately 2- foot by 2-foot by 4-foot and only the elder befana hag that made the hamper can retrieve any desired item from the hamper with an action. Any other creature must perform a successful DC Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to find a specified item in a number of minutes {@dice 3d12} – the searcher's Intelligence modifier. If destroyed, a new hamper takes a year and a day to construct.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder befana hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder befana hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Broomstick
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

legendaryHeader: The elder befana hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The elder befana hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder befana hag makes one attack with her broomstick.

legendary.name: Command Construct
entries: The elder befana hag commands one construct loyal to her within 60 feet of her to use its reaction to make one melee attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The elder befana hag casts {@spell bestow curse} ({@dc 16}).

legendary.name: Clean Sweep (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: If the elder befana hag is holding her broom, she flies up to 50 feet.

A befana hag possesses one of the kindest hearts in existence, and she desires nothing more than to spread kindness and good cheer to the cold and hungry. Appearing as little more than a withered old woman bent over under a heavy hamper, these hags roam the winter in search of those who need them most, bringing them gifts of toys, food, and firewood. These hags love to bring joy and good cheer, and are always ready with a clever joke or an uplifting bit of advice.

entries.name: The Kindly Hags
entries: A befana hag spends her free time gathering firewood, cooking hearty meals, and crafting peculiar and delightful toys. These are packed securely into the magic hamper on her back, which can contain an almost endless supply of objects, so that she can deliver them to the poor and needy on her magic broom. The majority of the space in a befana hag's hamper is occupied by bundles of firewood and bags of coal. However, a befana hag always stores a good deal of food and a few magical items within her hamper as well.

entries.name: Crafty
entries: Befana hags are naturally skilled at craftsmanship, and their homes are littered with the detritus of innumerable projects. Dolls, figures, and miniature houses fill all available shelf space in a befana hag's home, waiting to be gifted to just the right little boy or girl. Every toy a befana hag crafted contains a little spark of magic. A doll will perform chores for good little girls. A teddy bear will sing songs to a little boy when he's lonely or frightened. A carving of a star may glow in the dark with a soft light that only a child can see.

entries.name: Foes of the Cold
entries: Befana hags are the deadly enemies of the cruel hags of winter such as bheur hags, marzanna hags, and gryla hags. Though not as physically powerful as these winter hags, a befana hag is cunning. Their greatest skill is the empowerment of others, and many heroes have overthrown wicked tyrants or defeated terrible monsters because of the magical items and wise advice of a befana hag. Other hags always think twice before attacking a befana hag, as there's no telling just what she may have hidden in her hamper.

entries.name: Covens
entries: An elder befana hag that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) has a challenge rating of 11 (7,200 XP).

The oldest befana hags have seen countless winters and understand firsthand the cruelty of the season. Their devotion to lessening the suffering of mortals is unflappable, and when an elder befana hag sets her mind to something there is no stopping her.

entries.name: A Befana Hag's Lair
entries: A befana hag prefers to lair in out of the way mountains with easy access to the materials she needs for crafting. Her lair will always be well hidden, disguised by both magical and mundane means, though there will always be charms that allow the lost or lonely to end up on their doorsteps. Though unassuming from the outside, a befana hag's lair will always be warm and cozy within.

A befana hag's home will always have guardians. Animated tables, rugs of smothering, fire pokers with the statistics of flying swords, and other {@spell animated objects} are likely to be found guarding a befana hag's home.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A befana hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions.

items: The hag commands one construct within her lair that is loyal to her to use its reaction to make one melee attack.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful befana hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Inanimate objects such as tree stumps and rocks are prone to speaking and may act as guides to lost individuals.

entries: When the hag dies, these effect fades after {@dice 1d10} days.

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The befana hag's broom is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an {@i antimagic field}. If targeted by {@i dispel magic}, the befana hag's broom must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: Constructed Nature
entries: The broom doesn’t require air, food, drink, or sleep. The magic that animates the broom is dispelled when the construct drops to 0 hit points. When reduced to 0 hit points it becomes inanimate and is too damaged to be of much use or value to anyone.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the befana hag's broom remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal broom.

action.name: Broomstick
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

reaction.name: Animated Attack
entries: If the broom is motionless and a creature grabs hold of it, the broom makes a Dexterity check contested by the creature’s Strength check. If the broom wins the contest, it flies out of the creature’s grasp and makes a melee attack against it with advantage on the attack roll.

Every befana hag possesses a broomstick which is unwaveringly loyal to it and can be used as a broom of flying. While in the hands of a befana hag the broom seems docile and inanimate, but when unattended these brooms will defend their befana hag with a cunning and intelligence rarely seen in constructs. The broom can even be borrowed. A befana hag may lend her broom to a lost child or a hero in need of a fast form of transportation. The broom will obey the orders of any creature it is lent to, but it will return to its befana hag as soon as its assigned task is completed.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The gryla hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit 4} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The gryla hag has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Smell Disobediance
entries: The gryla hag can determine, by scent, whether a creature has knowingly broken a law or disobeyed a command given to it by an authority figure within the last 24 hours.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gryla hag makes one claw attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Create Coal Heart (1/Day)
entries: The gryla hag rips the heart out of the corpse of one humanoid or a Large or smaller giant within 5 feet of her that died within the past minute. If the creature had knowingly disobeyed a law or a command given to it by an authority figure within the last 24 hours, the gryla hag crushes the heart in her hand, compressing it into a lump of coal in a flash of light. The lump of coal contains the creature's soul, which can only be freed by burning the coal, a process which takes 1 hour.

A gryla hag is a monstrous hag. Hunched and twisted, these towering hags easily stand at an imposing 8 feet tall, and with their huge tusks and horns they are among the most frightening hags to behold. These hags prefer to lair in mountains and in fields of volcanic stone, making their homes in caves or beneath rocks.

entries.name: Devil Dealers
entries: Bardic lore states that the first gryla hag was a human woman who made a deal with a minor devil. This woman was strong, willful, and proud, beloved by all and considered the light of her town. When the devil came to collect its price she challenged it to a hunting competition for her soul. The devil accepted. However, the devil did not expect this woman to hunt it, and when her arrows felled the devil it granted her a cursed boon. She would live forever, but her youth would only persist if she continued to pay it one sinful soul each year.

As the years wound on and the woman continued to corrupt those around her to extend her own life, and soon those who had once admired her found her wickedness to be repulsive. Soon her loneliness overwhelmed her, and she gradually transformed into the monstrous creature known as the gryla hag.

entries.name: Soul Snatchers
entries: The infernal touch of a gryla hag's existence can be seen in how she can smell disobedience and capture the souls of wrong doers in their compressed hearts. These coal hearts can be used for many things, but they are most often used to assuage the hag's bitter loneliness, either by trading to devils for companionship or by using them to animate mockeries of life to keep her company. These hags will always seek to surround themselves with companions, often taking on devils or trolls as husbands and adopting goblins, orcs, or wicked fey as children. However, their desire to be admired and loved always leads them to push their companions away.

entries.name: A Gryla Hag's Lair
entries: A gryla hag prefers to lair in caves which they festoon with ornaments of animal pelts and bones. Their lairs are often occupied by their husband, usually an ogre or troll, and adopted children, often goblins or spined devils.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A gryla hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions.

items: The hag grants itself or one creature loyal to it the benefits of the {@spell blur} spell until initiative count 20 of the following round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful gryla hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Ghostlight torches can be found throughout the region. These may be harmless lights, replicating the effects of {@spell continual light}, or they may be immobile will-o-wisps which attack creatures that get too close.

entries: When the hag dies, this effect fade after {@dice 1d10} days.

entries.name: Effigy
entries: If the gryla hag has in its possession both the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no more than 24 hours and the coal heart of the creature (see the Create Coal Heart action), she can replace the creature's entrails with straw and pebbles, then bind the creature's soul to its body using its coal heart in a ritual that takes 3 hours. The creature then animates as an effigy. The effigy uses the creature's original statistics except that it is a construct, it is lawful evil, and it must obey the orders of the gryla hag that made it. Additionally, the creature's weight is reduced by 25%.

These effigies are used by the hag for a variety of purposes. She may replace a parent with an effigy of itself to torment its children, or use an effigy as a guard, or even take one as a husband or child. The effigy's behavior will be little altered at first, but over time its behavior will degrade, causing it to spend long periods of time staring at nothing or performing the same task over and over again. Additionally, they cannot digest food, so any food consumed by the effigy will simply rot in its body if not manually removed.
A gryla hag can only have 3 effigies active at a time.

monster.name: Elder Gryla Hag

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder gryla hag's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The elder gryla hag has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Smell Disobediance
entries: The  elder gryla hag can determine, by scent, whether a creature has knowingly broken a law or disobeyed a command given to it by an authority figure within the last 24 hours.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder gryla hag fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The elder gryla hag has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The  elder gryla hag makes one claw attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Poisonous Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) poison damage. A target hit by the bite must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the target becomes immune to the poison damage from this attack for 24 hours, but can still take damage as normal.

action.name: Create Coal Heart (3/Day)
entries: The  elder gryla hag rips the heart out of the corpse of one humanoid or a Large or smaller giant within 5 feet of her that died within the past minute. If the creature had knowingly disobeyed a law or a command given to it by an authority figure within the last 24 hours, the  elder gryla hag crushes the heart in her hand, compressing it into a lump of coal in a flash of light. The lump of coal contains the creature's soul, which can only be freed by burning the coal, a process which takes 1 hour.

legendaryHeader: The  elder gryla hag can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The  elder gryla hag regains spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The  elder gryla hag makes one claw attack.

legendary.name: Curse (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The  elder gryla hag casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Punishment (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The  elder gryla hag casts {@spell command} ({@dc 17}) on one creature that she can see. Even if the target succeeds on the saving throw against the spell, it still takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage.

A gryla hag is a monstrous hag. Hunched and twisted, these towering hags easily stand at an imposing 8 feet tall, and with their huge tusks and horns they are among the most frightening hags to behold. These hags prefer to lair in mountains and in fields of volcanic stone, making their homes in caves or beneath rocks.

entries.name: Devil Dealers
entries: Bardic lore states that the first gryla hag was a human woman who made a deal with a minor devil. This woman was strong, willful, and proud, beloved by all and considered the light of her town. When the devil came to collect its price she challenged it to a hunting competition for her soul. The devil accepted. However, the devil did not expect this woman to hunt it, and when her arrows felled the devil it granted her a cursed boon. She would live forever, but her youth would only persist if she continued to pay it one sinful soul each year.

As the years wound on and the woman continued to corrupt those around her to extend her own life, and soon those who had once admired her found her wickedness to be repulsive. Soon her loneliness overwhelmed her, and she gradually transformed into the monstrous creature known as the gryla hag.

entries.name: Soul Snatchers
entries: The infernal touch of a gryla hag's existence can be seen in how she can smell disobedience and capture the souls of wrong doers in their compressed hearts. These coal hearts can be used for many things, but they are most often used to assuage the hag's bitter loneliness, either by trading to devils for companionship or by using them to animate mockeries of life to keep her company. These hags will always seek to surround themselves with companions, often taking on devils or trolls as husbands and adopting goblins, orcs, or wicked fey as children. However, their desire to be admired and loved always leads them to push their companions away.

entries.name: Covens
entries: A gryla hag that is part of a coven (see the “Hag Covens” sidebar in the {@i Monster Manual}) has a challenge rating of 13 (10,000 XP).

entries.name: A Gryla Hag's Lair
entries: A gryla hag prefers to lair in caves which they festoon with ornaments of animal pelts and bones. Their lairs are often occupied by their husband, usually an ogre or troll, and adopted children, often goblins or spined devils.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: A gryla hag that has attained the status of grandmother or auntie may have a handful of lair actions available to it. Consult {@i Volo's Guide to Monsters} pg. 59 for more detail on hag lair actions.

items: The hag grants itself or one creature loyal to it the benefits of the {@spell blur} spell until initiative count 20 of the following round.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region within 1 mile of a powerful gryla hag's lair is warped by her magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Ghostlight torches can be found throughout the region. These may be harmless lights, replicating the effects of {@spell continual light}, or they may be immobile will-o-wisps which attack creatures that get too close.

entries: When the hag dies, this effect fade after {@dice 1d10} days.

entries.name: Effigy
entries: If the gryla hag has in its possession both the corpse of a creature that has been dead for no more than 24 hours and the coal heart of the creature (see the Create Coal Heart action), she can replace the creature's entrails with straw and pebbles, then bind the creature's soul to its body using its coal heart in a ritual that takes 3 hours. The creature then animates as an effigy. The effigy uses the creature's original statistics except that it is a construct, it is lawful evil, and it must obey the orders of the gryla hag that made it. Additionally, the creature's weight is reduced by 25%.

These effigies are used by the hag for a variety of purposes. She may replace a parent with an effigy of itself to torment its children, or use an effigy as a guard, or even take one as a husband or child. The effigy's behavior will be little altered at first, but over time its behavior will degrade, causing it to spend long periods of time staring at nothing or performing the same task over and over again. Additionally, they cannot digest food, so any food consumed by the effigy will simply rot in its body if not manually removed.
A gryla hag can only have 3 effigies active at a time.

immune.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The hoarfroster can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hoarfroster has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the hoarfroster has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hoarfroster makes two touch attacks.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 2}) cold damage, and the target's Strength score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}. The target dies if this reduces its Strength to 0. Otherwise, the reduction lasts until the target finishes a short or long rest.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The hoarfroster exhales an icy blast of cold air in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, on a failed saving throw the creature contracts Consuming Cold (see “Consuming Cold” in the info section).
A creature killed by this attack becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.

A hoarfroster is an incorporeal fey spirit of hatred and ice and looks like a gaunt, spectral elf made of whirling snow. They dwell alone or in pairs, preferring to lair in small caves, burrows, and burial mounds with no entrances. These fey despise light and warmth, and any creatures that brings either into the solitude of their homes are viciously hounded by the hoarfroster's debilitating touch and frigid breath until they succumb to the cold and perish.

entries.name: Night Hunters
entries: A hoarfroster has no need for either food or drink. However, it still feels compelled to kill any living creatures it encounters, especially humanoids. Luckily, hoarfrosters despise daylight and refuse to leave their lairs when the sun is in the sky. As such, the land occupied by a hoarfroster is all but totally devoid of nocturnal animals.

entries.name: Deadly Cold
entries: A hoarfroster carries with it a supernatural disease that causes slow, miserable death. Known as consuming cold, this disease causes creatures infected by it to slowly waste away until they freeze solid. Elves are especially fearful of this disease, as the corpse of an elf that dies from this disease gives birth to a new hoarfroster the following year. For this reason, the bodies of elves that died from cold are often burned.

entries.name: Consuming Cold
entries: Consuming cold is a supernatural disease that can be contracted through contact with a hoarfroster or simply through exposure to extreme cold in an area under the influence of the Feywild. Infection occurs through contact with a hoarfroster or when a creature in an area of extreme cold either within the Feywild or in an area with a heavy influence by the Feywild meets one of the following conditions. When a creature fails a Constitution saving throw to resist exposure to intense cold, roll a {@dice d6}. If a creature fails a Constitution saving throw to resist gaining a level of exhaustion from a supernatural effect, roll a {@dice d8}. If a creature fails a Constitution saving throw against an effect that deals cold damage, roll a {@dice d12}. On a roll of 3 or lower of these dice, the creature also contracts Consuming Cold.

Upon infection, the infected creature suffers one level of exhaustion. An infected creature regains only half the normal number of hit points from spending Hit Dice and no hit points from finishing a long rest.

At the end of each long rest, an infected creature must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the character gains one level of exhaustion. If a creature dies as a result of these exhaustion levels, its body freezes solid. If an elf dies while infected with this disease, a hoarfroster rises from its body a year later if its body is frozen at the time.

If a creature succeeds on its saving throw made against this disease at the end of a long rest after having spent the last 24 hours or longer in a warm or hotter environment, it reduces its exhaustion level by one. If it loses all exhaustion levels while in a warm or hotter environment, it is cured of consuming cold.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hoary hunter's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
will: {@spell counterspell} ({@i against spells that deal fire damage only})

2e: {@spell plane shift} ({@i self and mount only})

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The hoary hunter has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The hoary hunter's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Rejuvenation
entries: If the hoary hunter is killed, it dissolves into snow. If its master is still alive, the hoary hunter gains a new body in {@dice 1d10} days, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within its master's lair.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the hoary hunter has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the hoary hunter fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Winter Sight
entries: The hoary hunter ignores any light or heavy obscurement created by snow or fog.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hoary hunter can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes three longsword attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 10 ({@damage 1d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with both hands, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage. If a creature is reduced to 0 hit points by an attack by this weapon, the hoary hunter can attempt to capture the target's soul in the sword. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or its soul is captured by the hoary hunter's sword and it dies instantly.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the hoary hunter's choice that is within 120 feet of the hoary hunter and aware of It must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the hoary hunter's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

bonus.name: Sword of Specters
entries: The hoary hunter's sword is an extension of its spirit and cannot be disarmed from it. The sword can have up to 10 spirits to it, and has {@dice 1d6 + 4} spirits bound to it. As a bonus action, the hoary hunter presents its sword and calls up the enslaved spirits of those it has captured in it; any number of souls bound to its sword arise in unoccupied spaces within 15 feet of the hoary hunter. The {@creature specters|specter} act right after the hoary hunter on the same initiative count and fight until they're destroyed. They disappear when the hoary hunter is destroyed. The hoary hunter can dismiss these specters as a bonus action. A specter killed is destroyed and passes into the afterlife.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The hoary hunter makes one weapon attack.

legendary.name: Command Thrall
entries: The hunter commands one creature under its control or {@condition charmed} by it to use its reaction to move up to its speed or make one weapon attack.

legendary.name: Magic (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The hoary hunter casts a spell from its Innate Spellcasting with a casting time of 1 action.

A hoary hunter is a fey spirit made from wind, snow, and the soul of a legendary warrior. Powerful archfey of cold such as the Prince of Frost and deities of winter such as Auril can create a hoary hunter from the soul of a powerful mortal sworn to their service. These fey spirits appear as tall, statuesque beings made of snow, their hair and clothes constantly tugged by unseen winds. A hoary hunter is utterly loyal to its master, and so long as its master persists the hoary hunter persists as well, returning to life even if slain.

entries.name: Faultless Champion
entries: The spirit used to create a hoary hunter is chosen for its obsession with perfection and its loyalty to its master. These fey are given an asperii blackheart to ride, and on its back a hoary hunter pursues those that have displeased their master to dominate or slay. When the hunter kills a victim, it captures their spirit in its sword to return to its master or to be summoned and commanded as the hoary hunter pleases.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The boggle can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Paranoia Oil
entries: The boggle excretes nonflammable oil from its pores. When a creature makes contact with the oil with exposed skin, whether through direct contact with the boggle or with an item coated in the boggle's oil, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or become wracked with paranoia for 1 minute. While under the effects of this oil, the target is {@condition frightened} of the first creature that it sees and has disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the boggle's oil for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The boggle has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

action.name: Pummel
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage and the target is subjected to the boggle's oil..

action.name: Oil Coating {@recharge 6}
entries: The boggle coats one Medium or smaller object or a 5-foot square of ground or wall with its oil. The oil lasts for 1 hour.

bonus.name: Dimensional Rift
entries: The boggle can create an {@condition invisible} and immobile rift within an opening or frame it can see within 5 feet of it, provided that the space is no bigger than 10 feet on any side. The dimensional rift bridges the distance between that space and any point within 30 feet of it that the boggle can see or specify by distance and direction (such as "30 feet straight up"). While next to the rift, the boggle can see through it and is considered to be next to the destination as well, and anything the boggle puts through the rift (including a portion of its body) emerges at the destination. Only the boggle can use the rift, and it lasts until the end of the boggle's next turn.

Hobs are diminutive fey born from powerful emotions of humanoids. They often live in or around the homes of humanoids, though they may range far and wide on their own. They naturally encourage the sort of emotion that gave rise to them. They prefer to remain unseen by humanoids, using hiding places and invisibility to avoid notice, and those who attempt to reveal their existence may find themselves on the receiving end of their resident hob's mischief.

A boggle is born from feelings of loneliness and isolation. The far rarer blue boggle is born from especially intense feelings of loneliness and isolation brought on by blizzards. Becoming cut off from the rest of the world can cause fear and mistrust to rapidly breed, causing people to turn against their friends and family. Psyches gradually crumble, alliances break down, and madness takes hold. A blue boggle is the embodiment of this paranoia, and the insidious oil that it excretes easily spreads fear and mistrust.

These fey make their burrow in massive snowdrifts near those that they torment. If their victims die of starvation or exposure, the boggle may take up residence in their home amid their rotting carcasses, or it may drag their bodies into the warrens it has dug within the deep snowdrifts.

monster.name: Nisse
languages: and the language of the house it resides in

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The nisse's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 10}, {@hit 2} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The nisse has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Outsize Strength
entries: While grappling, the nisse is considered to be Medium. Also, wielding a heavy weapon doesn't impose disadvantage on its attack rolls.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts
entries: The nisse can communicate with beasts as if they shared a language.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} until cured with {@spell lesser restoration} or similar magic. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creature cannot recover hit points through natural means such as a long or short rest.

action.name: Invisibility
entries: The nisse magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks or casts a spell, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the nisse wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

Hobs are diminutive fey born from powerful emotions of humanoids. They often live in or around the homes of humanoids, though they may range far and wide on their own. They naturally encourage the sort of emotion that gave rise to them. They prefer to remain unseen by humanoids, using hiding places and invisibility to avoid notice, and those who attempt to reveal their existence may find themselves on the receiving end of their resident hob's mischief.

A boggle is born from feelings of loneliness and isolation. The far rarer blue boggle is born from especially intense feelings of loneliness and isolation brought on by blizzards. Becoming cut off from the rest of the world can cause fear and mistrust to rapidly breed, causing people to turn against their friends and family. Psyches gradually crumble, alliances break down, and madness takes hold. A blue boggle is the embodiment of this paranoia, and the insidious oil that it excretes easily spreads fear and mistrust.

These fey make their burrow in massive snowdrifts near those that they torment. If their victims die of starvation or exposure, the boggle may take up residence in their home amid their rotting carcasses, or it may drag their bodies into the warrens it has dug within the deep snowdrifts.

trait.name: Frigid Aura
entries: A creature that touches the elemental or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

trait.name: Ice Glide
entries: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical ice and snow. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it is moving through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

Composed equally of elemental air and elemental water, the ice elemental is a lumbering mass of living ice. These elementals can glide through ice and snow as easily as if they were liquid, and can force their way through soil and earth just as a winter frost pierces the ground. Creatures in arctic landscapes have a great deal to fear from these plodding glaciers, as they can pinpoint the location of any creature in direct physical contact with snow or ice, and their bodies are so cold that they freeze creatures that make contact with them.

monster.name: Ice Elemental
senses: tremorsense 60 ft. (in ice and snow only)

trait.name: Frigid Aura
entries: A creature that touches the elemental or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

trait.name: Ice Glide
entries: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical ice and snow. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it is moving through.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage.

Composed equally of elemental air and elemental water, the ice elemental is a lumbering mass of living ice. These elementals can glide through ice and snow as easily as if they were liquid, and can force their way through soil and earth just as a winter frost pierces the ground. Creatures in arctic landscapes have a great deal to fear from these plodding glaciers, as they can pinpoint the location of any creature in direct physical contact with snow or ice, and their bodies are so cold that they freeze creatures that make contact with them.

entries.name: Variant: Frozen Solid
entries: If you so desire, a water elemental that takes 50 or more cold damage in a single turn might harden into a solid mass of ice. While solidified, it is petrified, ignoring its condition immunity. 2 rounds later, the mass of ice reforms into an ice elemental with the same number of hit points the water elemental had remaining.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The jolakott has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The jolakott has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the jolakott moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the jolakott can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Smell Broken Oaths
entries: The jolakott can determine, by scent, whether a creature within 60 feet of it has broken or otherwise failed to uphold an oath, contract, or promise within the last year. If it tastes that creature's blood, it learns the precise nature of this broken oath.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The jolakott can use its Frightful Presence. It then makes one attack with its claw.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the jolakott's choice that is within 120 feet of the jolakott and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the jolakott's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

reaction.name: Punish Failure
entries: When a creature within 5 feet of the jolakott fails on a saving throw or an attack roll, the jolakott makes one claw attack against the creature.

This massive, panther-like fey is a cruel pursuant of oath breakers. Reaching almost 15 feet tall at the shoulder, these enormous feline monsters are deadly hunters. When the time of yule arrives, it is released from its dark home to hunt. A jolakott can only hunt those who have failed to uphold oaths that they have made to devour, though they may defend themselves. These oaths may be as serious as oaths taken to protect one's homeland or as minor as a failure to knit as many socks as promised. They cruel beasts have no concept of mercy or clemency. They care only about satisfying their year-long hunger. Crueler than any cat, the jolakott will draw out the death of its prey, playfully batting it to and fro while describing in detail the crimes that they committed.

entries.name: Yule Hunters
entries: Beings that hunt for sinners such as devils, night hags, and grylla hags are particularly fond of jolakott, as they make searching for new victims substantially easier. A jolakott is under no compunction to obey these creatures, though, so those creatures that wish to form an alliance with a jolakott would be wise to offer them a good deal or risk being treated to the jolakott's teeth and claws.

monster.name: Julbocken
languages: understands Common and Sylvan but can't speak

trait.name: Aura of the Lingering Harvest
entries: Nonmagical, edible vegetable matter within 300 feet of the julbocken is not subject to spoilage. So long as it remains in the aura, such food cannot be effected by poison, disease, mold, insects, or other contaminants. Edible vegetable matter that remains in the aura for 24 continuous hours are purified of any such contaminants.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the julbocken moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target  takes an extra 2 {@damage 1d4} bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 10} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The julbocken has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Summer's Fortitude
entries: The julbocken and any friendly creatures in physical contact with it have advantage on Constitution saving throws.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

A julbocken is a goat-shaped construct made from straw or corn husks. These constructs are made by farmers in regions with bitter cold winters to provide a safe home for they fey that tend to their fields to sleep during the winter. The last sheaf of grain or husk of corn collected in the harvest is used as the heart of this construct, and the body is constructed from straw and grass gathered all throughout the year. Once finished, it is left out in the field so that the fey spirit that protects the field might enter it. Once the farmers find the julbocken within the barn, they know that the spirit of the harvest has safely hidden itself away.

entries.name: Sleepwalking
entries: A julbocken is not like most constructs. It rarely moves, as the fey spirit that within it truly is asleep. When it does rouse itself into movement, it moves as if in a dream. It may wander aimlessly, making it necessary for the family tending to it to seek it out, or cause small acts of mischief like those committed by true goats. However, the benefits of a julbocken make these minor issues more than worth it. Even when asleep, the julbocken's presence prevents stored food from spoiling, and those in contact with a julbocken are more resilient against disease, cold, and hunger.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the killer spruce remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal spruce tree.

trait.name: Rooted
entries: The killer spruce is rooted into the ground. It cannot be pushed or pulled without being uprooted. Uprooting it requires a successful {@dc 30} Strength check made by a Huge or larger creature. If uprooted, the killer spruce is {@condition incapacitated}, and if left uprooted for 1 week the killer spruce dies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The killer spruce makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. If its saving throw result is 5 or lower, the {@condition poisoned} target falls {@condition unconscious} for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature takes an action to shake it awake.

reaction.name: Last Resort
entries: If the killer spruce is reduced to 0 hp, it attempts to fall on the creatures that killed it. Any creatures within a 20 feet long line that is 15 feet wide must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be automatically hit by the killer spruce's Slam attack. The slam attack counts as a critical hit.

A killer spruce is an ill-tempered tree that can stand no other kinds of life near it aside from fey. Resembling common spruce trees, a killer spruce resides in the same cold weather environments of a common spruce and can only be distinguished from its mundane cousins by the complete absence of animal tracks below it. Its needles are harder and stronger than a common spruce, but by the time you are close enough to examine its needles, it has already attacked.

entries.name: Hateful Trees
entries: A killer spruce attacks with hard branches covered in sharp needles capable of injected a drowsy venom into its victims. Once it has begun its attack, only the slaughter of its victims or its own death will stop its wrath. Even in death, a killer spruce does not relent in its hatred and it will attempt to fall on its hated enemies in the hopes of bringing them down with it.

entries.name: Fey Friends
entries: Killer spruces despise all living creatures, save for fey and the friends of fey. For reasons unknown, killer spruces allow pixies, sprites, and dryads to frolic totally unperturbed beneath their branches. However, they utterly despise elves, especially eladrin, and will viciously attack any elves that come within reach of its branches.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The mari lwyd's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The mari lwyd can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Punish the Miserly
entries: A creature has disadvantage on saving throws against spells cast by the mari lwyd if it has denied a request made by the mari lwyd or its allies for food, drink, or aid within the last hour.

trait.name: Season's Sanctuary
entries: A creature who targets the mari lwyd with an attack or a harmful spell must first make a Wisdom saving throw ({@dc 14}). On a failed save, the creature must choose a new target or lose the attack or spell. Once a creature succeeds on this saving throw, it does not need to make it again against this mari lwyd for 24 hours.

action.name: Vicious Mockery (Cantrip)
entries: The mari lwyd tells an insult filled joke at the expense of a creature that can hear it within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 4d4}) psychic damage and have disadvantage on all attack rolls it makes before the end of its next turn.

action.name: Wassailing Spirit
entries: The mari lwyd grants its blessing to up to 6 creatures within 60 feet of it. Until the start of the mari lwyd's next turn, an affected target adds {@dice 1d6} to all its attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws.

The mari lwyd is a fey spirit of merriment, the embodiment of the old tradition of wassailing. It takes the form of a tall, gaunt specter with a grinning horse skull for a head, a ribbons and holly on its brow and twinkling glass orbs for its eyes. It attaches itself to rowdy groups of singers, dancers, or warriors, empowering them with its blessings and encouraging them towards feats of bravery and merriment.

entries.name: Let Us In!
entries: The mari lwyd is the spirit of wassailing, and wassailing is not a polite tradition. It is rowdy, joyous, and aggressive. A group of wassailers goes round to the houses of the wealthy, singing bawdy songs and demanding libations in exchange. When the master of the house refuses to acquiesce, they open themselves up to the influence of the mari lwyd, which can compel them into acts of buffoonery while its allies cause mayhem. The wealthy will often offer handsome bounties for the head of a mari lwyd to prevent this possibility.

trait.name: Aura of Fear
entries: Any beast or humanoid that starts its turn within 10 feet of the meenlock must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the start of the creature's next turn.

trait.name: Fear of Fire and Light
entries: If the meenlock takes fire or radiant damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn. The meenlock also has disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight while in bright light.

trait.name: Melt in the Sun
entries: The meenlock takes 5 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. The meenlock's maximum hit points decreases by 5 for every hour spent in a temperature above freezing. If the meenlock's hit points are reduced to zero by either of these conditions, it melts into a puddle of dirty water and black viscera.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The meenlock makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 3d4 + 2}) slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 hour. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Ovipositor
entries: The meenlock injects a creature within 5 feet of it that is {@condition paralyzed} or {@condition unconscious} with {@dice 2d4} meenlock eggs. The target takes 2 {@damage 1d4} piercing damage and must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or become infected with a disease that nourishes and supports the eggs. The creature remains infected for 3 months. The eggs grow and gestate when the host feels fear. After the host has felt at least 1 hour's worth of fear its stomach becomes distended and it feels unwell, its speed is halved, and it has disadvantage on attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws. After two hours worth of fear, the target is so swollen that it is {@condition incapacitated} and its speed is zero. After three hours worth of fear, the meenlocks chew their way out of the host's body, killing it in the process.

One continuous hour of sunlight cures the disease, and the disease cannot progress while the creature is within 5 feet of an area of flame equal to or larger than a campfire. If the disease is cured before the emergence of the meenlocks, the unborn meenlocks are disintegrated.

bonus.name: Shadow Teleport {@recharge 5}
entries: The meenlock can teleport to an unoccupied space within 30 feet of it, provided that both the space it's teleporting from and its destination are in dim light or darkness. The destination need not be within line of sight.

Meenlock are horrific, insectoid fey that are born from fear and lurk in shadow. However, even more terrible are the longnight mothers born during the long, endless nights of the far norther winters. A longnight mother is larger, stronger, and smarter than a common meenlock, with carapaces like hard black ice and eyes like glowing pinpricks of hatred. However, their most dangerous trait is their ovipositor, which can inject meenlock eggs into its victim. These eggs gestate as their host experiences fear, swelling until a handful of new meenlock burst from their victim's stomach. When a longnight mother is born, a small colony of meenlocks can rapidly multiply into an infestation that threatens an entire region until the sun returns, bringing the light and warmth that melts a longnight mother.

entries.name: Incorporating into Icewind Dale
entries: The endless night brought on by Auril has created the perfect conditions for longnight mothers to arise, and these wretched creatures are causing meenlock numbers to rapidly multiply. Meenlocks can be found lurking all throughout the dark places of Icewind Dale.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The cheimon's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The cheimon can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The cheimon has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts
entries: The cheimon can communicate with beasts as if they shared a language.

action.name: Cold Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Wall of Ice {@recharge 6}
entries: The cheimon magically forms an opaque wall of ice on a solid surface it can see within 60 feet of it. The wall is 1 foot thick and up to 30 feet long and 10 feet high, or it's a hemispherical dome up to 20 feet in diameter.

When the wall appears, each creature in its space is pushed out of it by the shortest route. The creature chooses which side of the wall to end up on, unless the creature is {@condition incapacitated}. The creature then makes a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The wall lasts for 1 minute or until the cheimon is {@condition incapacitated} or dies. The wall can be damaged and breached; each 10-foot section has AC 5, 30 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage, and immunity to acid, cold, necrotic, poison, and psychic damage.

Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

Cheimon are solitary spirits of ice bound to glaciers and icebergs. A cheimon can swim through the ice of its home as easily as it swims through water, and they spend hours luxuriating in the magnificent cold of the ice. They reside far from the homes of mortals, and while some avoid mortals at all costs, others can't help but be fascinated by the short-lived creatures that so shun the icy realms that these nymphs adore. Travelers near a cheimon's home may catch glimpses of a humanoid shape moving beneath the surface of the ice, watching them in fascination, but these fey are shy and rarely show themselves.

entries.name: Glacier Guides
entries: Glaciers can shape a landscape over thousands of years, and cheimon understand this intrinsically. They can feel the whole history of their iceberg within the cracks that groan through it, and from that history they can learn the history of the land it has traveled across. As such, cheimon often possess a great deal of hidden knowledge, and if a supplicant can propitiate them with gifts, they may learn much of the history of their lands.

entries.name: Iceberg Riders
entries: The cheimon that are bound to icebergs spend much of their lives traveling across the seas. They learn the stories of the currents that push them and the fish that swim by them. They see the patterns of the clouds and the storms of the seas. They have seen many strange things, and those that can convince them to divulge their knowledge can learn much about the world far beyond the horizon.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The khione's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Hide in Plain Sight
entries: The khione has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide while it is in a snowy field.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The khione has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The khione makes two attacks, choosing from either its freezing touch or snowball for each.

action.name: Freezing Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) cold damage.

action.name: Snowball
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 3} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) cold damage.

action.name: Snow Flurry (3/Day)
entries: The khione creates a 10-foot radius sphere of whirling snow centered on itself, heavily obscuring the area. The flurry lasts until the start of its next turn.
