Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

The khione are alseids, nymphs of fields, who embrace the cold of winter, becoming creatures of snow and joy. They love to observe snowball fights, sledding, snowman crafting, and all the other joyful diversions that winter brings. However, if the pristine snow of homes are threatened, they can bring the full fury of winter down upon the heads of their enemies.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The kostro's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

3e: {@spell grease} ({@i creates slick ice instead of grease})

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The kostro can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Ice Dancer
entries: The kostro can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. While moving on a surface composed of ice, the kostro' speed is tripled.

trait.name: Invisible in Water
entries: The kostro is {@condition invisible} while fully immersed in water.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The kostro has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Thin Ice
entries: While moving on a surface composed of ice, the kostro can move in a loop which encompasses an area no larger than four 5-foot squares. Once the kostro completes the loop, the ice within the loop becomes incorporeal to a depth of 5 feet until the end of the kostro's turn.

Any creatures standing on the ice when it becomes incorporeal must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or fall through the ice. If a creature only partially travels through the ice before it becomes corporeal again, then it is {@condition restrained} by the ice. A creature {@condition restrained} by the ice can escape if it or another creature uses its Action to make a successful {@dc 14} Strength check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The kostro makes two psychic touch attacks.

action.name: Psychic Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) psychic damage.

Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

Naiads are spirits of water, living in rivers, lakes, and other aquatic realms. When their homes freeze during the winter, some may wait in slumber in their beds of mud and river weeds until the sun thaws the ice. However, others may embrace the transformation and become kostro, gliding gracefully across the smooth surface of the ice in intricate dances.

entries.name: Beautiful but Treacherous
entries: A kostro whiles away its time gliding, spinning, and leaping across the ice that covers its home. These dances are magnificent to behold, but to see a dance without the permission of the kostro is to invite disaster. If a spy is discovered, the kostro may attempt to lure them out onto the ice, only to dance a circle around them to make the ice as insubstantial as air to send them plummeting into the water below. Those that decline the kostro's invitation may still find themselves tormented by the winter spirits that tend to the kostro's needs.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The nootaiq's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The nootaiq can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aquatic Invisibility
entries: If immersed in water, the nootaiq can make itself {@condition invisible} as a bonus action. It remains {@condition invisible} until it leaves the water, ends the invisibility as a bonus action, or dies.

trait.name: Armor Dependent
entries: The nootaiq wears a suit of gleaming, ice like armor which holds the creature's spirit. The armor has an AC and hit points equal to that of the nootaiq, but the armor can't be directly harmed while the nootaiq wears it. If the armor is destroyed, the nootaiq becomes {@condition poisoned} and dies within 1 hour. A nootaiq is willing to do anything in its power to recover the armor if it is stolen, including serving the thief.

trait.name: Ship Killer
entries: The nootaiq ignores the damage threshold of seafaring vessels when attacking with its ice trident.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts
entries: The nootaiq can communicate with beasts as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the nootaiq fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The nootaiq makes three attacks with its ice trident.

action.name: Snowball
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage in melee or at range, or 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage if used with both hands, plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

action.name: Water Lash
entries: The nootaiq causes a 5-foot cube of water within 60 feet of it to take a shape of its choice and strike one target it can see within 5 feet of that water. The target must make a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and if it is a Large or smaller creature, it is pushed up to 15 feet in a straight line or is knocked {@condition prone} (nootaiq's choice). On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The nootaiq makes one Ice Trident attack.

legendary.name: Ocean Magic (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The nootaiq uses Water Lash or casts an at-will from its Innate Spellcasting.

Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

The nootaiq are nereids who have bound themselves to a specific iceberg. In the dark bellies of their iceberg they forge the mantles that contain their spirits into suits of gleaming armor, freezing their hearts in the process, granting them greater control over both the waters of their homes and the ice that they have adopted into themselves.

entries.name: Iceberg Fortress
entries: A nootaiq rules over its iceberg as a castle, populating it with naiads, nereids, and creatures of cold and vicious winter. They roam the oceans in these mobile fortresses, searching for ships to founder with the merciless strikes of their icebergs and weapons. Many nootaiq swear fealty to powerful being of cruel winter such as Auril or the Prince of Frost, while others are content to see to their own desires.

entries.name: Cruel Winter
entries: Winter is a time of suffering, of cruel storms and bitter cold and wretched disease. A nootaiq wields all of these forces against mortals, assaulting them with blasts of deadly cold, burning acid, vicious lightning, and debilitating disease. These nymphs seek only to spread the suffering of winter to their victims.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The orithyia's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The orithyia has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orithyia makes two attacks, choosing from cutting winds or frostbite for each.

action.name: Cutting Winds.
entries: {@atk ms,rs} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 60 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage in melee or at range, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Frostbite (Cantrip)
entries: The orithyia causes numbing frost to form on one creature that it can see within 60 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage, and it has disadvantage on the next weapon attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

action.name: Armor of Frost (3rd-Level Spell: 1/Day)
entries: A spectral frost covers the orithyia, granting it 15 temporary hit points. If a creature hits it with a melee attack while it has these hit points, the creature takes 5 cold damage.

reaction.name: Rebuke Flame {@recharge 6}
entries: The orithyia casts counterspell on a spell that deals fire damage. If the spell is successfully countered, the creature that attempted to cast the spell takes 5 cold damage.

Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

The orithyia are the beautiful nymphs of cold winds. They race across frigid landscapes, glorying in the bitter cold and magnificent ice. During the warm months, they live on the tops of freezing mountains or retreat to the eternal winter of northern tundras, but when winter descends they return to dance through blizzards without a care.

entries.name: Biting Winds
entries: Though orithyia prefer to spend their time exploring the joy of their existence, they take the duty of protecting their homes seriously. If the mountains or tundras that they reside in are threatened, they don armor of magical frost and enter battle, fighting their foes with numbing cold and slashes of cutting wind, using magic to disrupt the battlefield and weaken dangerous foes.

entries.name: Fear of Fire
entries: Orithyia fear fire above all else, and they are quick to extinguish any flames that they encounter, no matter how small. Any attempt to create or wield fire is met with vicious retribution. They are right to fear flame, as exposure to warmth causes their delicate bodies to melt away into steam.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The pitys's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The pitys has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The pitys can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Tree Stride
entries: Once on its turn, the pitys can use 10 feet of movement to step magically into one living tree within reach and emerge from a second living tree within 60 feet of the first tree, appearing in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the second tree. Both trees must be Large or bigger.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The pitys makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target deals only half damage with weapon attacks that use Strength.

reaction.name: Spiny Shield
entries: The pitys adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the pitys must see the attacker and be wielding its shield. Whether or not the attack is able to overcome the pitys's new AC, the attacker takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) piercing damage if it is within 5 feet of the pitys.

Nymphs are physical embodiments of the beauty of nature whose lives are bound either to a location such as a tree or a mountain, an object such as a mantle or a veil, or a natural phenomenon such as a flame or a cloud. Whether male or female, a nymph is always heartbreakingly lovely and incredibly perilous.

During the winter months, most dryads retreat into torpor, slumbering within the hearts of their trees until the spring reawakens them. They are the most vulnerable at this time, unable to defend themselves or their homes. To protect their forests, a dryad may take on the role of an evergreen guard. These dryads bear the mantle of holly and wield swords of wood imbued with a slumbering venom and shields bristling with spines. They wield the twin forces of the cold embrace of winter and the life that sleeps within it. Those who would threaten an evergreen guard's home will find themselves at the mercy of thorn, cold, and implacable slumber.

trait.name: Air Form
entries: The orglash can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Cold Absorption
entries: Whenever the orglash is subjected to cold damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the cold damage dealt.

trait.name: Cold Regeneration
entries: The orglash regains 5 hit points at the start of its turn if in an environment of extreme cold. If the orglash takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the orglash's next turn. The orglash dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The orglash has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: World Bound
entries: The orglash is treated as a creature native to the Material Plane for the purposes of spells such as {@spell banishment} and {@spell banishing smite}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orglash makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cold Blast {@recharge 4}
entries: The orglash exhales an icy blast of freezing air in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 54 ({@damage 12d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, a creature that fails on its saving throw has its speed reduced by half for {@dice 1d4} rounds. A creature killed by this effect becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.

An orglash is an elemental spirit of cold wind bound to the material world. These elementals are created by fey spirits, and their lives are intrinsically bound to the land that they were woven from. Orglash are empowered by bitter cold, regaining health from mere exposure to frigid temperatures, and as such reside mostly on high mountain tops, coming down only during winter to roam the world.

entries.name: World Bound
entries: Because they were created from the essence of the world itself, they have no connection to the Elemental Planes and consider the Material Plane their true home.

trait.name: Bewitching Gaze
entries: If a creature starts its turn within 30 feet of the rat king and the two of them can see each other, the rat king can force the creature to make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw if the rat king isn't {@condition incapacitated}. On a failed save, the creature is affected by one of the following conditions until the start of its next turn depending on the head it made eye contact with:

items: {@b Red Eyes.} The target is under the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell.
{@b Gold Eyes.} The target is {@condition charmed} by the rat king.
{@b Green Eyes.} The target is {@condition blinded}.
{@b Blue Eyes.} The target is {@condition frightened}.
{@b Black Eyes.} The target is {@condition poisoned}.

entries: Once the rat king has imposed one of these effects on a creature, it cannot impose that effect on another creature until after the end of its next turn.

A creature that isn't surprised can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If it does so, it can't see the rat king until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If it looks at the rat king in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

trait.name: Cursed Life
entries: If the rat king is subjected to a {@spell remove curse} spell, it must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) force damage and lose a head.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the rat king fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The rat king has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The rat king's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: The rat king has five heads. While it has more than one head, the rat king has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}. Each of its heads is associated with a different color and possesses a different form of supernatural awareness.

items: {@b Red Eyes.} The head can {@spell detect magic} at will.
{@b Gold Eyes.} The head can {@spell detect thoughts} at will.
{@b Green Eyes.} The head can {@spell see invisibility} at will.
{@b Blue Eyes.} The head can {@spell detect evil and good} at will.
{@b Black Eyes.} The head can {@spell detect poison and disease} at will.

entries: Whenever the rat king takes damage from a critical hit, one of its heads dies. Whenever a head dies, the rat king loses access to the effects garnered to it by that head from the Multiple Heads and Bewitching Gaze features, as well as its ability to use its corresponding action. If all its heads die, the rat king dies.
The rat king can regrow its lost heads by eating one rat for each head lost during the course of a long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The rat king makes one attack with each of its available actions. It can use its teleport action in place of an attack it is no longer able to make.

action.name: Red Flame
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage.

action.name: Gold Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Green Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage and the target cannot recover hit points until the start of the rat king's next turn.

action.name: Green Touch
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage in melee or at range.

action.name: Black Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage in melee or at range, plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage.

action.name: Teleport
entries: The rat king magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

bonus.name: Deft Footwork
entries: The rat king can take the Dash or Disengage action on each of its turns.

bonus.name: Swarm Form
entries: The rat king magically polymorphs into a {@creature swarm of rats}, or back into its true form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. In swarm of rats form, the rat king gains the statistics of a swarm of rats, but retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and Magic Resistance and Legendary Resistance traits.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The rat king makes an attack with one of its available options.

legendary.name: Graceful Maneuver (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The rat king takes the Disengage action, and moves up to half its speed.

legendary.name: Storm or Weapons (Costs 2 Actions) {@recharge 5}
entries: The rat king spins and attacks any creature close to him. Each creature within 10 feet of the rat king must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 6d8}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

A rat king is a wretched abomination born from numerous rats bound together in terrible suffering. Possessing the small, lithe body of a child, these wretched horrors have five lolling rats heads and as many grasping arms. Filled with hatred for the cruel world that birthed them, these wretched monsters seek to spread misery and pain, dominating rats and rat-kin to seek out the vengeance they so crave.

entries.name: Born of Cruelty
entries: Old stories claim that rat kings are created when rats gather together for warmth during the winter and their tails become tangled together amid the squalor of their filthy dens. However, anyone familiar with rats will tell you that this is absurd, as rats are actually quite clean creatures. No, rat kings are born from deliberate cruelty, from evil minded people who purposefully tie the tails of rats together. This act of senseless cruelty may summon a fey spirit to possess the miserable pile, uniting their minds in suffering and fusing them into one hateful creature.

entries.name: Many Heads
entries: A rat king can have up to five heads, and each head possesses a different power. The gaze of the rat king can inflict fear, sickness, blindness, or even madness. Each head wields a different weapon or magic, and with the rat king's unnatural grace and uncanny ability to teleport, killing a rat king is no small feat. Even if you cut off its heads, if just one remains it can regrow the others by devouring its subjects, making a rat king incredibly difficult to slay.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the rat king takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the rat king can't use the same effect two turns in a row:

items: The rat king casts {@spell dominate monster} ({@dc 14}). If a creature succeeds on its saving throw against this spell, it is immune to it being cast in this way for the next 24 hours.
Up to four creatures loyal to the rat king or charmed by it that it can see use their reactions to move up to their speed and make one weapon attack.

The rat king summons one {@creature swarm of rats} in a space it can see within 30 feet of it, which is loyal to it and obeys its commands. The swarm lasts for 1 hour, or until reduced to 0 hit points or the rat king uses this lair action again.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing the rat king's lair is warped by its magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Rats within the area act as the eyes and ears of the rat king.

While within the region, the rat king can use an action to attempt to dominate any rat related creature, such as a wererat, a xvart, swarm of cranium rats. The target must make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, it is considered charmed, ignoring immunity. If a creature succeeds on its saving throw against this effect, it is immune to it for the next 24 hours.
Whispers can be heard just at the edge of hearing.

resist.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered or gilded

trait.name: Buried Treasure
entries: The redcap immediately becomes aware when any wealth that it buried is unearthed while within 10 miles of it. It can pinpoint the location of a creature in possession of any wealth that it buried.

trait.name: Cut Down to Size
entries: If the redcap hits a single target with three wicked sickle attacks in the same turn, the target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Dexterity saving throw or have its feet cut off. The target is knocked {@condition prone} if unable to stand without its feet. A creature is immune to this if it is Huge or larger, has Legendary Actions, or no feet. Such a creature instead takes an extra 21 ({@damage 6d6}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Outsize Strength
entries: While grappling, the redcap is considered to be Medium. Also, wielding a heavy weapon doesn't impose disadvantage on its attack rolls.

trait.name: Snow Tread
entries: While moving through snow, the redcap has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks that rely on sound.

trait.name: The Stink of Wealth
entries: The redcap can determine by scent how much money a creature has on its person, whether an object or piece of equipment is worth more than 100 gp, and what kind of lifestyle a creature is able to maintain. If a creature is able to maintain a wealthy or higher lifestyle, the redcap has advantage on attack rolls against the target.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The redcap makes three attacks with its wicked sickle.

action.name: Wicked Sickle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

Redcaps are born out of violence and bloodshed, and different kind of violence can create different kinds of redcaps under the right circumstances. A redcap whitefoot is born from the violence of oppression. When blood is shed while a peasant is evicted from their home or a poor man lashes out against a heartless tax collector, if that blood falls on pristine snow it may give rise to a redcap whitefoot. These redcaps, like common redcaps, must shed blood to survive, but their preferred victims are the wealthy.

entries.name: White Feet
entries: Unlike common redcaps, which wear heavy boots of clanking iron, whitefoots are barefoot. In fact, their steps are so light that they make no sound in snow, allowing them to move stealthily during the winter. However, their victims may not be so lucky. If given the opportunity, a whitefoot will cut their foes down at the ankles, sending them toppling into the cold snow. Whitefoots love to see a once mighty creature be laid low, and will take any opportunity to taunt such a creature before it dies.

entries.name: Haters of Gold
entries: They loathe the smell of gold and silver, and can detect the value of items and the wealth on a creature simply by its stink. These fey will focus their fury on creatures carrying valuable items, viciously cutting them down so that they can rip their coins, gems, and magic items away from their corpses and bury them. If a creature digs up what they have buried, the whitefoot knows immediately and hunts that creature down without mercy. Whitefoots have a good reason to despise wealth, too, as weapons that have been coated in silver or gold are especially painful to them.

monster.name: Frozen Rusalka
languages: any languages it knew in life

trait.name: Blighted Soul
entries: {@spell Detect evil and good}, {@spell commune with nature}, and other similar spells and effects identify the frozen rusalka as undead. The frozen rusalka also benefits from desecrated ground and is treated by {@spell antilife shell} as if it was an undead creature.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The frozen  rusalka can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The frozen  rusalka has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Freezing Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) cold damage and the target's speed is halved until the start of the frozen rusalka's next turn.

If a creature is hit by this attack three times within the same hour, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or become {@condition restrained} by ice for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.

reaction.name: Curse of Numbness
entries: When a creature that the frozen rusalka is allied with is reduced to 0 hit points, the creature that reduced the frozen rusalka's ally to 0 hit points must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw if it is within 60 feet of the rusalka and the frozen rusalka can see it. On a failure, the target becomes numbed. While numb, a creature has disadvantage on all attack rolls, as well as skill checks and saving throws that rely on Strength or Dexterity. At the end of each of its turns, it can repeat the save, ending the effect on itself on a success.

To the uninitiated, these mournful, incorporeal spirits appear to be ghosts. However, they are not undead, though it is a very fine distinction. A rusalka is created when mortal calls out in desperation as they die and their cries are heard by a fey being. If the mortal is willing to the terms of service set forth by the fey, their new patron rescues them from the grip of death and transforms them into an incorporeal rusalka.

entries.name: Cruel Irony
entries: When it is created, a rusalka is bound to the fate that brought its mortal existence to a close, dooming them to exist in a state of perpetual torment until released from their bonds of service. Their bond with the element that they were rescued from gives them unique powers with which they can serve their cruel patrons.

entries.name: Patron Bound
entries: A rusalka is bound to serve the fey that created it. The fey could be a powerful archfey, a cunning hag, a decadent eladrin lord, or any other being of the Feywild in possession of the knowledge of how to bind a dying soul to their service. The rusalka cannot disobey the terms of service that their patron created, and thus a rusalka is an unfailingly loyal servant.

entries.name: Life Beyond Death
entries: A rusalka doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

A frozen rusalka is created when a creature faces death from exposure to bitter cold cries out for mercy. These spirits roam the earth, inflicting the suffering of cold on all creatures that they encounter. Their touches cause frost to creep across the bodies of their victims, slowing them until they are fully encased. When suitably enraged, a frozen rusalka can levy a curse on a curse on a creature that numbs their entire body.

entries.name: Incorporating into Icewind Dale
entries: Auril loves to create frozen rusalkas out of those who freeze to death in Icewind Dale, and these wandering spirits are not uncommon in the frozen wastes. They are especially common on her island of Solstice.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the shatjan moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its ram on the same turn, the target takes an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The shatjan has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Reindeer
entries: The shatjan can communicate with reindeers as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Winter Stride
entries: The shatjan ignores any penalties imposed on its movement by deep snow, strong winds, or slick ice.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shatjan makes two weapon attacks: one with its ram and one with its spear.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Spear
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage in melee or at range, or 14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The shatjan exhales a blast of freezing wind in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The shatjan are closely related to satyrs, though they are very different from their lighthearted kin. A shatjan is a tall, powerfully built humanoid with the head of a reindeer. Perfectly adapted to the brutal cold of the north, shatjan eschew most clothing, though they do like to adorn themselves in strange runes. These stoic fey protect reindeer herds, roaming alongside them as they migrate across the tundra.

entries.name: Herd Guardians
entries: A shatjan's entire life is dedicated to guarding its herd. Typically, these fey will guard their herd in mated pairs, using spears, longbows, and their sturdy antlers to fend off any creatures that would threaten their herds. Shatjan are not concerned with protecting their herds from predators like wolves, as that is part of the natural order. Their primary concern is with humanoids, as mortals will overhunt herds into non-existence if allowed to. Mortals must first reach an agreement with the shatjan that guard a herd of reindeer before hunting from it. Hunters that break that agreement or neglect to consult with the shatjan beforehand will be subjected to their bitter cold breath weapons and their mastery of wintry terrain.

entries.name: Incorporating into Icewind Dale
entries: The Reghed barbarians view shatjan as divine manifestations of the will of the gods, and as such are always deferential to them. A shatjan will be willing to negotiate hunting rights with respectful Reghed, especially their shamans.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The bralani's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The bralani has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The bralani's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the bralani can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bralani makes three scimitar attacks or two longbow attacks.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d6 + 6}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) piercing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Whirlwind
entries: The bralani magically polymorphs into a whirlwind, or back into its humanoid form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (the bralani's choice). In whirlwind form, the bralani has the statistics of an air elemental, but retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and damage resistances and immunities.

The deserts, tundra, and open seas of the Feywild are even more harsh and unforgiving than their mortal counterparts. However, these are the favored realms of the bralani, spirits of wind and freedom. Unfettered and wild, the bralani live their lives in a glorious fugue of emotion, rapidly shifting from one feeling to the next as the mood takes them. Rage can quickly blossom into joy, which may in turn wilt into sorrow, all within a single sentence.

entries.name: Wind Folk
entries: The bralani are short and stocky, like dwarves, but that is where their similarities end. Their faces, like all sidhe, possess a distinctly elven quality, and they race joyously in the wide open spaces of the sky. Equally comfortable in both arctic tundras, sweltering deserts, and stormy seas, the bralani never sleep, roaring in delight as they dance through sandstorms and raging blizzards.

entries.name: Sidhe Shapes
entries: Every sidhe possesses two forms, their humanoid form and a second form, their sidhe shape. Some sidhe shapes take on the form of beasts, while others take the shape of ephemeral light or elemental forces. Both of these forms are their true forms, as such they cannot be forced into a different form by spells such as moonbeam. The sidhe tag counts as the shapechanger tag for the purposes of spells such as {@i polymorph}. Only cold iron can restrict this power.

{@b Cold Iron Weakness.} While in contact with cold iron, a sidhe can only assume its humanoid form. If touched with cold iron while in its second form, it automatically reverts back to its humanoid form.

immune.note: damage from non-magical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Blood Tracker
entries: If the vaukalak smells a creature's blood, it has advantage on all Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks made to find the target for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The vaukalak has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The vaukalak has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The vaukalak's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The vaukalak has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the vaukalak's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The vaukalak has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Smell Alliance
entries: The vaukalak can determine whether a creature is allied with another creature or part of an organization by smell. Additionally, it can determine the degree of loyalty that a creature possesses with another by smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vaukalak can use its Terrifying Howl. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claws (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) slashing damage.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The vaukalak exhales a blast of freezing wind in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Terrifying Howl
entries: The vaukalak unleashes an unearthly howl audible for 1 mile. Each creature that is not allied with the vaukalak that is within 120 feet of it and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened} in this way, a creature must take the Dash action and move away from the vaukalak by the safest available route on each of its turns, unless there is nowhere to move. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the vaukalak's Terrifying Howl for the next 24 hours.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Wolf
entries: The vaukalak magically polymorphs into a Large wolf, or back into its humanoid form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed or borne by the new form (the bralani's choice). In wolf form, the vaukalak's statistics remain the same except for size.

The vaukalak are beings of the brutality of nature and the hunger of winter. Appearing as powerfully built humanoids, their eyes burn with a feral light, ferocity etched in their every movement. They live on tundras and taigas, hunting beast and humanoid with equal fervor. When their joyous, mournful howls echo through the night, the wise hide indoors.

entries.name: Wolf Kin
entries: The vaukalak can take the form of wolves, and they have much in common with them. They are strong, agile, cunning, and possess incredibly sharp senses. However, the trait that they most share with wolves is their intense loyalty to their kin. A vaukalak is never encountered without pack mates. Their pack can consist of anything, from wolves, lycanthropes, savage fey, nomadic humanoids, or stranger. Whatever form their pack mates take, a vaukalak is unflichingly loyal to them. Stories exist of babies abandoned in the wilderness only to be rescued by a merciful vaukalak mother and raised as one of her own. Such humanoids who eventually return to mortal society always go on to become leaders of their kind, valuing loyalty and community above all else.

entries.name: Loyalty is Everything
entries: Vaukalak most value kinship, and displays of loyalty will garner the respect of a vaukalak. A vaukalak may spare the life of a mother willing to lay down her life to protect her child or a man willing to fight to the death to protect his people, or at the very least grant them a swift and merciful death. Vaukalak can even smell kinship on other creatures. Through scent alone, a vaukalak can detect familial relations, bonds of friendship, and even a creature's loyalty to their country, guild, or team.

entries.name: Winter Hunter
entries: A vaukalak is most alive when in the midst of a hunt, when all distractions focus down into a single point, and they feel a savage joy when they work in concert with their pack to bring down prey and taste their hot blood. Vaukalak can move easily without detection in snowy terrain, moving to an ideal ambush location before unleashing a howl that strikes fear into their prey and moving in for the kill. If threatened, they also possess the ability to unleash a cone of brutal cold against their foes.

entries.name: Vaukalak in Icewind Dale
entries: The Wolf tribe view vaukalak as holy creatures, and the vaukalak view the Wolf Tribe as distant kin. If the players successfully complete the Test of Preservation in Chapter 5, a vaukalak named Ernouf approaches Aerix Vokototh to adopt the child and raise him to fend for himself. If any of the players have earned the trust of Aerix or have come to develop a familial bond with the child, Ernouf can smell it and thanks them for their efforts, declaring them to be kin.

entries.name: Sidhe Shapes
entries: Every sidhe possesses two forms, their humanoid form and a second form, their sidhe shape. Some sidhe shapes take on the form of beasts, while others take the shape of ephemeral light or elemental forces. Both of these forms are their true forms, as such they cannot be forced into a different form by spells such as moonbeam. The sidhe tag counts as the shapechanger tag for the purposes of spells such as {@i polymorph}. Only cold iron can restrict this power.

{@b Cold Iron Weakness.} While in contact with cold iron, a sidhe can only assume its humanoid form. If touched with cold iron while in its second form, it automatically reverts back to its humanoid form.

trait.name: Frigid Body
entries: A creature that touches the virage without its permission or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The virage has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Mind Freeze Aura
entries: The virage can begin or stop producing this aura as a bonus action. Whenever a creature begins its turn within 30 feet of the virage or comes within 30 feet of the virage for the first time, it must make a {@dc 18} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure the target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) cold damage and is {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a success it takes half the damage and is not otherwise effected. Creatures immune to the {@condition charmed} condition or cold or psychic damage are immune to this effect.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of the virage includes its Charisma bonus.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The virage makes two touch attacks.

action.name: Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Captivating Call
entries: The virage speaks captivating words. Every humanoid and giant within 300 feet of it that can hear it speak must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} until the virage stops speaking. The virage may take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue speaking. It can stop this effect at any time.

While {@condition charmed} in this way, a target is {@condition incapacitated}. If the {@condition charmed} creature is more than 5 feet away from the virage, the target takes the Dash action on its turn to move toward the virage by the most direct route. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain such as a pit of spikes, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the virage, a target can repeat its saving throw. A creature can also repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns. It a creature's saving throw is successful, the effect ends on it.
A target that successfully saves is immune to this virage's Captivating Call for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: The virage covers itself and anything it is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes it look like another creature of its general size and humanoid shape. The illusion ends if the virage takes a bonus action to end it or if it dies.

action.name: Create Illusory Food
entries: The virage creates facsimiles of food and drink out of snow and frigid water, up to 10 pounds worth. The food and drink appears hearty, tastes delicious, and even seems to satisfy hunger and warm the insides of those who eat it. However, if a creature performs a successful {@dc 18} {@skill Investigation} check or views the food and drink with truesight the food is revealed to be nothing more than snow. Any creature that perceives the food for what it is tastes only snow when consuming it and does not feel satisfied or warmed by it. Creatures that do not see through the illusion of the food do not notice the deleterious effects of starvation on themselves.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Snow Flurry
entries: The virage transforms into a 5-foot radius snow flurry or back into its humanoid form. All equipment that it is wearing or carrying merge into this form. In snow form, the virage's statistics remain the same except for the following changes: it has a flying speed of 60 feet, it is ephemeral and cannot carry anything, and it is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained} as well as to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons.

Spirits of the cruelty of winter, virage are pale, beautiful fey who delight in watching mortals starve and freeze to death. Outwardly they seem charming and kind, playing the part of gracious hosts to weary travelers in their wintry realms. However, their cheerful palaces and warm food are merely illusions to fool the unwary, and visitors will find nothing but slow death.

entries.name: Courts of Ice
entries: A virage is royalty among the fey, and they attract many servants, from boreal and oread nymphs to frost pixies. However, they don't just draw the loyalty of fey. Their natural charisma and beauty often leads to them being served by frost giants, and winter obsessed druids may serve them as loyal mortal vassals. Even elementals and the undead may serve these cruel fey, ice mephits frolicking in their stone gardens and will-o-wisps lighting their halls.

entries.name: Lost to Bitterness
entries: Legend says that the first virage were once mighty heroes of the Summer Court, beautiful and kind warriors loyal to the Sun Prince. However, when the Sun Prince's true love betrayed him he threw his heart into bitterness, plunging his realm into eternal winter. The endless nights and bitter cold eventually transformed the once kind warriors into the cruel creatures they are today.

entries.name: Deadly Winter
entries: Virage are deadly foes. The very air around them is infused with a bitter silence that freezes both the mind and body, and their bodies are so infused with cruel cold that their flesh denies flame and decay, inuring them to the ravages of fire and death. When angered they can transform into clouds of raging wind, but when feeling playful they will disguise themselves as mortals and use their captivating calls to lure their victims to their death.

entries.name: A Virage's Lair
entries: A virage makes its palace of ice in out of the way locations of perpetual cold, such as snowy mountaintops. These lairs are difficult to get to, the paths fraught with peril unless the virage desires company, in which case travelers will find that the only paths in the snow lead directly to her doorstep.

entries.name: Deceptive Home
entries: If the virage wishes, it can cause the inside of its home to seem warm and welcoming. Cold walls of ice and stone may appear as thick planks of sturdy wood, and crackling fires that seem to warm its guests may be scattered throughout the lair. However, these are all illusions, and its lair is always frigid within. If a creature succeeds on a {@dc 18} {@skill Investigation} check or views the palace with truesight they perceive the true nature of the palace, seeing the building materials for what they really are and feeling no warmth from the pale illusory flames. A creature that does not perceive this illusion is still subject to the deleterious effects of extreme cold. If {@spell dispel magic} is cast on the illusion, it dispels it within a 20 foot cube.

entries.name: Incorporating into Icewind Dale
entries: All virage consider themselves to be the children of Auril in some capacity or another, and with the everlasting night that she has created they have been happily exercising their right as her children. However, the virage known as Princess Vassilia has learned that Auril has greatly weakened herself to cast her spell and sees this as an opportunity to claim the throne of the Frostmaiden.

entries.name: Sidhe Shapes
entries: Every sidhe possesses two forms, their humanoid form and a second form, their sidhe shape. Some sidhe shapes take on the form of beasts, while others take the shape of ephemeral light or elemental forces. Both of these forms are their true forms, as such they cannot be forced into a different form by spells such as moonbeam. The sidhe tag counts as the shapechanger tag for the purposes of spells such as {@i polymorph}. Only cold iron can restrict this power.

{@b Cold Iron Weakness.} While in contact with cold iron, a sidhe can only assume its humanoid form. If touched with cold iron while in its second form, it automatically reverts back to its humanoid form.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The thomil can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the thomil doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The thomil deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: World Bound
entries: The thomil is treated as a creature native to the Material Plane for the purposes of spells such as {@spell banishment} and {@spell banishing smite}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thomil makes two slam attacks. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}).

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The thomil engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw at the start of each of the thomil's turns or take 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the thomil moves, the engulfed thomil moves with it. The thomil can have only one creature engulfed at a time.

A thomil is an elemental spirit of stone bound to the material world. These elementals are created by fey spirits, and their lives are intrinsically bound to the land that they were woven from. Thomil find heat uncomfortable, so they are only active during the summer if roused into action by a direct call, spending their time instead in the form of boulders. During the winter, though, or on frigid mountaintops these elementals can be found roaming far and wide. Creatures that anger them will be buried alive within their bodies.

entries.name: World Bound
entries: Because they were created from the essence of the world itself, they have no connection to the Elemental Planes and consider the Material Plane their true home.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rimefire witch's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
will: {@spell stone shape} ({@i effects ice instead of stone})

1e: {@spell conjure elemental} ({@i as a 6th-level spell: {@creature ice elemental|TFC}, {@creature orglash|TFC} or {@creature thomil|TFC} only}
{@spell word of recall} ({@i destination is bonded to rimefire withc's lair})

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The rimefire witch is a 17th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). The rimefire witch has the following druid spells prepared:

trait.name: Animal Speaker
entries: The rimefire witch can speak with beasts as if they shared a common language.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the rimefire witch fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Rimefire Bond
entries: The rimefire witch is bonded on a deep, spiritual level with its rimefire eidolon. The rimefire witch and the eidolon always know the distance and direction to one another and can communicate telepathically regardless of intervening distance, as well as while on different planes of existence.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: he rimefire witch uses rimefire bolt twice.

action.name: Rimefire Bolt
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 11} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d10}) cold damage.

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit ({@hit 11} with {@spell shillelagh}), reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) damage if used while {@spell shillelagh} is active.

action.name: Heart Sight
entries: The rimefire witch touches a creature and magically knows the creature's current emotional state. If the target fails a {@dc 19} Charisma saving throw, the rimefire witch also knows the creature's alignment. Celestials, fiends, and undead automatically fail the saving throw.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The rimefire witch makes one quarterstaff attack.

legendary.name: Magic (Costs 1-3 Actions)
entries: The rimefire witch uses Rimefire Bolt for 2 Legendary Actions or expends one spell slot to cast a 3rd-level or lower spell, expending a number of Legendary Actions equal to the spell slot level expended.

A rimefire witch is an uldra who has taken on the sacred task of tending to a rimefire eidolon. A rimefire witch is summoned to its task by divinely sent dreams, compelled to venture across treacherous mountains or dangerous seas to unite with the shard of divinity that is the rimefire eidolon that called out to them. Once they reach their charge, they bond with it, gaining the powers of winter.

entries.name: White Witch
entries: A rimefire witch is chosen for their kindness largely because their task is to watch over the broken fragment of a dead goddess. However, they are also given great power to wield, power which can only be trusted to the kind. As such, rimefire witches always dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of others, whether it be providing shelter to cold animals, guiding lost travelers to safety, or undermining the schemes of an evil hag or white dragon. Interestingly, hags consider rimefire witches to be kin, of a sort, and rarely meddle directly in their affairs. Some may even cooperate with rimefire witches in the interest of a common goal, forming covens just as they would with fellow hags.

entries.name: A Rimefire Witch's Lair
entries: The rimefire witch makes its lair in the home of the rimefire eidolon which is tends to, and they can draw from its power to protect it. While within 3 miles of its rimefire eidolon's lair, the rimefire witch can cast the following spells at will without providing material components: {@spell clairvoyance}, {@spell control weather}, {@spell nondetection}. Once per day while within 3 miles of its rimefire eidolon's lair, the rimefire witch can cast {@spell storm of vengeance} ({@dc 19}).

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the rimefire witch takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; the rimefire witch can't use the same effect two turns in a row.

items: The rimefire witch casts {@spell wall of ice}. It can maintain concentration on this effect on subsequent rounds, but it cannot use any other lair actions while it does so.

One creature that the rimefire witch can see within 120 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 19} Intelligence saving throw or be affected with the {@spell feeblemind} spell until initiative count 20 of the following round.

The rimefire witch expends one spell slot to cast a spell that restores hit points and/or ends a status condition. The spell can target any creature within the lair, regardless of intervening distance, so long as the rimefire witch is aware that the target is in the lair.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The uldra is a 10th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). The uldra has the following bard spells prepared:

trait.name: Animal Speakers
entries: The uldra can speak with beasts as if they shared a common language.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage in melee or at range.

bonus.name: Inspiration (4/Day)
entries: The uldra speaks stirring words or sings an inspiring song to grant one creature within 60 feet of it that can hear it one inspiration die, a {@dice d10}. Once within the next 10 minutes, the creature can roll the die and add the number rolled to one ability check, attack roll, or saving throw it makes. A creature can have only one Inspiration die at a time.

The rare and elusive uldra are unusual folk. They embody the rare mercies of winter, and dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of the cold and helping others survive the season in small subtle ways. They coat plants in a layer of frost to protect them from flash freezes and create snowbanks to insulate cold animals and travelers. They dislike being found by mortals, but those that leave them gifts of hats will find their homes well guarded from both beasts and the elements, as there are few things that the uldra love more than hats. An uldra facing a problem that's beyond it, though, might overcome its natural shyness to approach a humanoid for help.

entries.name: Forgotten Queen
entries: The uldra do not keep a written history, preferring to maintain all of their records through oral accounts. One of their oldest stories is of Hleid, their last queen, a primordial goddess of winter. The details differ from tribe to tribe, and even from teller to teller, but they all agree Hleid was beautiful, powerful, and kind, a lady of mercy and protection in the otherwise cruel winter of the world. However, she was slain and her spirit broken into pieces which plummeted to the earth. The uldra have taken on no gods since Hleid was slain, mourning her death in songs and stories and protecting those fragments of her that remain.

Uldra wish to bring joy and contentment into the dark places of the world, and music is one of the greatest ways to spread joy. The carolers of the uldra people spend their time learning songs, investigating folk songs, hymns, limericks, and all other forms of music, composing their own songs as well. The carolers are among the most outgoing of the uldra, and may even reveal themselves to mortals if they believe that they are in need of good cheer.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The uldra is a 11th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit 7} to hit with spell attacks). The uldra has the following warlock spells prepared:
footerEntries: ~ The uldra casts these on itself before combat.

trait.name: Animal Speakers
entries: The uldra can speak with beasts as if they shared a common language.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The uldra penitente has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uldra makes three attacks with its eldritch blast.

action.name: Eldritch Blast (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 7} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) force damage.

The rare and elusive uldra are unusual folk. They embody the rare mercies of winter, and dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of the cold and helping others survive the season in small subtle ways. They coat plants in a layer of frost to protect them from flash freezes and create snowbanks to insulate cold animals and travelers. They dislike being found by mortals, but those that leave them gifts of hats will find their homes well guarded from both beasts and the elements, as there are few things that the uldra love more than hats. An uldra facing a problem that's beyond it, though, might overcome its natural shyness to approach a humanoid for help.

entries.name: Forgotten Queen
entries: The uldra do not keep a written history, preferring to maintain all of their records through oral accounts. One of their oldest stories is of Hleid, their last queen, a primordial goddess of winter. The details differ from tribe to tribe, and even from teller to teller, but they all agree Hleid was beautiful, powerful, and kind, a lady of mercy and protection in the otherwise cruel winter of the world. However, she was slain and her spirit broken into pieces which plummeted to the earth. The uldra have taken on no gods since Hleid was slain, mourning her death in songs and stories and protecting those fragments of her that remain.

A penitente is an uldra that has made an eldritch pact with a {@creature rimefire eidolon|TheFeyCompendium} to gain arcane power. These uldra seek out power so that they may protect their homes and combat evil wherever it arises. They may study magic under the guidance of a {@creature rimefire witch|TheFeyCompendium} or go adventuring on their own to master their powers. Though just as kind as the rest of their kin, penitentes are far more cutthroat in their methods of defending the innocent. They have no qualms about levying curses or killing if it means ensuring the safety of another. These wintry arcanists are often accompanied by fey such as {@creature rime sprites|TheFeyCompendium} or {@creature frost faeries|TheFeyCompendium}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The uldra is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). The uldra has the following ranger spells prepared:

trait.name: Animal Speakers
entries: The uldra can speak with beasts as if they shared a common language.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The uldra wolfwalker has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the uldra wolfwalker's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uldra makes two weapon attacks. In place of one weapon attack, the uldra can command a beast it is allied with to use its reaction to make one weapon attack.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Wolfwalk
entries: The uldra transforms into its {@creature wolfwalker form|TheFeyCompendium}. While in wolfwalker form, it uses the Wolfwalker Form statistics, retaining its hit points. While wolfwalking, it can return to its true form as a bonus action.

The rare and elusive uldra are unusual folk. They embody the rare mercies of winter, and dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of the cold and helping others survive the season in small subtle ways. They coat plants in a layer of frost to protect them from flash freezes and create snowbanks to insulate cold animals and travelers. They dislike being found by mortals, but those that leave them gifts of hats will find their homes well guarded from both beasts and the elements, as there are few things that the uldra love more than hats. An uldra facing a problem that's beyond it, though, might overcome its natural shyness to approach a humanoid for help.

entries.name: Forgotten Queen
entries: The uldra do not keep a written history, preferring to maintain all of their records through oral accounts. One of their oldest stories is of Hleid, their last queen, a primordial goddess of winter. The details differ from tribe to tribe, and even from teller to teller, but they all agree Hleid was beautiful, powerful, and kind, a lady of mercy and protection in the otherwise cruel winter of the world. However, she was slain and her spirit broken into pieces which plummeted to the earth. The uldra have taken on no gods since Hleid was slain, mourning her death in songs and stories and protecting those fragments of her that remain.

The uldra are guardians of animals, protecting them during the bitter cold of winter. The wolfwalkers are those uldra that patrol the borders of uldra territory in the shape of beasts, protecting those who live there from over-hunting, unnatural monsters and other threats. They ally themselves with wolves and form tight pack bonds. In this way, they also protect the wolves from retribution by mortals, as they ensure that their packs never get so desperate that they hunt mortals or their animals.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolfwalker form's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The wolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wolf makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

The rare and elusive uldra are unusual folk. They embody the rare mercies of winter, and dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of the cold and helping others survive the season in small subtle ways. They coat plants in a layer of frost to protect them from flash freezes and create snowbanks to insulate cold animals and travelers. They dislike being found by mortals, but those that leave them gifts of hats will find their homes well guarded from both beasts and the elements, as there are few things that the uldra love more than hats. An uldra facing a problem that's beyond it, though, might overcome its natural shyness to approach a humanoid for help.

One of their oldest stories is of Hleid, their last queen, a primordial goddess of winter. The details differ from tribe to tribe, and even from teller to teller, but they all agree Hleid was beautiful, powerful, and kind, a lady of mercy and protection in the otherwise cruel winter of the world. However, she was slain and her spirit broken into pieces which plummeted to the earth. The uldra have taken on no gods since Hleid was slain, mourning her death in songs and stories and protecting those fragments of her that remain.

The wolfwalkers are those uldra that patrol the borders of uldra territory in the shape of beasts, protecting those who live there from over-hunting, unnatural monsters and other threats. They ally themselves with wolves and form tight pack bonds. In this way, they also protect the wolves from retribution by mortals, as they ensure that their packs never get so desperate that they hunt mortals or their animals.

monster.name: Yule Defender
languages: understands Gnomish and Sylvan but can't speak

trait.name: Command Reliant
entries: The defender takes its turn immediately after the {@creature uldra wondermaker|TheFeyCompendium} that controls it. Unless the uldra wondermaker that controls it uses a bonus action to give it a command, the only action it can take on its turn is the Dodge action.

trait.name: Repairable
entries: If the {@spell mending} spell is cast on the defender, it regains {@dice 2d6} hit points.

trait.name: Vigilant
entries: The defender can't be surprised.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The defender makes two attacks.

action.name: Force-Empowered Rend
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Repair (3/Day)
entries: The magical mechanisms inside the defender restore 13 ({@dice 2d8 + 4}) hit points to itself or to one construct or object within 5 feet of it.

reaction.name: Deflect Attack
entries: The defender imposes disadvantage on the attack roll of one creature it can see that is within 5 feet of it, provided the attack roll is against a creature other than the defender.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The uldra is a 11th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 16}, {@hit 8} to hit with spell attacks). The uldra has the following artificer spells prepared:

trait.name: Animal Speakers
entries: The uldra can speak with beasts as if they shared a common language.

trait.name: Arcane Jolt (4/Day)
entries: When the uldra hits a target with a weapon attack or its {@creature yule defender|TheFeyCompendium} hits a target with an attack, the uldra can channel energy through the strike to create one of the following effects:

items: The attack deals an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) force damage.
The uldra restores 10 ({@dice 3d6}) hit points to one creature or object within 30 feet of it.

trait.name: Magic Items
entries: The uldra's weapons are both magical +1 weapons (included in the attack). The uldra's shield is a magical +1 shield.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uldra makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Hand Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage with {@spell flame arrows|XGE}.

reaction.name: Repulsion Shield (4/Day)
entries: Immediately after being hit by a melee attack, the uldra can cause its shield to emit a pulse of force to push the attacker up to 15 feet away from it.

The rare and elusive uldra are unusual folk. They embody the rare mercies of winter, and dedicate themselves to lessening the suffering of the cold and helping others survive the season in small subtle ways. They coat plants in a layer of frost to protect them from flash freezes and create snowbanks to insulate cold animals and travelers. They dislike being found by mortals, but those that leave them gifts of hats will find their homes well guarded from both beasts and the elements, as there are few things that the uldra love more than hats. An uldra facing a problem that's beyond it, though, might overcome its natural shyness to approach a humanoid for help.

entries.name: Forgotten Queen
entries: The uldra do not keep a written history, preferring to maintain all of their records through oral accounts. One of their oldest stories is of Hleid, their last queen, a primordial goddess of winter. The details differ from tribe to tribe, and even from teller to teller, but they all agree Hleid was beautiful, powerful, and kind, a lady of mercy and protection in the otherwise cruel winter of the world. However, she was slain and her spirit broken into pieces which plummeted to the earth. The uldra have taken on no gods since Hleid was slain, mourning her death in songs and stories and protecting those fragments of her that remain.

Wondermakers are uldra who have dedicated themselves to crafting wondrous toys to bring joy to children, as well as defending children from the threats that lurk in winter's shadows. These uldra array themselves in joyfully colored armor and stand as a bulwark against fiends, ghosts, and evil fey, aided by their magical constructs, foremost of which are their robotic {@creature yule defender|TheFeyCompendium}. Though these wondrous constructs are crafted in the shape of reindeer, nutcrackers, teddy bears, and other cheerful appearances to bring happiness to children, they can fight ferociously to defend the innocent.

trait.name: All Around Vision
entries: While in its true form, the uthraki has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The uthraki has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Nighttime Regeneration
entries: The uthraki regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it is currently nighttime. If the uthraki takes fire damage, is hit by a weapon made of stone or wood, or is exposed to sunlight, this trait doesn't function at the start of the uthraki's next turn. The uthraki dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The uthraki makes three attacks: two claw attacks and one bite attack.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the uthraki hits the same creature with two claw attacks in the same turn, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage. This attack has advantage if the uthraki is grappling the target.

action.name: Change Shape
entries: The uthraki magically polymorphs into a Small or Medium humanoid or a beast with a CR equal to or less than its own. It reverts to its true form if it dies or if it uses a bonus action to return to it. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. In humanoid form, its statistics are the same. In beast form, the uthraki gains the statistics of its selected beast, but retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and Magic Resistance and Nighttime Regeneration traits.

The uthraki are malevolent forest spirits that favor temperate and sub-arctic climates. In its natural form, an uthraki resembles a large, gray ape with a vaguely human-like face, distinguished by a ring of black, hateful eyes that fully encircle its head, granting it full vision of its surroundings at all times. However, these monsters are rarely seen in their true forms, preferring instead to take the form of harmless creatures such as a lost child, a friendly bard, or prey animals such as rabbits. They use these cunning disguises to lower the defenses of their intended victims, allowing them to slay and devour them easily.

entries.name: Night Hunters
entries: The uthraki are spirits of the dark and cold of forests. An uthraki hunts during the night, as their incredible vision and agile movement grants them mastery of terrain, while their supernatural connection to darkness enables them to heal almost instantly from even fatal injuries. Only fire, sunlight, and weapons made of stone or wood are able to halt this healing, and uthraki will avoid attacking creatures that openly carry flame.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The wendigo's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The abyssal wendigo has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Beyond Sight
entries: If the wendigo ends its turn 25 feet or further away from a creature that it is not allied to, it is {@condition invisible} to that creature until the end of the wendigo's next turn.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the abyssal wendigo moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with its gore on the same turn, the target takes an extra 14 ({@damage 4d6}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Musk of Terror
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the abyssal wendigo must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target is {@condition frightened}. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the abyssal wendigo's Musk of Terror for 24 hours.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The abyssal wendigo regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If the abyssal wendigo takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the abyssal wendigo's next turn. The abyssal wendigo dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
