entries: If the abyssal wendigo fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The abyssal wendigo makes two attacks with its claws and one with its bite. If it begins its turn grappling a creature or is targeting a {@condition prone} creature, it can instead make four attacks with its bite.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the abyssal wendigo hits a creature with two claw attacks in the same turn, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become infected with {@i Wendigo's Hunger} (see Info section for details). This attack scores a critical hit on a natural roll of 19-20.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d10 + 5}) piercing damage and the target has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws for the next minute.

legendary.name: Cannibal's Hunger
entries: The wendigo targets one creature that it can see within 60 feet of it. The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or use its reaction to move up to its speed towards the nearest creature and make a bite attack against it, with a preference for creatures it is allied with. When the targeted creature makes a bite attack, it makes an attack using the attack modifier, damage roll, and effects one the wendigo's own Bite attacks. Creatures infected by Wendigo's Hunger or possessed by a lesser wendigo have disadvantage on the saving throw to resist this effect.

legendary.name: Auto-Cannibalism (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The wendigo eats part of its own flesh, dealing 7 {@damage 2d6} damage to itself. Any creatures that have become immune to the wendigo's Musk of Terror through succeeding on their saving throw against the effect lose their immunity and must begin saving against it again.

An abyssal wendigo is a towering monster of bloody fur. Created when a demon devours a wendigo or a creature infected with Wendigo's Hunger, these horrific creatures are the true epitome of brutal savagery and insatiable hunger. Invisible until it is within just scant yards of its victims and able to take on the form of mist or wind, the first warning that a creature receives of its presence is usually its horrific musk, by which point it is already too late.

entries.name: Unyielding Hunger
entries: An abyssal wendigo is a towering monster of bloody fur. Created when a demon devours a wendigo or a creature infected with Wendigo's Hunger, these horrific creatures are the true epitome of brutal savagery and insatiable hunger. Invisible until it is within just scant yards of its victims and able to take on the form of mist or wind, the first warning that a creature receives of its presence is usually its horrific musk, by which point it is already too late.

entries.name: Wendigo's Hunger
entries: A humanoid that consumes the flesh of another humanoid creature while within the Feywild or an area touch by the Feywild must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become infected with Wendigo's Hunger, which has an incubation period of {@dice 1d4} days. Once the incubation period is complete, the creature gains the following flaw: “I crave to feed on the flesh of sentient creatures, especially my kin.

The first time each day that an infected creature witnesses a humanoid become injured, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or attempt to feed on them. The infected creature has disadvantage on the saving throw if the humanoid it witnessed being injured is an ally or family member. Each time that a creature infected with the Wendigo's Hunger successfully feeds on another humanoid's flesh, its Wisdom score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}.

After reach long rest, a creature infected with Wendigo's Hunger must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or have its Wisdom score reduced by 1. When its Wisdom score is reduced to 1, the creature immediately transforms into a wendigo, racing into the sky with such speed that its feet are burned away into charred, bloody stumps.
Gnolls, leucrotta, shoosuva, wendigo, hyenas, and any fiends loyal to Yeenoghu can detect if a creature is infected by Wendigo's Hunger by scent and will avoid attacking it.

Wendigo's Hunger can also be contracted from the bite of a wendigo. If an infected creature does not feed on another sentient creatures for 10 consecutive days, it is cured of Wendigo's Hunger. Otherwise, it can be cured with greater restoration or similar magic. When the creature is cured of Wendigo's Hunger, any reduction in Wisdom that it suffered from the disease is restored.

monster.name: True Wendigo
languages: understands the languages of its host
as well as Abyssal and Sylvan

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The wendigo's weapon attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to non-magical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Heart of Ice
entries: When the wendigo is reduced to 0 hit points, it doesn't die. Instead, it falls {@condition unconscious} and its host is exposed within its heart of ice. The host is conscious and acts on the wendigo's turn, but is {@condition restrained} and cannot be removed from the heart of ice unless it attempts to leave or accepts help from another creature, which requires a successful {@dc 19} Strength check performed as an action by either the host or another creature. The host shares the wendigo's damage immunities and resistances. Otherwise the host is treated as if it was a normal creature of its type. If the host is killed or removed from the wendigo's heart, the wendigo dies.

At the beginning of each of the wendigo's turns, ice begins to regrow to cover the host. The ice is considered to be a Medium object that cannot be removed from the wendigo's chest. It has an AC of 19 and gains 25 hit points at the start of each of the wendigo's turns. The ice has immunity to acid, cold, poison, and psychic damage and vulnerability to fire damage.

If the ice reaches 40 hit points, or if the host is not killed or removed from the wendigo's chest within 5 rounds, the wendigo's chest closes up and the wendigo regains consciousness with full health at the start of its turn.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the true wendigo fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The true wendigo has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wendigo makes two attacks with its claws and one with its bite. If it begins its turn grappling a creature, it can instead make four attacks with its bite.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 20}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the wendigo loses the use of that hand to make claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) piercing damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw or become infected with Wendigo's Hunger (see Info section for details). This attack scores a critical hit on a natural roll of 19-20.

action.name: Frightful Presence
entries: Each creature of the wendigo's choice that is within 120 feet of the wendigo and aware of it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the wendigo's Frightful Presence for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Unholy Hunger
entries: The wendigo grabs a humanoid currently at 0 hit points within 10 feet of it, then feasts on the body, killing the target. The wendigo's maximum hit points are increased by a value equal to the target's maximum hit points. The wendigo's maximum hit points can be increased up to 600 hit points. If the wendigo's maximum hit points exceed 300, it is considered Gargantuan sized. While Gargantuan, it has advantage on Strength checks and saving throws and can grapple Large or smaller creatures with its claw attacks.

If the wendigo takes fire damage while its maximum hit points have been increased as a result of this action, the wendigo's maximum hit points are reduced by the amount of fire damage dealt, though it cannot reduce the wendigo's hit point maximum below its normal value.

legendary.name: Charge
entries: The wendigo moves up to its speed without triggering opportunity attacks.

legendary.name: Savage (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The wendigo makes one bite attack against each creature within 10 feet of him.

A true wendigo is the ultimate expression of greed, gluttony, and unmitigated craving. When a creature that is consumed by its vices becomes a wendigo, rather that speed into the sky to become a spirit of wind, its body becomes encrusted in ice and transforms into the heart of a hideous monstrosity. Appearing as a gaunt, emaciated mockery of the creature it once was, a true wendigo craves food endlessly and will devour everything even remotely edible if allowed, including trees, wagons, and even homes. However, what it craves most in the world is the flesh of humanoids, and it gluts itself on humanoid flesh every chance it gets.

entries.name: A Growing Terror
entries: Though a true wendigo eats constantly, its hunger is never satisfied. Anything short of humanoid flesh tastes like ash in its mouth, and though humanoid flesh satisfies for a time, the wendigo's curse causes it to grow ever larger the more humanoid flesh it consumes. This places the wendigo in a constant state of tormented hunger, leading it to rampage without rest. Only fire can curb the wendigo's unrestrained growth, causing its extra flesh to slough off its body like bloody, foul smelling slush.

entries.name: Slim Chance of Redemption
entries: At the core of the true wendigo is its heart of ice, and within that heart of ice is the body of the creature that became the wendigo. As long as that creature remains alive, the wendigo can recover from any injury, no matter how severe. If critically injured, the wendigo falls unconscious and its heart breaks open, exposing its host to the open air. It is then that the host can be saved from its wretched fate, for if it can be extricated from the heart the wendigo dies and its host is cured of Wendigo's Hunger. Though many that become true wendigos are unworthy of redemption, being greedy and rapacious monsters even before their transformation, others may have been afflicted with addictions beyond their control in life.

entries.name: Ravenous Wendigos
entries: The stat block presented for true wendigos assumes that the wendigo is first encountered at its normal hit point maximum of 147. Because of the nature of its Unholy Hunger action, only its hit point maximum is increased when it consumes a humanoid, not its current hit points. As a result, the increased maximum hit points does not have any effect on the wendigo's CR, unless it is accompanied by a creature with ample healing magic.

The stat block presented for true wendigos in this supplement assumes that the wendigo is first encountered at its normal hit point maximum of 150. Because of the nature of its Unholy Hunger action, only its hit point maximum is increased when it consumes a humanoid, not its current hit points. As a result, the increased maximum hit points does not have any effect on the wendigo's CR, unless it is accompanied by a creature with ample healing magic.

items: A true wendigo encountered with 300 hit points has a CR of 18 (20,000 XP).
A true wendigo encountered with 600 hit points has a CR of 21 (33,000 XP).

entries.name: Wendigo's Hunger
entries: A humanoid that consumes the flesh of another humanoid creature while within the Feywild or an area touched by the Feywild must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or become infected with Wendigo's Hunger, which has an incubation period of {@dice 1d4} days. Once the incubation period is complete, the creature gains the following flaw: “I crave to feed on the flesh of sentient creatures, especially my kin.

The first time each day that an infected creature witnesses a humanoid become injured, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or attempt to feed on them. The infected creature has disadvantage on the saving throw if the humanoid it witnessed being injured is an ally or family member. Each time that a creature infected with the Wendigo's Hunger successfully feeds on another humanoid's flesh, its Wisdom score is reduced by {@dice 1d4}.

After reach long rest, a creature infected with Wendigo's Hunger must succeed on a {@dc 14} Charisma saving throw or have its Wisdom score reduced by 1. When its Wisdom score is reduced to 1, the creature immediately transforms into a wendigo, racing into the sky with such speed that its feet are burned away into charred, bloody stumps.
Gnolls, leucrotta, shoosuva, wendigo, hyenas, and any fiends loyal to Yeenoghu can detect if a creature is infected by Wendigo's Hunger by scent and will avoid attacking it.

Wendigo's Hunger can also be contracted from the bite of a wendigo. If an infected creature does not feed on another sentient creatures for 10 consecutive days, it is cured of Wendigo's Hunger. Otherwise, it can be cured with greater restoration or similar magic. When the creature is cured of Wendigo's Hunger, any reduction in Wisdom that it suffered from the disease is restored.

monster.name: Selephra, the Bramble Queen

resist.special: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Selephra's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Barkskin
entries: Selephra's AC cannot be lower than 16.

trait.name: Bramble Limbs
entries: Selephra possesses vines which extend 5 feet out from her in all directions. This area is considered difficult terrain. These vines also give Selephra her incredible speed and allow her to extend up to 5 feet away from any surface on which she is walking or climbing. A player can attempt to destroy a 5 foot cube of vines by dealing at least 15 slashing or fire damage to the vines rather than Selephra in a single turn (AC 16). Selephra regrows her vines in {@dice 1d4} turns. Without her vines, Selephra loses her ability to extend 5 feet away from a surface, her walking and climbing speed is reduced to 30 feet, and the reach of her vines attack is decreased to 5 feet.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Selephra fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Selephra has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Selephra makes three attacks with her vines.

action.name: Vines
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}).

action.name: Blood Drain
entries: One creature {@condition grappled} by Selephra must make a {@dc 19} Constitution saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save as its blood is drained by the thorny vines, or half as much on a success. Selephra recovers hit points equal to half the amount of necrotic damage dealt.

legendaryHeader: Selephra can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Selephra regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Attack.
entries: Selephra makes one attack with her vines.

legendary.name: Crush (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Selephra crushes one creature being {@condition grappled} by her vines. The target must make on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 4d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage on a failure or half as much on a success.

legendary.name: Regrow (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Selephra regrows all of her vines.

entries.name: Archfey
entries: The archfey are beings of peerless power in the Feywild. Powerful, perilous, and amazing, the archfey are not to be trifled with. Some were once worshiped as gods by humanoids, while others have little interest in the brief lives of those who walk in the mortal lands.

Once Selephra was beautiful and kind, the princess of a powerful eladrin nation who would dance among the fields of flowers that she so loved. Joyous and merry, she was beloved by her people and her fiancé, a handsome and vigorous elven prince of unsurpassed skill as a warrior. However, her happiness was marred when he was called off to war with a neighboring kingdom.
He never returned.

In her sorrow, she had a cottage built on the border of her kingdom and the kingdom that had claimed her love, so that she could watch the road for her love. She waited there for years, her joy and flesh withering, her dreams tangling amid the briars of her grief, until she could not bear it any longer. She walked down the road, and none dared stop her as she stormed the castle at the end of the path, so great was her fury and desire to rescue her love. However, when she reached his chamber, she discovered him in the bed of another.

In her rage, she called down a terrible curse upon herself and both kingdoms. The castle was strangled by thorny vines, and all within were torn apart slowly, though none suffered more than the man who broke her heart. Some even say that he and his lover are still alive today, trapped within the depths of their castle as their flesh is slowly pulled from their bones, and that Selephra visits them from time to time to exact new tortures on them.

entries.name: The Grieving Palace
entries: Her heart broken and her limbs coated in blood, Selephra returned to the cottage that she spent so many years waiting in, and her bitter vengeance followed her. Neither kingdom now stands, only tangled forests of thorns fraught with vengeful wraiths, weeping ghosts, and cruel fey. She resides in that cottage still, calling it her Grieving Palace, and she is served by fawning sprites and doting hags. Guests in this morose place are served muddy tea from cracked glasses and moldy food on filthy plates. Those who comment on the squalor are tortured in horrible ways.

entries.name: Queen of Fury
entries: Though Selephra is still beautiful, it is a sickly and terrible beauty. The curse that she called down upon herself transformed her flesh, piercing it with thorny vines that trail sensuously from her arms. Her arms are pallid and frail looking, though they are as strong as tree limbs. She watches her guests with dark, cruel eyes, disguising her mutilated appearance with shrouds of illusion to lure her victims into a false sense of security.

Selephra hates all the world, including herself, but she especially despises falsehood and betrayal. Anyone who she deems guilty of deceit, faithlessness, or disloyalty will immediately draw her ire, and she and her servants will hound the unlucky wretch till their death. Ultimately though, she wreaks her vengeance on any mortals foolish or unlucky enough to cross her path, regardless of their virtues.

entries.name: The Grieving Palace
entries: Though it appears as nothing more than a decrepit cottage, this is the Grieving Palace, home of Selephra, the Bramble Queen. The Grieving Palace is not a real place in the most literal sense of the word. Rather, it is a state of mind built of brick and mortar. When a humanoid experiences betrayal and heartbreak, a Grieving Palace begins to form on the corresponding spot on the Feywild of that humanoid's home. Should that person's heartbreak continue to grow into bitterness, the Grieving Palace will grow as well, until it engulfs the true home of the mourner, occupying the same spot on both planes. Green hags, wicked dryads, and cruel sprites flock to a Grieving Palace, called by the bitterness of Selephra. Eventually, the mourner is transformed into a fey and their home fades away, leaving only an empty husk of a home forever touched by the Bramble Queen's caress.

trait.name: Damage Threshold
entries: The wood man has immunity to all damage unless it takes 25 damage or more from an attack, in which case it takes damage as normal. Any damage that fails to meet or exceed the damage threshold is considered superficial and doesn't reduce the wood man's hit points.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The wood man's weapon attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Epic Regeneration
entries: The wood man regains 25 hit points at the start of its turn. The wood man dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points for 10 turns in a row.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the wood man fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The wood man has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The wood man deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: World Bound
entries: The wood man is treated as a creature native to the Material Plane for the purposes of spells such as {@spell banishment} and {@spell banishing smite}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The wood man makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}28 ({@damage 4d8 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.If the target is a Large or smaller creature and the wood man is not grappling two creatures already, the target is {@condition grappled} by the wood man (escape {@dc 27}).

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 19} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 5d12 + 10}) bludgeoning damage.

legendary.name: Slam
entries: The wood man makes one Slam attack.

legendary.name: Throw Creature
entries: The wood man throws one creature that it is grappling up to 300 feet away from it. If a thrown target strikes an object, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet it was thrown, to a maximum of {@dice 20d6}. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 27} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Summon Ally {@recharge 6}
entries: The wood man summons one {@creature treant} or an elemental or fey with a Challenge Rating of 7 or lower. The summoned creature obeys any orders given to it by the wood man and remains for 1 hour.

A wood man is a titan of nature. Created by now forgotten gods of nature to battle the primordials long ago, these immense beings resemble massive walking trees, dwarfing even treants with their titanic size. These beings slumber deep in the wilderness, still as hale and hearty as they were at the dawn of time when they did battle with monsters of the infant world.

entries.name: Guardians of the Land
entries: A wood man is dedicated, body and soul, to the defense of the land that birthed it. However, they are only roused from their slumber when true threats arise that the treants and native inhabitants of their lands cannot handle, such as a demonic incursion or an invasion from a neighboring army. When moved to action, a wood man is a catastrophic force of destruction, able to topple the mightiest of towers and summon a nearly endless army of allies to its aid.

entries.name: Nigh Unkillable
entries: Though a wood man resembles a massive treant, they share few of their weaknesses. A wood man is immune to flame and lightning and laughs at the cold of winter. Their iron hard bark cannot be damaged by anything less than a magical blade, easily shrugging off fists and arrows as if they were nothing but midges. Even if a creature is able to deal damage to a wood man, it quickly recovers from any damage dealt to it. Only an enormous amount of damage dealt to it over a long period of time can truly harm the wood man.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The yeti chuchuna's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 15}). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Fear of Fire
entries: If the yeti chuchuna takes fire damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The yeti chuchuna has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The yeti chuchuna has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The yeti chuchuna has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The yeti can use its Chilling Gaze or cast one spell from its Innate Spellcasting, then make two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Chilling Gaze
entries: The yeti targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the yeti, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw against this magic or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage and then be affected by one of the following effects for 1 minute, unless it is immune to cold damage:

items: {@b Frozen.} The target is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.
{@b Hibernation.} The target falls {@condition unconscious}. It wakes up if it takes any damage or if another creature uses its action to shake the sleeper awake.

{@b Terror.} The target is {@condition frightened} of the yeti. On each of its turns, the {@condition frightened} creature must take the Dash action and move away from the yeti by the safest and shortest available route, unless there is nowhere to move. If the target moves to a place at least 60 feet away from the yeti where it can no longer see the yeti, this effect ends.
{@b Sickness.} The target has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. At the end of each of its turns, it can make another Wisdom saving throw. If it succeeds, the effect ends.

entries: An effect can be ended early if {@spell bestow curse} is cast on the target. If the target's saving throw is successful, or if the effect ends on it, the target is immune to that effect and the Chilling Gaze of all other yetis (but not abominable yetis) for 1 hour.

The yetis are a race of large, evil minded creatures of the frozen north. They hunt for what meager creatures can be found in their barren lands, freezing their prey with their chilling gazes and rampaging through any creatures that dare to stand in their way.

The winter wastes of the world are not generous, and many yeti starve to death for lack of food. A yeti on the brink of death may call out for aid, and occasionally a powerful fey may answer. These fey may bless the yeti with powers over death, granting them the ability to capture and harness the spirits of nature and the dead, transforming them into a chuchuna. A chuchuna's eyes become capable of laying terrible curses on those that are unfortunate enough to be seen by these cruel monsters. Armed with these new powers, a chuchuna can take on challenges that before would have daunted it. With their magic they can bully others of their kind into obedience, creating uncharacteristically coordinated attacks by the savage monsters. However, these powers do not come for free, and the fey that granted the chuchuna its powers expect its obedience in return.

entries.name: Incorporating into Icewind Dale
entries: You can choose to use the stats of a yeti chuchuna for Korgrah rather than those of an abominable yeti. Korgrah is a servant of Auril, having sworn itself to her service long ago, and he rules over the other yetis of the island with a cruel brutality.

monster.name: Emee Khunbish

immune.note: damage from non-magical weapons that arent silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Emee Knubish's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Graystaff Magic
entries: Emee Knubish carries a graystaff, a length of gray wood that is a focus for her inner power that can be weilded as a magic weapon. She can ride the staff as if it were a {@item broom of flying}. Only when the graystaff is in her possession does the staff retain its magical properties.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The emee khunbish can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Emee Khunbish fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Emee Khunbish has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The emee khunbish regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If Emee Khunbish takes acid or lightning damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of Emee Khunbish's next turn. Emee Khunbish dies only if she starts her turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Ever Returning
entries: When Emee Khunbish dies, her spirit takes to the wind and seeks out a random {@spell bheur hag} somewhere in the multiverse. That bheur hag becomes the new Emee Knubish and within a month has gained her statistics.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, or 22 ({@damage 4d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Cold Blast (While wielding Graystaff only) {@recharge 5}.
entries: Emee Knubish summons an icy blast from her Graystaff in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Additionally, a creature that fails on its saving throw has its speed reduced by half for {@dice 1d4} rounds. A creature killed by this effect becomes a frozen statue until it thaws.

action.name: Maddening Feast
entries: Emee Knubish feasts on the corpse of one enemy within 5 feet of her that died within the past minute. Each creature of Emee Knubishs choice that is within 60 feet of her and able to see her must succeed on a {@dc 20} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of her for 1 minute. While {@condition frightened} in this way, a creature is {@condition incapacitated}, cant understand what others say, cant read, and speaks only in gibberish; the DM controls the creatures movement, which is erratic. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creatures saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Emee Knubishs Maddening Feast for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Size Change
entries: Emee Knubish magically increases in size, along with anything she is wearing or carrying. She can return to her normal size as a bonus action. While enlarged, Emee Knubish is Large, doubles her damage dice on Strength-based weapon attacks (included in the attacks), and makes Strength checks and Strength saving throws with advantage. If Emee Knubish lacks the room to become Large, she attains the maximum size possible in the space available.

legendaryHeader: Emee Knubish can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. Emee Knubish regains her spent legendary actions at the start of her turn.

legendary.name: Cruel Cold
entries: Emee Knubish makes one slam attack or casts {@spell ray of frost}.

legendary.name: Curse
entries: Emee Knubish casts {@spell bestow curse}.

legendary.name: Size Change (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Emee Knubish uses her Size Change action or returns to her normal size.

Legends say that Emee Knubish is the first of the bheur hags, and that she was already old when Auril herself was young. Capable of swelling in size to that of an ogre, Emee Knubish is a wintry terror In fact, she is not even a single entity. Rather, Emee Knubish is an ancient spirit which passes from one bheur hag to another, spreading cold and suffering wherever she goes.

entries.name: Bitter Winter
entries: Emee Knubish's motivation seems to be to spread misery and death, though the means by which she achieves this are always strange and esoteric, albeit frightfully effective. She may spend a summer piling stones at a certain point on a hill, only for them to cause an avalanche that causes a father to break his neck that winter. Or she may drip a single drop of saltwater onto the roots of a great tree every day for a decade, causing it to sicken and weaken until an errant touch sends it it collapsing onto a road, blocking it at a crucial juncture. Her methods are inscrutable, as if she is following some ancient pattern that only she can read.

entries.name: Always Changing
entries: Emee Knubish is a living spirit that passes from one bheur hag to another. When she dies, her spirit travels across the world, inhabiting another bheur hag. The spirit of Emee Knubish and her new host then merge, combining their personalities and experiences to create a new version of Emee Knubish. This means that Emee Knubish is never the same. Sometimes she may be terse and quiet, speaking only when necessary, while other times she may be boisterous and loud, taking great delight in the pain she inflicts. However, no matter the new personalities she attains, she will always seek to create brutal winter and incredible suffering. Only her death can release the land she lairs in from her grasp, sending her spirit to another realm.

entries.name: Great Grandmother
entries: Emee Knubish is one of the few hags who has attained the title of Great Grandmother, placing her among the ranks of such has as Cegilune, Malagard, and Baba Yaga herself. All hags show her respect, but hags of winter show her particular deference. Often she presides over winter solstice sabbaths, and the dark plots hatched under her hands can humble entire kingdoms.

entries.name: Emee Khunbish's Lair
entries: Emee Khunbish usually lives in the lair of whatever bheur hag she was prior to her spirit possessing it, favoring out of the way mountain tops.

monster.name: Prince of Frost

immune.note: damage from non-magical weapons that arent silvered

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Prince of Frost's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 20}, {@hit 12} to hit with spell attacks). He can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Bitter Edge
entries: Bitter Edge is a magical longsword and uses the Prince of Frost's spellcasting modifier for attack and damage rolls. When the Prince of Frost draws or swings this weapon, he can choose to extinguish all nonmagical flames within 30 feet of himself. Furthermore, when the Prince of Frost casts {@spell imprisonment} with his Innate Spellcasting, the target is imprisoned in the diamond on the hilt of Bitter Edge.

trait.name: Heart of Ice
entries: The first time a creature takes cold damage from the Prince of Frost on a turn, it must make a {@dc 20} Charisma saving throw. The saving throw has disadvantage if the creature has a flaw rolled from the “Flaws of the Prince” table (located at the info section). On a failure, the creature's soul begins to freeze. If a creature fails its saving throw against this effect three times, the ice from its soul freezes its entire body into a block of ice. While frozen in this way, the creature is {@condition petrified}, is immune to cold damage, and is vulnerable to fire damage. If it succeeds three times, it becomes immune to this trait for 24 hours. The successes and failures do not need to be consecutive. This condition can be cured with {@spell greater restoration} or similar magic or by 10 uninterrupted hours of exposure to sunlight in a temperature above freezing.

trait.name: Hunting Regalia
entries: The Prince of Frost's hunting regalia is a set of magical plate armor made of mythril. The armor does not impose disadvantage on the Prince of Frost's Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks. While wearing it, he can cast additional spells with his Innate Spellcasting trait (these spells are marked with a tilde ~).

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the Prince of Frost fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Prince of Frost has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Winter Stride
entries: The Prince of Frost ignores difficult terrain created by ice and snow.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Prince of Frost makes three attacks: choosing either Bitter Edge or {@spell Ray of Frost} for each. In place of two attacks, he can cast either {@spell command} or {@spell hold person}.

action.name: Bitter Edge (Longsword)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) slashing damage, or 17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands, plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) cold damage.

action.name: Ray of Frost (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 60 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage and the target's speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of the Prince of Frost's next turn.

bonus.name: Fey Step {@recharge 4}
entries: The Prince of Frost can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space he can see.

legendaryHeader: The Prince of Frost can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The Prince of Frost regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The Prince of Frost makes one melee attack or casts {@spell ray of frost}.

legendary.name: Blizzard Step (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Prince of Frost uses his Fey Step action if it is available, creating a 20 foot radius burst of frigid snow and wind at either his initial position or his destination. Any creature within the burst takes 11 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage.

legendary.name: Rime Curse (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: The Prince of Frost targets one creature that has taken cold damage this round. The target must, succed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw or become partially encrusted with ice. While encrusted with ice, the creature's speed is halved, it cannot take reactions, and it can't make more than one attack on its turn. In addition, the target can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, but not both. This effect lasts for 1 minute. A target can repeat the saving throw on the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

In the far reaches of the Feywild, there exists a land where the sun never rises and the moon never sets. A realm of towering glaciers and barren orchards, of pitiless ice and driving snow. Here the full moon glares down at fields of silently glistening ice from a sky so clear that every star gleams like a snowflake. Here blizzards move across the plains, carrying with them mountains of snow to blanket the earth. And it is here, in the dream of deepest winter, that resides the Prince of Frost.

entries.name: Tragedy and Sorrow
entries: It is unwise to seek truth in the Feywild, as facts in this dreaming realm are merely a matter of opinion. Far wiser it is to seek stories, and the story of the Prince of Frost is sad and tragic. For you see, he was once known as the Sun Prince, a great and vigorous eladrin lord of light and summer. Betrothed to an elven maiden, he was about to have his dearest wish granted when his love betrayed him and fled his realm, having fallen in love with a human warrior. In his sorrow, the Sun Prince laid a curse upon himself, freezing his heart and razing his realm of warmth and joy.

It is said that the Prince's betrothed and her love fled across the boundaries of time itself in order to escape his wrath, and that they are periodically reincarnated into mortal flesh. The Prince relentlessly seeks out the reincarnations of his lost love in the hopes of reuniting with her, and he seeks the reincarnation of the one she betrayed him for in the hopes of finding his revenge.

entries.name: Mighty Winter
entries: The bitter lord of winter commands the respect of all fey who reside in his cold and barren realm, though they all give him a wide berth. Unlike Oberon, whose passions burn like a mighty bonfire, endearing him to others, the Prince of Frost is cold and calculating. Though he is not unduly cruel, he is utterly without mercy, and there is nothing that can thaw his heart. It is rare to see emotion on his handsome face, though his ire can be raised when thwarted, and he brooks no rudeness or insult. He bears the mantle of winter and plants wither away at his touch.

entries.name: The Palace of Frozen Tears
entries: The Prince of Frost makes his lair in the Fortress of Frozen Tears, a palace of ice that glistens in the perpetual full moon of the Vale of the Long Night. While in his lair, the Prince of Frost can, at will, create items out of ice as if with the {@spell fabricate} spell. Items crafted in this way behave as if made of steel while within the lair, but they behave as regular ice outside of the lair.

entries.name: Flaws of the Prince
entries: If a creature fails a saving throw to resist the effects of extreme cold while within the Prince of Frost's realm or within sight of the archfey, roll on the Flaws of the Prince table to determine the nature of the flaw, which is a character flaw that lasts until cured.

entries.caption: Flaws of the Prince
rows: {@i Love is foolish, and those who succumb to sentiment are worthy of nothing but disdain}.
{@i I resent the happiness of lovers, and will do everything I can to spoil that happiness}.
{@i Love and joy are frivolous. I only have time for my goals and ambitions, and I expect the same out of others}.
{@i Displays of affection disgust me, and if I see anyone openly display affection for another I lose respect for them}.

entries.name: The Vale of the Long Night
entries: Far from the realms of gentle twilight and verdant growth that make up much of the Feywild is a place of bitter cold and eternal night. An endless stretch of unblemished white snow glistens beneath a full moon that seems to swallow the entire night sky. Nothing grows from the frozen soil here, and no joy can survive under the bleak gaze of the cold moon. This is the Vale of the Long Night, a world of perpetual sorrow and winter.

entries.name: The Council of Frozen Voices
entries: Made of scholars, philosophers, monarchs, and other mortals who fell victim to the cruel machinations of the Prince of Frost, the Council of Frozen Voices is a choir of frozen bodies preserved in eternal misery within the Palace of Frozen Tears. They serve as the Prince of Frost's advisers and impart their wisdom to him when he commands it.

entries.name: The Sisters of Lament
entries: Once the Sisters of Delight, the undead Mournwind and Soulsorrow serve their dread lord in the hopes of one day reclaiming their lost innocence. They spread misery and sorrow across the lands touched by winter.

entries.name: Lord Rimeharrow
entries: This {@creature wight} was once a powerful Reghed chieftain. However, he made a deal with the Prince of Frost, and now his soul is forever bound to the fey lord. He does not resent his unending service to the Pale Prince, as he does not believe he would have a good afterlife waiting for him after what he did. He is the Pale Prince's favored envoy to other fey lords, and he performs his duties to the letter, though without passion. He wields an {@i ice brand}.

entries.name: Uzromis
entries: This {@creature ice devil} is sworn to the service of the Prince of Frost by means of a deal struck with Mephistopheles, and she sees to the protection of her lord's realm from outsiders with sadistic glee, brutally slaughtering any who would dare intrude on the Vale of the Long Night uninvited. For those who do carry an invitation, though, she is a staunch guardian, protecting them from the dangers of the wintry realm for as long as her lord decrees.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The abeil vassal makes three attacks, one with its stinger and two with its claws or javelin.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage in melee or at range.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. Additionally, on a failed save the target becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target has disadvantage on all Strength and Constitution saving throws.

bonus.name: Drone
entries: The abeil vassal begins producing a hypnotic droning sound, which it can continue making for up to one minute as if concentrating on a spell. Any creature that isn't an abeil that starts its turn within 30 feet of the abeil must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for 10 minutes. A creature that can't hear the drone automatically succeeds on the save. The effect ends on the creature if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to wake it up. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, it is immune to the drone off all abeil for the next 24 hours.

In the meadows of the Feywild, one might find a magnificent sight. Magnificent, geometric towers constructed of warm, silky wax, as strong as stone, with windows of golden honey crystal rise from the flowery fields. The sonorous drone of a hundred legions of bees creates a soothing lullaby that carries on the gentle winds, and the steady hum of industry thrums from within the warm walls. These are the hives of the abeil.

entries.name: Bee Folk
entries: The abeil resemble large bees with humanoid torsos and elven features, decorated with black and yellow stripes and bearing large gossamer wings. They construct their palace hives out of enchanted wax that the workers produce, working alongside mundane bees, all laboring for the queen. Their palace hives are always teeming with activity, whether it be the rude labor of the normal insects or the higher endeavors of the vassals.

entries.name: Lovers of Labor
entries: Abeil love to work and be productive. The labor of each individual serves the interests of the hive as a whole, and they perform their labors with enthusiasm and delight. However, they are not mindless slaves. Each abeil is an individual, with their own interests and personalities, and they each serve the hive out of genuine love for their mother, the queen.

The backbone of the palace hive, the vassals provide all of the labor that keeps their world running smoothly, from the tending of the gardens, to the preparation of food, to the repairs to the walls. These loyal members of the hive work tirelessly to ensure the survival of their mother and fellow sisters.

entries.name: Bee Helpers
entries: The foundation of the palace hive is the hundreds of beehives for both mundane and giant bees. These loyal insects produce honey and wax and perform the majority of the foraging, while the giant bees are ridden by the vassals like a human might ride a horse. These bees possess an innate understanding of the needs of the hive, and as such it is the honor of the vassals to see to their needs.

entries.name: Vassal Court
entries: Not all of the vassals perform manual labor. Some of them break off from the lives of physical labor lead by their sisters to pursue lives of mental labor; becoming poets, philosophers, artists, and so on. The most skilled of these vassals are especially beloved by their queen and serve as her advisers in the vassal court. The word of the queen is law and her will is unassailable, but she rarely makes a decision without first consulting her vassal court. It is these advisers who exert the most influence over the queen's fancies.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The abeil soldier makes three weapon attacks, only one of which may be its Sting attack.

action.name: Maul
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d8 + 6}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. Additionally, on a failed save the target becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target has disadvantage on all Strength and Constitution saving throws.

action.name: Stormwing {@recharge 5}
entries: The abeil soldier rapidly beats its wings. All creatures within 20 feet of the abeil solider must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) thunder damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. Additionally, on a failure, the target is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute.

bonus.name: Drone
entries: The abeil soldier begins producing a hypnotic droning sound, which it can continue making for up to one minute as if concentrating on a spell. Any creature that isn't an abeil that starts its turn within 30 feet of the abeil soldier must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for 10 minutes. A creature that can't hear the drone automatically succeeds on the save. The effect ends on the creature if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to wake it up. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, it is immune to the drone off all abeil for the next 24 hours.

In the meadows of the Feywild, one might find a magnificent sight. Magnificent, geometric towers constructed of warm, silky wax, as strong as stone, with windows of golden honey crystal rise from the flowery fields. The sonorous drone of a hundred legions of bees creates a soothing lullaby that carries on the gentle winds, and the steady hum of industry thrums from within the warm walls. These are the hives of the abeil.

entries.name: Bee Folk
entries: The abeil resemble large bees with humanoid torsos and elven features, decorated with black and yellow stripes and bearing large gossamer wings. They construct their palace hives out of enchanted wax that the workers produce, working alongside mundane bees, all laboring for the queen. Their palace hives are always teeming with activity, whether it be the rude labor of the normal insects or the higher endeavors of the vassals.

entries.name: Lovers of Labor
entries: Abeil love to work and be productive. The labor of each individual serves the interests of the hive as a whole, and they perform their labors with enthusiasm and delight. However, they are not mindless slaves. Each abeil is an individual, with their own interests and personalities, and they each serve the hive out of genuine love for their mother, the queen.

The soldiers are the first and last line of defense for the palace hives, massive hulking brutes with unswerving loyalty to the hive. As such, they maintain constant, unsleeping vigilance, alert for any threat to their home and family. They regard all strangers with suspicion; for an outsider to gain the full trust of a soldier is virtually impossible. Any who show themselves to be a danger to the hive will find themselves at the mercy of the soldier's enfeebling stings and thunderous wings.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The abeil queen's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the abeil queen fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The abeil queen has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The abeil queen makes three weapon attacks, only one of which can be her sting attack.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Sting
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. Additionally, on a failed save the target becomes {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, the target has disadvantage on all Strength and Constitution saving throws.

bonus.name: Drone
entries: The abeil queen begins producing a hypnotic droning sound, which it can continue making for up to one minute as if concentrating on a spell. Any creature that isn't an abeil that starts its turn within 30 feet of the abeil queen must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition unconscious} for 10 minutes. A creature that can't hear the drone automatically succeeds on the save. The effect ends on the creature if it takes damage or if another creature takes an action to wake it up. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, it is immune to the drone off all abeil for the next 24 hours.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The abeil queen makes one Sting attack.

legendary.name: Command Hive
entries: One {@creature abeil vassal|TheFeyCompendium}, {@creature abeil soldier|TheFeyCompendium}, {@creature giant honey bee|ToB2}, or {@creature swarm of bees|ToB2} loyal to the abeil queen that she can see must use its reaction to move up to its speed as she directs or make a weapon attack against a target that she designates.

In the meadows of the Feywild, one might find a magnificent sight. Magnificent, geometric towers constructed of warm, silky wax, as strong as stone, with windows of golden honey crystal rise from the flowery fields. The sonorous drone of a hundred legions of bees creates a soothing lullaby that carries on the gentle winds, and the steady hum of industry thrums from within the warm walls. These are the hives of the abeil.

entries.name: Bee Folk
entries: The abeil resemble large bees with humanoid torsos and elven features, decorated with black and yellow stripes and bearing large gossamer wings. They construct their palace hives out of enchanted wax that the workers produce, working alongside mundane bees, all laboring for the queen. Their palace hives are always teeming with activity, whether it be the rude labor of the normal insects or the higher endeavors of the vassals.

entries.name: Lovers of Labor
entries: Abeil love to work and be productive. The labor of each individual serves the interests of the hive as a whole, and they perform their labors with enthusiasm and delight. However, they are not mindless slaves. Each abeil is an individual, with their own interests and personalities, and they each serve the hive out of genuine love for their mother, the queen.

The heart and soul of the palace hive, the queen maintains the cohesion of the hive and guide it in whatever direction she sees fit. This often leads to hives that are dedicated to the pursuit of a particular artistic endeavor, such as cooking or architecture, while other hives may pursue textiles or agriculture. The direction of the hives considerable manual and artistic labours are ultimately directed by their Queen.

entries.name: Princes and Princesses
entries: The queen is the mother of all the members of her hive, and they are all her daughters. She gives birth to them as helpless larvae, which are tended to by their sisters until they mature into fully fledged vassals and soldiers, save for the few whom she personally rears, tutoring them in the ways of ruling, grooming them as princesses. However, when a hive begins to grow particularly large and the queen decides that it is time, she begins to give birth to princes. Princes are unlike their sisters. They are lazy and rakish, seeing little appeal in the labors that their kin take such joy in. They prefer to spend their days either relaxing in the hive or exploring the surrounding countryside, playing pranks on those that they encounter. These layabouts will eventually be forced out of the hive by their sisters, and will search far and wide for hives with other princesses, whom they will wholeheartedly court in the interest of gaining a new home to mooch from. Once a princess chooses a husband, or husbands, she will drink the royal honey that transforms her into a queen.

entries.name: Telling the Bees
entries: Abeil queens are always curious for information, and as such will seek to gain it through whatever channels she can find. One such method is the construction of a Melissae Token, which she will give to a swarm of bees before sending them on their way. A hive built around this Melissae Token becomes a queen's eyes and ears in both the Feywild and the Material Plane. Mortals who live near an abeil palace hive tend to have numerous superstitions about bees and beekeeping, such as that if you do not tell your bees about important family events that they will leave your household or that if you swear at your bees that you will have poor fortune. Such superstitions likely derive from the consequences of having a hive that serves an abeil queen.

entries.name: Oracle Queens
entries: Very rarely, rather than compete with each other, a trio of abeil queens will unite into a group known as a thriae. These thriae abandon their palace hives in favor of remote mountaintops or islands, eschewing their hundreds of vassal daughters to instead maintain a small retinue to see to their needs. These trios work together to unlock the secrets of divination, learning the technique of brewing honey which, when consumed, grants sight beyond sight. They may be willing to grant those that seek them a taste, for a price.

entries.name: The Palace Hives
entries: An abeil palace hive is a remarkable place. The walls and floors, though hard as stone, feel soft and slightly warm, and the sunlight that filters in through the honey crystal windows bathes everything that is seen in an unearthly golden glow. The very walls serve as homes for hives of mundane bees, and spaces for gardens are everywhere.

entries.name: Lair Actions
entries: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the abeil queen takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects. An abeil queen encountered in her lair has a Challenge Rating of 15 (13,000 XP).

items: A swarming cloud of bees fills a 20-foot radius sphere centered on a point the abeil queen chooses within 120 feet of her. The cloud spreads around corners and remains until the abeil queen dismisses it as a bonus action, uses this lair action again, or dies. The area in the cloud is lightly obscured. Any creature in the cloud when it appears must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. A creature that ends its turn in the cloud takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage.
The abeil queen causes four {@creature giant bee|ToB2}s or {@creature swarm of bees|ToB2} to appear in unoccupied spaces that she chooses within the lair.
Up to three abeil vassals, abeil soldiers, giant bees, or swarms of bees that are loyal to the abeil queen can use their reactions to move up to their speed and make one weapon attack.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The area surrounding an abeil palace hive is warped by the hive queen's magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: All abeils within 1 miles of the palace hive maintain a low level telepathic connection with all other abeil loyal to their queen within 10 miles of the palace hive. This does not allow for the intentional transmission of information. Rather, it grants all affected members approximate knowledge of the location of other members of the hive, alerts all other members of the hive to danger, and provides up to date understanding of the terrain.

Bees within 1 miles of the palace hive are typically loyal to the queen and serve as her eyes and ears. These bees may be more or less aggressive than normal depending on the queen's disposition toward the party.
Flowering plants grow in especially great profusion within 10 miles of the palace hive.

entries: If the queen dies and there is no princess to replace her, the flowering plant quantity stays the same, but the other effects fade over {@dice 1d10} days as the hive loses cohesion.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The elder treant's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 17}, {@hit 9} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the elder treant remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a massive tree.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the elder treant fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Empowered Strikes
entries: The elder treant's attacks count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The elder treant deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The elder treant can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elder treant can use its Create Treant action. It then makes two slam attacks or one Rock attack.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 15} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d6 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 15} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}35 ({@damage 4d12 + 9}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Create Treant
entries: The elder treant magically animates up to two trees that it can see within 60 feet of itself and loses 30 hit points for each tree animated. The trees gain the statistics of a {@creature treant} with maximum hit points. The treants revert back to normal trees if the elder treant is reduced to 0 hit points, taking root if possible. The elder treant cannot have more than two trees animated at a time.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The elder treant makes one melee attack.

legendary.name: Entangle
entries: The elder treant casts {@spell entangle}.

In the ancient forests of the world, deeper than all but the most knowledgeable of druids dare to travel, reside the elder treants. Old beyond reckoning, these arboreal titans are so ancient as to recall the time before the first elven empires, when the drow had yet to break from their kin and the other races were but children. Ponderous and thoughtful, elder treants are slow to anger, but when their ire is raised the ground trembles with their fury for miles.

entries.name: Soul of the Forest
entries: An elder treant is a part of its forest as much as the forest is a part of it. It's made of bones of the branches and boughs. Its soul is the deep green twilight and the brow beating sun above the canopy. Its fingers extend to the leaves and hold the daylight. The forest lives inside its spirit. Druids will seek out an elder treant with the same reverence that a pilgrim might seek out a holy sight.

entries.name: Heroes of the Fey
entries: Even in the Feywild, elder treants are incredibly rare. The few who do live in the world are regarded as heroes and royalty by the lesser fey. Even Archfey grant them a significant degree of respect, making elder treants akin to fey lords themselves. However, elder treants have no interest at all in the petty politics of the fey courts, nor in the mad cap jokes or joyous hunts of the wild fey. They are content to contemplate their arboreal realms, tending to its needs and protecting it from harm.

entries.name: Relkath of the Infinite Branches
entries: Far from the Sword Coast, across the Sea of Fallen Stars, is the Yuirwood, a cloaked realm of ancient ruins and deep forests, a realm of elves and fey. Wandering these woods is Relkath of the Infinite Branches, wise and dangerous. Relkath uses the same statistics as the Elder Treant, but has the following additional trait and a Challenge Rating of 21 (33,000 XP):

{@b Green Curse.} If a creature starts its turn with 120 feet of Relkath and it can see the creature, Relkath can can force the creature to make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save the creature magically begins to polymorph into a tree and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is polymorphed into a tree of its same size category. While a tree, the creature retains its hit points, has AC 16, vulnerability to fire damage, and resistance to bludgeoning and piercing damage. The creature remains a tree until freed by the {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic. A creature becomes immune to this effect for 24 hours on a successful save.

entries.name: Regional Effects
entries: The region containing a tireganierk's lair is enriched by the fey's presence, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Plant life is hardier within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair. All plant life benefits from the effects of the plant growth spell as if with the 8 hour casting time version. All plant life is better able to resist the cold, and any plant monsters native to the area or conjured within the area has resistance to cold damage.
Creatures friendly to the tireganierk have advantage on saving throws to resist {@condition exhaustion}.

The first time a humanoid harms animal or plant life while within 3 miles of the tireganierk's lair, it must perform a {@dc 15} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, the creature's sense of direction becomes useless for 1 week. During that time, all Survival checks that it makes to prevent becoming lost automatically fail, and all Survival checks to forage for food and track have disadvantage. The creature can perform the saving throw again after each long rest, ending the effects early on a success.

entries: If the tireganierk dies, the enriched soil remains for several seasons. All other effects fade over {@dice 2d10} days.

trait.name: Cruel Noon
entries: The chirtelma has advantage on all attacks made against targets that are illuminated by bright sunlight.

trait.name: Lurker in the Light
entries: As long as it is in an area bright sunlight, the chirtelma and any equipment worn or carried by it is {@condition invisible}.

trait.name: Heatstroke
entries: Any creatures within 30 feet of the chirtelma that are illuminated by bright sunlight must perform a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw at the beginning of their turn. On a failed saving throw, the creature is under the effects of the {@spell confusion} spell until the beginning of its next turn. For every three saving throws failed, the creature gains one level of {@condition exhaustion}. The failed saving throws do not need to be sequential. Fey and creatures that have an immunity or resistance to fire damage automatically succeed on this saving throw, and creatures that are adapted to hot climates or that are at least partially submerged in cool liquid have advantage on the saving throw. Creatures clad in medium or heavy armor, wearing heavy clothing, or who have vulnerability to fire damage make the saving throw with disadvantage.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The chirtelma has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The chirtelma's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Scythe (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d4 + 4}) slashing damage.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Heat Shimmer
entries: The chirtelma magically polymorphs into a heat shimmer, or back into its humanoid form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. In heat shimmer form, the chirtelma gains the statistics of a {@creature invisible stalker}, but retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, and damage resistances and immunities and does not have the Faultless Tracker feature.

A chirtelma is a cruel and beautiful fey of summer that loves nothing more than tormenting and killing humanoids toiling out in the hot fields. Empowered by sunlight, this childlike fairy has no fear of retribution so long as the sun is bright in the sky.

entries.name: Lurker in the Light
entries: While in bright sunlight, a chirtelma is invisible, totally undetectable save for a wisp of dust in the hot air. They stalk through summer fields in search of unwary workers or travelers. When they find a victim they approach the target unseen as nothing more than a whisper on the wind, bringing with them a stifling heat. A chirtelma enjoys cruel games, and it will draw out the death of its victim for as long as it finds it amusing. Once bored with this game, a chirtelma will chop off its victim's head with its blazing scythe, though if it's feeling generous it may leave its victims a gibbering wreck, their brains half cooked.

entries.name: Fear of the Dark
entries: A chirtelma hates shadows, because in darkness its true, childlike form is revealed and its powers over its victims are robbed. Even the shade offered by an oak tree or under a wagon may be enough to deter a chirtelma. They also shun cool water, and swimming across a running stream is said to frighten them off. During the night and rainy days, a chirtelma will shelter itself in remote, out of the way areas, often guarded by other lesser fey such as sprites and dryads.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The coure's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save @{dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The coure has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The coure can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of the coure includes its Charisma bonus while it isn't wearing armor or wielding a shield.

action.name: Magic Bolt (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) force damage.

action.name: Superior Invisibility
entries: The coure magically turns {@condition invisible} until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the coure wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Starlight
entries: The coure can transform into a Tiny ball of starlight or back into its true form. In light form, the coure has immunity to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical weapons, produces bright light out to 10 feet and dim light out to an additional 10 feet, and can pass through solid objects, taking 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn within a solid object. In this form, the coure is immune to being {@condition grappled}, knocked {@condition prone}, and {@condition restrained}.

The coure are the sidhe of whimsy and fun. Appearing as beautiful children with butterfly wings, these sidhe rule over coteries of pixies, sprites, and other diminutive fey. These fey love little more than pranks, and they lead their fairy brothers and sisters in daring adventures of whismy. However, they are also surprisingly conscientious, and they take the well being of their subjects very seriously.

entries.name: A Sad Tale
entries: An old eladrin story says that coure are actually the spirits of eladrin who died while still children, reborn into fairies that they may experience all the fun that they were robbed. Though many scholars dispute this, as there is no evidence to support it, the facts behind a story are not as important as the sound of a story in the Feywild, and the story persists.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The firre's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Gentle Flames
entries: Whenever the firre would deal fire damage, it can choose to exclude plantlife from being affected by the fire.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The firre has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The firre's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Unearthly Grace
entries: The AC of the firre includes its Charisma bonus while it isn't wearing armor or wielding a shield.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The firre can use its Gaze. It then makes two weapon attacks or begins to sing. The firre can cast an at will spell from its Innate Spellcasting instead of making an attack.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage, plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) lightning damage.

action.name: Javelin
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage in melee or at range, plus 11 ({@damage 2d10}) fire damage if thrown.

action.name: Gaze
entries: The firre targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition blinded} for 1 minute and ignite into flames. Until a creature takes an action to douse the fire, the target takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Song
entries: The firre begins to sing and chooses one of the following magical effects: a charming melody, a glorious aria, a gentle lullaby, or a persuasive ballad. Any creature within 60 feet of the firre that can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be affected as described below for as long as the firre continues to sing. The firre must take a bonus action on its subsequent turns to continue singing. It can stop singing at any time. The song ends if the firre is {@condition incapacitated}. Other sidhe and creatures that can't be {@condition charmed} are unaffected.

An affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to that effect for the next 24 hours.

items: {@b Charming Melody.} The creature is {@condition charmed} by the firre for 1 minute. If the firre or any of its companions harms the creature, the effect on it ends immediately.
{@b Glorious Aria.} The creature is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. If the firre or any of its companions harms the creature, the effect on it ends immediately.
{@b Gentle Lullaby.} The creature falls asleep and is {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. The effect ends if the creature takes damage or if someone takes an action to shake the creature awake.
{@b Persuasive Ballad.} The creature is affected as if by the suggestion spell for 1 minute. If the firre or any of its companions harms the creature, the effect on it ends immediately.

bonus.name: Sidhe Shape: Pillar of Flame
entries: The firre can magically polymorph into a pillar of fire or back into its humanoid form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying is absorbed by the new form. In fire form, the firre has the statistics of a fire elemental but retains its hit points, alignment, Intelligence, Wisdom, Charisma, damage resistances and immunities, and has a flying speed of 50 feet (hover).

reaction.name: Inspiration
entries: The firre adds {@dice 1d6} to an attack roll, saving throw, or skill check made by a creature within 60 feet of it that can hear the firre.

The forests of the Feywild contain many trails and if you travel down them long enough, chances are you might meet a tall elven figure with bright auburn hair and eyes that burn with an inner fire. This is a firre, a living spirit of flame whose passion for music burns within them as a literal fire.

entries.name: Bards and Troubadours
entries: firre loves nothing so much as music, and they travel the Feywild and the mortal realms alike in search of new songs, adding to their ever growing repetoire. They are highly sought after by archfey, but they rarely stay in one place for long, their wanderlust drawing their feet back to the paths of the world.

entries.name: Music of the Soul
entries: The music of a firre can reach into even the most hardened of hearts, inflaming them with passion, crippling them with beauty, or swaying them.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ghaele's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ghaele has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The ghaele's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghaele can use its Gaze action. It then makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword (Humanoid Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) slashing damage, plus 22 ({@damage 4d10}) lightning damage.

action.name: Gaze
